story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Yiqing Zhao. I'm an NYC-based Asian actress/singer ( More about me: www.yiqingzhao.com) This is my first play and I'm so excited to produce it this summer!

"Lost and Found " will be produced at Hudson Guild Theatre with an all-Asian cast, as a part of the NY Summerfest.

Play Synopsis: After a dark secret has been revealed, Tommy separates with his girlfriend. Meanwhile, he meets with Maggie, now a successful writer, who was in love with him in high school. As he is inspired by Maggie and ready to start a career with her, he is devastated by the multiple blows that come at him. Will he survive?

I am launching this campaign to gather funds for the production. Your help means a lot to me!

 

Campaign Details:

I am trying to raise $1,000 for the entire production of this play. This will cover:

The participation fee of the theatre festival( $257), rehearsal space rental( $15 per hour, 30 hours of rehearsal), props purchase( $200, including books, plates, cups and utensils, fake food, etc), Marketing expenses( $150, including printing of posters and postcards, playbills, etc).

If I fail to reach this goal, I will have to take a loan from the bank to make the production happen.

Perks:

Whoever donates over $50 will get a postcard from us signed by all our cast!

The Impact

This original play explores the ideas of friendship, romantic relationships, deception, integrity, ambition, and life and death, by telling the life stories of four young people who reunite in NYC 6 years after high school graduation. It's moving, it's based on true stories, and it has an all-Asian cast, which is not very common in theatre. By contributing to this campaign, you are helping a female playwright put her story into life. You are also helping a bunch of young actors shine on their beloved stage! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word and come the see the show! Words of encouragement are very much appreciated too! You can always reach me (me@yiqingzhao.com)

story:
Short Summary

Together, we can make an amazing, hilarious, and empowering show, on this conservative budget, that will inspire young women to stop playing small. It will inspire everyone who sees the show to value the feminine all around them:

  • As a circus-theatre artist, I tackle big questions with charm and bawdiness. As a teacher, I have seen how kids are often taught to value the masculine ways of doing things, without regard to compassion and equilibrium.
  • We had a great show last year, which was thought-provoking and touching. It inspired hundreds of people to think about how feelings can guide us as much as what's 'been done before.' How letting our hearts break is a sign of being on the right path, rather than being a weakness. How following our heart's desires is more than a Disney song. Everything I wish my Granny had said.
  • I am taking this material to a residency in Maine, working with a new director, and getting the show ready to tour college campuses.
  • Art is a powerful way to incite change in our world. A show like mine gets into people's hearts and affects them in a way  political campaigns can fail to do.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Since I am fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, your donations are TAX-DEDUCTIBLE!
  • The bulk of this funding is for rehearsal fees and paying my director what she's worth. This show has also been accepted to a residency in Maine this summer, which has a $1400 price tag. The full budget:

    • Director & Rehearsal Fees: $2240

    • Costumes: $305

    • Props: $110

    • Performers' Insurance: $285

    • Residency: $1400

    • NACA Membership to book College Venues: $634

  • Your dollars (VOTES!) count. Where you choose to spend your money, and what you help to flourish, speaks loudly. This campaign will help you make your voice even louder, with help to contact your representatives about where you want your money to go.
  • And there are funny greeting card perks, too! So you can improve the world, one laugh at a time.

The Impact

  • Funding that used to be available to artists like myself is getting scarcer and scarcer through the world of grants. The new paradigm is groundroots: people like you supporting arts and messages that you believe in.
  • Your dollars can counteract proposed cuts the the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the National Endowment for the Arts.
  • A recent New York Times article explained how the proposed cuts are "about control. It’s about creating a society where propaganda reigns and dissent is silenced." You have power to help curb that control.
  • https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/06/opinion/why-authoritarians-attack-the-arts.html?smid=go-share&utm_source=Fractured+Atlas+Communications&utm_campaign=25a5117d2a-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2016_12_27&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_df4ecc1677-25a5117d2a-390633137
  • I have created 6 original shows that have received rave reviews and all came in at budget.

Risks & Realities

  • Some artists have a habit of leaking money designated for a show into an inefficient or prolonged process that doesn't show results. I am dedicated to an actual timeline that has helped me get six previous shows mounted and applauded in record time.
  • Some residencies are a risk to invest in, because the creative process can be so fickle. I have worked with this residency's leader, Giovanni Fusetti from Padua, Italy on numerous projects. He reliably supports the creation of work that is hilarious and honest.
  • Another residency at the same facility in Maine was the launchpad for my 2nd one-woman show in 2010.
  • Offering to paying a director as a collaborator is a big risk many artists don't take. Because I believe in my director, and in her expertise and experience, (and because I believe in supporting the arts), I am committed to paying other artists for their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't give? Tell! https://igg.me/at/GrannySays

  • Please forward this campaign link to someone you know who cares about the arts.
  • Even clicking on some of the videos below helps bring awareness to the campaign!

  • Donate your time / expertise:

    • We’ll get a lot of perks to send out, so if you have extra stamps, envelopes, or time to help put the rewards together, I will be immensely grateful! 

    • Do you sew? YOU could be the seamstress I hire for the new costumes!

  • You can also help by making sure you laugh 7-12 times every day.

Costumes: $305
Props: $110
Performers' Insurance: $285
Residency: $1400
NACA Membership to book College Venues: $634


Your dollars (VOTES!) count. Where you choose to spend your money, and what you help to flourish, speaks loudly. This campaign will help you make your voice even louder, with help to contact your representatives about where you want your money to go.

Another residency at the same facility in Maine was the launchpad for my 2nd one-woman show in 2010.

Other Ways You Can Help
Can't give? Tell! https://igg.me/at/GrannySays

Please forward this campaign link to someone you know who cares about the arts.
Even clicking on some of the videos below helps bring awareness to the campaign!

Donate your time / expertise:

We’ll get a lot of perks to send out, so if you have extra stamps, envelopes, or time to help put the rewards together, I will be immensely grateful! 
Do you sew? YOU could be the seamstress I hire for the new costumes!


You can also help by making sure you laugh 7-12 times every day.

story:
Help a Clown Today

Your contributions will go towards helping our rehabilitated clowns reach their dreams and support our efforts to take them to their natural home - The Edinburgh Fringe Festival. 

Beadledom: Alpha and Omega is the next stage in the C.O.R.P. project, two solo clown shows which will provide emerging clowns Dott Cotton and Edward Cartwright with the platform they so desperately need.

Why we need your help

Taking these shows to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival marks a huge milestone in the rehabilitation of our clowns, but it doesn't come cheap. We need to make sure that Dott and Ed are housed and transported to Edinburgh. We need to make sure that their shows are designed and lit to make them happy. We need to make sure they have music. We need to make sure that their team of clown therapists are there with them (Designer - Lily Faith Knight, Composer - Spesh Maloney, Production Manager - Abi Toghill, Movement Director - Bronwen Wilson and Director - Becca Cox). Above all we need to make sure they have an audience. Without these things we will not be able to preserve the incredible progress that we have already made and we will finally be able to coax Ed out of that box.

Where the money will go

Accommodation - In Edinburgh is an expensive business. We would put £1500 towards comfortable rooms for our clowns, with wardrobe space for those big shoes and a place to hang up their noses

Transport - We need to get our clowns, our set and our props to Edinburgh and back again - a pedal car just won't cut it so we need a van. £400 will go towards getting everything there and back again

Marketing - Our clowns can't cope without an audience. We need to create trailers, flyers and posters to make sure that people come and see them. The alternative is unthinkable. £400 will go towards making this happen

Set / Costume / Props - Every clown needs things to play with and somewhere to play with them in. We will put £675 towards getting all of the materials we need to make the 2 shows happen

Butter and Top Hats - We have come to realise that Dott Cotton cannot operate without butter. It is her life blood. The only thing we can find to tempt Ed out of the box are top hats. £25 will provide enough butter and top hats to sustain a Dott and Ed for a month. Without this we cannot guarantee their survival.

About the Shows

A new pair of shows from Familia de la Noche. Set in Beadledom, an infinite office block and the headquarters of the Universe, Familia have created a pair of shows - α and Ω - that explore what makes humans tick. What makes the difference between a brilliant flash of life and a dull flicker? The Beadledoms are twins, but they are not identical. They are designed to be viewed individually but also jigsaw together to make a giant, glorious, messy, sad, happy, beautiful story- A bit like life.

Beadledom α: Follows the story of Max (Edward Cartwright (ITV/Les Enfants Terribles/National Geographic)), a Beadledom administrator on α-shift as he toils away populating the universe with life. Until a catastrophic cosmos malfunction leaves Max facing the biggest system reset of all time.

Beadledom Ω: Follows the story of Deborah (Dott Cotton(Les Enfants Terribles/London Hippodrome)), a Beadledom administrator on Ω-shift as she slogs away removing life from the universe. But she is obsessed with life, she longs to create one. Maybe today is her lucky day.

More info about the shows HERE

We realise this is a lot of money. But. There are two shows. With two extraordinary clowns. And one chance to make it happen. If you can't contribute please share - let the world know how much these clowns need help.

Remember - It's never too late to love a clown

story:
Who Are We?

Louanne Moldovan: Founder and Artistic Director of Cygnet Productions has been producing award winning theatre in the Portland area for over 18 years.  This past year Louanne directed the critically acclaimed production of The Set Up, winning the 2016 Drammy Award for Outstanding Ensemble and she recently directed Elizabeth in another solo show for the Arabian Shakespeare Company in San Francisco called We Made Bread by Jennifer Le Blanc. Aside from directing, Louanne is a stellar actress, an accomplished writer, mother and activist.

Elizabeth Huffman: Actor, Playwright, Artistic Director and founder of Chain Reaction, a new producing company specifically for international exchanges and multi ethnic productions. Elizabeth has been the Artistic Director of 4 classical companies and has won a total of 8 Drammy Awards for her directing, and costume designs.  She has taken 6 productions to Europe through her former company ICAP and invited two productions to come to Los Angeles from Germany. Elizabeth will be directing another one of her plays, Bon Temps Roulez at the Shakespeare Café, in January 2017 for the renowned Bremer Shakespeare Company in Bremen, Germany.   She is an award winning Equity actress and has performed in regional theatre across the USA and internationally.

What Is This About?

We are in the process of raising the funds to finish creating our new multi-media touring production of our acclaimed solo show: Not My Revolution.  This unique and powerful solo show resonates to current events as a timely cautionary tale and in the midst of the devastation of war, finds its way toward redemption. 

Not My Revolution reaped immediate critical acclaim and has been challenging audiences to question their position on refugees, to recognize that war is the great leveler, and that everyone is vulnerable.  After seeing the play and discussing it in talkbacks, many audience members are moved to ask what they can do to help.  We want to keep this conversation going, to reach into the heartland of America as well as the cultural landscape abroad to those who have been resistant to the idea of welcoming refugees into their community and impact that dynamic through experiencing this theatrical journey.

In the play, audiences witness a wealthy and successful Syrian woman’s descent into displacement and her loss of family and home due to a bloody revolution at the same time we meet another woman who shares a similar journey but in a different revolution in time: Marie Antoinette. During the night their stories counterpoint each other and diverge when a third character Adila, a young Syrian protester, influences the future of the Displaced Woman while Marie's execution is inevitable.

The play is relatable to all people who have lost their homes and families due to war, political oppression or catastrophic circumstances. Anyone is susceptible - from the richest in the land to the poorest. The conversation in the post-play talkbacks have been tremendously moving and inspiring.

Why We Think Not My Revolution is an Important Project to Support!

If we can help people to engage in conversation together after seeing the show, we can assist the audiences toward empathy and a better understanding of the refugees lives and circumstances. We want to inspire them to reach a place of compassion in their hearts and welcome them in their community;  to aid them to get back on their feet again and become the valued members of society they had been before war destroyed their lives.  Your contribution to this project will be supporting that effort, one step and one show at a time. 

What your contribution will help us to achieve

To complete the editing of the newly filmed portion of the show

      To complete the creation of our unique and portable set

      To purchase a projector and laptop to run the show anywhere on tour

      To rent rehearsal and theatre space for our presentation in late August 

      To pay our designers, director and technicians for their time and considerable skills

      To hire an assistant to help with marketing, grant writing and booking arrangements

      To create brochures, promo videos, postcards and website 

       To help purchase plane, train & automobile fares, housing and festival fees                            

What We Will Give You for Your Support

Without a doubt you would have our most heartfelt thanks. But we also want to thank you in other ways as well. Check out our fabulous perks!

$25- Fantastic Friends: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media as a Fantastic Friend.

$50: Sweet Supporters: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media as a Sweet Supporter Plus A Not My Revolution postcard signed by the cast, director and designers.

$100- Prominent Patrons: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media as one of our Particular Patrons PLUS a very pretty Marie Antoinette style fan or snuff box.

$250- Sensational Sponsors: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as one of our Sensational Sponsors PLUS a 5 x 7 signed & framed picture of the poster image.

$500: Avid Advocate: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as an Avid Advocate PLUS a 2018 Not My Revolution Calendar with pictures from all of the productions and two tickets to the show!

$750: Cheeky Champion: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as a Cheeky Champion PLUS a Not My Revolution T- shirt of our cool poster image and two tickets to the show!

$1000 and up- Beneficent Benefactor: 

A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as a Beneficent Benefactor PLUS a signed and beautifully bound copy of the script, A tray of delicious Syrian baklava sent to your house, two tickets to the show and...A chance to win the beautiful hand made quilt by Susan Magazine!

The Grand Prize for the largest donation is a beautiful handmade quilt by Susan Magazine depicting French and Middle Eastern textiles of fabric woven together. This will be announced then sent to the lucky winner when we reach our goal of $15,000!

Other Ways to Help

We know that a gift of money is not always possible but never fear there are lots of other ways to give support!

Plane tickets 

If you have mileage and are willing to donate 2 domestic plane ticket or even better, 2 international tickets, we will send you one of our special personalized show calendars… A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media!

Housing  

If we are traveling internationally to your city and you can house two or possibly three people while we are in your town we will bring you a sweet basket of Middle Eastern and French pastries … A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media!

See the Show and Pass the Word

If you are willing to forward this campaign page to your friends and colleagues who might be interested in contributing send out our link on your social media, email lists and encourage them to give if they can;  Twitter about it;  it will be far more interesting and helpful than the tweets coming daily from the White House!

Most Importantly: Come to see the show when we are in your town and bring a friend or two...that is also a great way to support this project!

Risks and Challenges

Creating a multi-media show like this is a huge undertaking and we need the time and resources to ensure that it is given the best possible effort to succeed. However we do have a Plan B and even a Plan C in place if we do not raise the money in this campaign.   We know the play can succeed without the film component, having already proved itself successful both internationally and more recently in New Mexico.  We can continue to move audiences on a barebones basis until we can find the additional financial support to complete our more professional vision of the project.  We are applying for various grants and corporate sponsorship and have been blessed with the initial start up and continued support from our dear friend and show sponsor, Ronni LaCroute. Your contribution, any contribution, will help us to finish the project and take it on the road to festivals, theatres and universities worldwide!

 Upon completion our new version audiences worldwide will be able to experience of the story with a far more compelling and universally accessible means of communication speaking to all nationalities across the globe and your contribution will also help to aid refugees in need every time we perform the show.  

Your generous donation will be tax deductible (Tax ID #93-1126712), and will be an invaluable contribution in bringing this stellar project to life!

Reviews/Articles/Radio Interviews 

Articles

https://www.cuntismmag.com/sisters-1/elizabeth-huffman-one-woman-revolution

https://www.abqjournal.com/1002984/not-my-revolution-explores-life-as-a-refugee.html

USA Reviews

https://www.abqjournal.com/1009488/onewoman-play-a-gripping-tale-of-syrian-refugee.html

http://www.talkinbroadway.com/page/regional/alb/alb422.html​

Radio Interviews

http://www.opb.org/radio/programs/state-of-wonder/article/syria-refugee-crisis-theater-portland-huffman/

http://www.classicalkhfm.com/brent-stevens-page/

German Language Reviews

http://www.weser-kurier.de/bremen/bremen-kultur-freizeit_artikel,-Was-dem-Leben-Sinnund-Wuerde-gibt-_arid,1471920.html

https://www.kreiszeitung.de/kultur/opfer-teil-problems-6818883.html

https://www.taz.de/Archiv-Suche/!5346643&s=French+gray&SuchRahmen=Print/

The conversation in the post-play talkbacks have been tremendously moving and inspiring.Why We Think Not My Revolution is an Important Project to Support!If we can help people to engage in conversation together after seeing the show, we can assist the audiences toward empathy and a better understanding of the refugees lives and circumstances. We want to inspire them to reach a place of compassion in their hearts and welcome them in their community;  to aid them to get back on their feet again and become the valued members of society they had been before war destroyed their lives.  Your contribution to this project will be supporting that effort, one step and one show at a time. What your contribution will help us to achieveTo complete the editing of the newly filmed portion of the show      To complete the creation of our unique and portable set      To purchase a projector and laptop to run the show anywhere on tour      To rent rehearsal and theatre space for our presentation in late August       To pay our designers, director and technicians for their time and considerable skills      To hire an assistant to help with marketing, grant writing and booking arrangements      To create brochures, promo videos, postcards and website        To help purchase plane, train & automobile fares, housing and festival fees                            What We Will Give You for Your SupportWithout a doubt you would have our most heartfelt thanks. But we also want to thank you in other ways as well. Check out our fabulous perks!$25- Fantastic Friends: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media as a Fantastic Friend.$50: Sweet Supporters: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media as a Sweet Supporter Plus A Not My Revolution postcard signed by the cast, director and designers.$100- Prominent Patrons: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media as one of our Particular Patrons PLUS a very pretty Marie Antoinette style fan or snuff box.$250- Sensational Sponsors: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as one of our Sensational Sponsors PLUS a 5 x 7 signed & framed picture of the poster image.$500: Avid Advocate: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as an Avid Advocate PLUS a 2018 Not My Revolution Calendar with pictures from all of the productions and two tickets to the show!$750: Cheeky Champion: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as a Cheeky Champion PLUS a Not My Revolution T- shirt of our cool poster image and two tickets to the show!$1000 and up- Beneficent Benefactor: A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name or business in our program and on all social media listing you as a Beneficent Benefactor PLUS a signed and beautifully bound copy of the script, A tray of delicious Syrian baklava sent to your house, two tickets to the show and...A chance to win the beautiful hand made quilt by Susan Magazine!The Grand Prize for the largest donation is a beautiful handmade quilt by Susan Magazine depicting French and Middle Eastern textiles of fabric woven together. This will be announced then sent to the lucky winner when we reach our goal of $15,000!Other Ways to HelpWe know that a gift of money is not always possible but never fear there are lots of other ways to give support!Plane tickets If you have mileage and are willing to donate 2 domestic plane ticket or even better, 2 international tickets, we will send you one of our special personalized show calendars… A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media!Housing  If we are traveling internationally to your city and you can house two or possibly three people while we are in your town we will bring you a sweet basket of Middle Eastern and French pastries … A huge happy thank you, inclusion of your name in our program and on all social media!See the Show and Pass the WordIf you are willing to forward this campaign page to your friends and colleagues who might be interested in contributing send out our link on your social media, email lists and encourage them to give if they can;  Twitter about it;  it will be far more interesting and helpful than the tweets coming daily from the White House!Most Importantly: Come to see the show when we are in your town and bring a friend or two...that is also a great way to support this project!Risks and ChallengesCreating a multi-media show like this is a huge undertaking and we need the time and resources to ensure that it is given the best possible effort to succeed. However we do have a Plan B and even a Plan C in place if we do not raise the money in this campaign.   We know the play can succeed without the film component, having already proved itself successful both internationally and more recently in New Mexico.  We can continue to move audiences on a barebones basis until we can find the additional financial support to complete our more professional vision of the project.  We are applying for various grants and corporate sponsorship and have been blessed with the initial start up and continued support from our dear friend and show sponsor, Ronni LaCroute. Your contribution, any contribution, will help us to finish the project and take it on the road to festivals, theatres and universities worldwide! Upon completion our new version audiences worldwide will be able to experience of the story with a far more compelling and universally accessible means of communication speaking to all nationalities across the globe and your contribution will also help to aid refugees in need every time we perform the show.  Your generous donation will be tax deductible (Tax ID #93-1126712), and will be an invaluable contribution in bringing this stellar project to life!Reviews/Articles/Radio Interviews Articleshttps://www.cuntismmag.com/sisters-1/elizabeth-huffman-one-woman-revolutionhttps://www.abqjournal.com/1002984/not-my-revolution-explores-life-as-a-refugee.htmlUSA Reviewshttps://www.abqjournal.com/1009488/onewoman-play-a-gripping-tale-of-syrian-refugee.htmlhttp://www.talkinbroadway.com/page/regional/alb/alb422.html​Radio Interviewshttp://www.opb.org/radio/programs/state-of-wonder/article/syria-refugee-crisis-theater-portland-huffman/http://www.classicalkhfm.com/brent-stevens-page/German Language Reviewshttp://www.weser-kurier.de/bremen/bremen-kultur-freizeit_artikel,-Was-dem-Leben-Sinnund-Wuerde-gibt-_arid,1471920.htmlhttps://www.kreiszeitung.de/kultur/opfer-teil-problems-6818883.htmlhttps://www.taz.de/Archiv-Suche/!5346643&s=French+gray&SuchRahmen=Print/​​​​​

story:
Who are we?

 We're Chase What Flies: Progressive Theatre, Classic Words.

In the summer of 2014, actors Frank Weidner and Jordan Klomp met when they shared the stage and worked in education  at Will Geer's Theatricum Botanicum. They quickly developed a friendship over a shared love of Shakespeare, social consciousness, and theatre education. Several years, productions, and co-taught classes later, Jordan approached Frank with an idea: a production of William Shakespeare's Cymbeline, performed by an ensemble of passionate and hardworking Classical Actors who shared in the duo's desire to tell an important story with rich language. They gathered friends and actors from across LA's premier theatre companies, and performed to an enthusiastic, sold-out crowd in 2016, and decided to name their ensemble after one of the play's most whimsical passages. And so, Chase what Flies was born. They now turn their attention to telling a sad story about the death of kings with Richard the Second.

What We Need and What You Get

  • Chase What Flies is a completely self-funded collective: we have no corporate backing or grants, only ticket sales and donations. We are not a company; rather, a group of artists putting in our own time and money to bring quality theatre to our community. Every cent we receive from donations goes directly towards set construction, theatre rental, and most importantly, reimbursing our tireless team for all of their talent and dedication. For Richard the Second, we have set our goal for $6000, in order to keep ticket prices affordable while simultaneously fairly compensating our cast and crew.
  • Of course, your generosity and support won't go unrewarded! We're offering a variety of perks to express our gratitude, including complimentary concessions and wine, comped tickets with preferred seating, and even a title of nobility from the imagination of our very own Richard II, Frank Weidner. Visit the perks page for all of the details!
  • Even if we are unable to reach our goal, EVERY CENT will do a little bit more to ensure our artists are cared for, and that Chase What Flies can continue to tell classic and poignant tales for the years to come.

The Impact

  • Chase What Flies is a true rarity in Los Angeles: an ensemble almost entirely made up of Professional Stage actors of the Actor's Equity Association, performing in an intimate setting with tickets readily affordable to all audience members. No concepts, gimmicks, or bells and whistles; instead, the performance of resonant works of theatre with a focus on theme and language.
  • Thanks to contributions and attendance from so many of you, our debut production of Cymbeline enjoyed a celebrated and sold-out run, where every member of our team was able to be reimbursed for their work. We wish to continue that tradition, and you--our friends, family, fellow artists, and audience--are an instrumental part of the Chase What Flies team. We need to to make it all happen!

Risks & Challenges

  • Perhaps our biggest challenge with Richard the Second is the play itself. As with Cymbeline, we have taken on another highly complex piece. Written entirely in Verse, this historical classic has been said by scholars "to live in the ear." It's all about rhythm, ritual, and sound: a true challenge for the modern audience and actor if done incorrectly.
  • Fortunately, we've assembled a dynamite cast and crew with the chops, creativity, and passion to make Richard the Second thrive. The R2 team is captained by our director Mark Bramhall, an award-winning actor in all artistic mediums, and an expert in unearthing the hidden gems in Shakespeare's text. His familiarity with the play and ability to simultaneously direct actors and help them grow as artists are a big reason why we're certain this will be a show to remember. 
  • ​We aren't just risking ourselves artistically: to make Richard the Second happen, our team has donated an incredible amount of their time and energy. Our actor-producers have dug into their savings to fund the show and reimburse our artists. All to bring this timely tale of misrule and political corruption to you. We know the reward to perform for you all is more than worth the risk!

Other Ways You Can Help

We fully understand that in some cases, making a monetary donation just isn't feasible. Don't fret! There are still many ways to help out Chase What Flies and the cast/crew of Richard the Second:

  • First and foremost, share our Indiegogo page. We want our story and art to reach as many people in the LA community as possible: your sharing will help make that dream a reality!
  • Follow us on social media! You can support the cause across the internet. Like us on:
  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pg/ChaseWhatFlies 
  • Instagram: @chasewhatflies  & Twitter @chasewhatflies
  • Finally, join us for our performances of Richard II, and purchase tickets at http://chasewhatfliesR2.bpt.me/ . As thanks for visiting our Indiegogo, use discount code Mowbray17 for $12 tix!

Thank you for your support. We hope to see you this November!

Chase What Flies

story:
vision

Mallory Fabian (artistic director & founder of fabe), along with many dancers, and collaborators are currently investigating the idea of stripping away layers that are often misconstrued as identity. We are in constant discussion about the way humans treat each other based on physical and personal attributes such as gender, race, sex, how we comply to behavioral norms, etc. Many people who live outside of "the norm" work endlessly to create an honest-to-self image and present it in a way that establishes something genuine and non-performative. While honoring that, we are working hard to strip away the boundaries that these efforts work to break. We are curious. Regardless of the stereotypes, is it possible to unknow the bias' that we hold and see the human beings in front of us for who they are?

fabe makes work that is fresh and unseen. We develop movement that comes from genuine interaction and is rooted from a deep place of exhaustion. Mallory is more interested in the experience for the dancer and viewer, not the technical perfection of the piece. As a whole, nothing is ever done the same, and the dancers are forced to think at all times about who they are in relation to each other and to the audience. 

This campaign is important to us because we are dedicated to continuing this investigation beyond the premiere in June. Our piece that premieres in November will be centered around these same ideas but from a different vantage point. There are thousands of ways to tell someone who you are and we choose to do that with movement. 

Your support not only funds our collaborators but it helps our investigation. The ability to continue an inclusive dialogue about identity is why we create. We are proud to have a diverse cast with different backgrounds, and the ability to bring these people together. The goal is to create a relatable and raw experience for everyone involved.

 

"The movement [is] very physical, intrusive and confrontational" 

"Fabian exposes the reality of accepting who we are, what we look like, and choices we make."

- Jeff Slayton 

current collaborators  

Choreography + Direction: Mallory Fabian 

Executive Director: Darby Kelley 

Lighting Design: Darius Gangei 

Prop Maker + Set Design: E Kelley 

Composer: City of Orchestras, Body Boys, Simon Greenberg

Videographer: Heather Rebecca 

Performers: Darby Kelley, Cody Brunelle-Potter, Simon Greenberg, Angelica Olivares, Taylor Unwin, Paige Amicon, Carissa Songhorian, Christopher Carvalho

Understudy: Sara Hartless & Tin Nguyen

Stage Manager: Marion Pugliesi  

funding 

Your money goes right back to our

  • directors, dancers, collaborators: lighting/costume/musicians
  • performance venues
  • rehearsal space rental fees
  • production expenses 
  • marketing
  • host community events 

Even if we don't reach our goal the show must go on! Every cent goes a long way and we promise to continue making work that is relevant and worth while. We've received so much support since we started last January and we're not stopping! 

The more money we raise the more we can give back to you! 

what's to come?

We want to give back to our donors the best we can. We will be having a work in progress showing of unknow in June and after the premiere we will be hosting a mixer for all of our donors. 

Our goal after the premiere is to start monthly company classes to get to know our community a bit more. 

But we need your help! 

By making a donation, you help further our reach into Los Angeles. 

In November we will premiere a new work as part of a show It's Not About Pretty which includes choreographers: Mallory Fabian, Brigette Dunn Korpela, & Vannia Ibarguen. INAP will showcase our passion for discussion and impact with a fresh outlook on things people discuss every day. 

Following this premiere the three of us are working on a 2019 tour. Stay tuned! 

did we mention?

A Rube Goldberg machine is involved in our next show? Check out our perks to see how you can get your hands on one!

how to help

Come to our shows and take class from time to time! 

We know times are tough. Even if you can't make a donation, sharing can go a long way! Spreading the word in any way that you can brings new faces into our lives, and we love new faces. 

We are so appreciative for each and every one of you. 

Thank you 

fabe <3 

 

___

 

fabe is fiscally sponsored by Rosanna Gamson/World Wide (RGWW). Your generous donation will be tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law, and your online gift will be recorded as a donation to RGWW. Alternatively, you can make your equally tax deductible donation the old-fashioned way by writing a check payable to Rosanna Gamson/World Wide and earmarked fabe and then putting it in the mail addressed to:

Rosanna Gamson/World Wide 

343 Laveta Terrace

Los Angeles, CA 90026

story:
Announcement!

"Bad Ass Beauty: The Rock Opera" is an official selection of 2018 New York Musical Festival's Next Link Project!  Show dates have been announced at the largest Off Broadway Theater on Theater Row in the largest musical festival in the world!  Opening night is Wednesday, July 11th.

 

What is Bad Ass Beauty: The Rock Opera

A new musical set to real rock music sung by an atypical rock vocalist who can wail.   It's like Hedwig & The Angry Inch starring Aretha Franklin set to the music of Nine Inch Nails.

Aralyn Ford is an ugly duckling who never realized she was a swan thanks to years of abuse at the hands of her father.  She’s been careening through life putting everyone else’s needs before her own to the point where even she doesn’t know which face she’s going to be wearing that day.  Now, she’s on a quest to pull herself together and release her inner Alpha Female.  She, her multiple personalities and her hard rockin’ band of misfits tell it like it is in this rough, raw soliloquy of sound.

Every dollar we raise with this campaign will go towards our upcoming production in New York City and it is coming up quickly!

 

So... it's important because.....

  • This is actual rock n' roll.  The music and lyrics are unapologetic and the vocals are like Janis Joplin... but bigger.  The style of music is not what one expects in musical theater.
  • The theme of female empowerment anchors the show.  Two of the three writers are women and the company is comprised of 10 women and 6 men... Now that's the way we like it!
  • You'll witness rock concert energy with deep, socially relevant contemporary issues... and it's funny as shit!
  • The diversity of all of the elements of this piece is appealing, which makes musical theater accessible to folks who might not normally check it out.   Therefore, the show broadens the audience for musical theater!

Dates

 

Join Our Team

The "Bad Ass Beauty: The Rock Opera" team has achieved the opportunity of a lifetime!  We successfully raised a little over 1/4 of our budget through grassroots efforts as well as a small grant.  So many people submit to the New York Musical Festival every year, some year after year, and are never selected!  This is a really big deal and everyone involved is thrilled!

Now what we need is your generous financial support to make launching this a reality. Our dates are set and money is needed to honor them.  With your pledge, you will be joining us in this exciting experience.  Your contribution will go towards developing the best possible creative aspects of the show such as choreography, lighting, costumes and musical arrangements which are such important aspects of production, as well as taking care of our talented and experienced cast and crew.

This really is your chance to be on the inside of a show’s creation.  To show our appreciation for your generous support, we have come up with some awesome rewards for your contribution that will make you a true industry insider!

 

Spread the Word

Please help us go viral with this campaign by spreading the word about this rock musical via email, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, phone, and good ol' word of mouth. Post this campaign on your social media sites. Email a campaign link to your friends!  That's @BaBMusical on Facebook, @BaBMusical on Twitter and @BaBRockOpera on Instagram.

Damn, musicals cost a small fortune!  NYMF provides lots of help and our costs are about 1/5th the cost of an independent Off Broadway show, and we're not even talking a musical... we just heard of a play in production with just a 5 member cast, no music, and the budget is a quarter of a million dollars!  Yup. 

  • Meeting our goal:  Yes! We will be able to produce our show in New York City but we'll have to cut back on some things.  We're still fabulous, though!  Dates are set, financing is still getting there. 
  • Exceeding our goal:  Yesss! Better sound, fuller design, actual costumes and a cooler theater experience will be had by all
  • Doubling our goal:     Yasssssss!  Balls to the wall all out production to the best of our talented designers' abilities, and they have abilities!

One last thing

This show contains adult themes and is for mature audiences.  It's rock n' roll, baby!

Dates


 
Join Our Team
The "Bad Ass Beauty: The Rock Opera" team has achieved the opportunity of a lifetime!  We successfully raised a little over 1/4 of our budget through grassroots efforts as well as a small grant.  So many people submit to the New York Musical Festival every year, some year after year, and are never selected!  This is a really big deal and everyone involved is thrilled!
Now what we need is your generous financial support to make launching this a reality. Our dates are set and money is needed to honor them.  With your pledge, you will be joining us in this exciting experience.  Your contribution will go towards developing the best possible creative aspects of the show such as choreography, lighting, costumes and musical arrangements which are such important aspects of production, as well as taking care of our talented and experienced cast and crew.
This really is your chance to be on the inside of a show’s creation.  To show our appreciation for your generous support, we have come up with some awesome rewards for your contribution that will make you a true industry insider!
 
Spread the Word
Please help us go viral with this campaign by spreading the word about this rock musical via email, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, phone, and good ol' word of mouth. Post this campaign on your social media sites. Email a campaign link to your friends!  That's @BaBMusical on Facebook, @BaBMusical on Twitter and @BaBRockOpera on Instagram.
Damn, musicals cost a small fortune!  NYMF provides lots of help and our costs are about 1/5th the cost of an independent Off Broadway show, and we're not even talking a musical... we just heard of a play in production with just a 5 member cast, no music, and the budget is a quarter of a million dollars!  Yup. 


Meeting our goal:  Yes! We will be able to produce our show in New York City but we'll have to cut back on some things.  We're still fabulous, though!  Dates are set, financing is still getting there. 

Exceeding our goal:  Yesss! Better sound, fuller design, actual costumes and a cooler theater experience will be had by all

Doubling our goal:     Yasssssss!  Balls to the wall all out production to the best of our talented designers' abilities, and they have abilities!

One last thing
This show contains adult themes and is for mature audiences.  It's rock n' roll, baby!

story:
https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/upcastle-...

Who? 

UnderOwl Theatre was formed by two friends, Chris and Frazer, who met through the University of Plymouth's Amateur Dramatic's society. Frazer had long dreamed of making his "pantomime for grownups", 'Upcastle Downcastle', a reality but was never able to successfully submit the script to the society's showcases, and never got it to a draft he was truly happy with.

This all changed the year he became flatmates with Chris, who sat down with him over many cups of tea, and turned the script into something they think is pretty gosh darn funny. So did several other people, and they were able to recruit a group of enthusiastic student actors, again from the society, and get the 'Upcastle Downcastle' on the road to Edinburgh.
 

"Evil sorceress, Morgan le Fay, has stolen the Holy Grail! With King Arthur gone a bit loopy, it’s up to unassuming royal chef, Rowan, his mother, the amorous Lady Matilda, and a few familiar characters from Arthurian legend to save the day!"

Upcastle Downcastle is the debut production from UnderOwl Theatre. A madcap, slightly raunchy, comedy pantomime for grownups, filled with ridiculous characters, stupid puns, frankly bizarre plot points, more drag parts than we originally intended, and a very, very low budget.

Gorgeous costumes, elaborate set, subtle-humour, well-developed characters; Upcastle Downcastle has none of these things, but it’s still a pretty fun 50 minutes or so.

Not to be taken too seriously.  Probably not suitable for children.


'Upcastle Downcastle' will be performing at theSpace on North Bridge, 13-25th August (19th off), at 9.05pm.

 

Why we need your help.

We have all made our own significant financial contributions to this endeavour. Accommodation, venue-hire, travel, and a number of other costs really pile up, but we have collectively managed to cover around 92% of it. We are falling on your generosity now to ask you to help us find that remaining 8%. We are only about £600 short of having all our costs met, and then we can sleep easy in our beds as August approaches.  

We know you all have many other delights and obligations you'd rather (or are required to) put your money towards but even the smallest donation will be loved and appreciated to the moon and back by us. 

There's been a lot of love and energy put into 'Upcastle Downcastle', and it will mean the world to us, particularly to Frazer, to see it finally realised.

Thank you, just for reading this far,

All our love and gratitude,

Chris and Frazer

Have a glance at our perks to see the small tokens of appreciation we can make for donations. :)

story:
January 10, 2018
Dixon Place
New York City

Going South takes place in North Carolina, today (2017). On a normal Monday morning, four cases appear on the same docket: "Custody," "Cake," "Co-Eds," and "Coco." The cases deal with divorce, discrimination, campus rape, and transgender issues, respectively. Going South addresses the outdated and outrageous laws that still reign supreme in the American South in the 21st Century.

Why tell this story?

Going South addresses many difficult topics at the forefront of current political discussion, so we believe it to be an important piece of current musical theatre. As the show is in its early stages of development, this initial production will benefit immensely from a rehearsal process and audience, which is why we have decided to accept Dixon Place's offer for the workshop performance. Combined with great storytelling and music, this initial in-progress workshop production will attract attention and visibility the show needs to continue growing and developing towards Off-Broadway and touring destinations in the future.

The title song, "Going South."

Why Dixon Place? 

  • Dixon Place is a non-profit cultural institution that has nurtured over 10,000 artists in its 30 year history. DP presents new works & works-in-progress in theater, music, dance, literature, performance art, puppetry, variety, circus arts, burlesque and visual art. Providing an opportunity for artists to develop new work is the core of their mission. Katya Stanislavskaya, THML Theatre Co., Kayla Friend, and John Albert Harris are honored to be given this opportunity to bring Going South as a work-in-progress to such a prestigious theatre for new works in the city.

By contributing to Going South, you will also be assisting THML Theatre Company in its mission to create a platform for emerging female theatre artists. Help us give voice to women's issues in New York City, the South, and beyond.

Since its inception in February 2017 to the present, THML Theatre Company has successfully produced 2 fully staged productions and 2 developmental readings. Kayla Friend and the THML Theatre Co. team is also gearing up for their third fully staged production, Trial by Ashley Griffin, which will be directed by Lori Petty, running at the American Theatre of Actors Beckmann Theater throughout January 2018. 

Going South has previously been developed at the BMI Lehman Engel Musical Workshop and New York Theatre Barn.

What We Need & What You Get

    We need $3900 to make this workshop a reality. Your contributions will go directly to pay for travel stipends for actors ($1694), rehearsal spaces ($1400 for 10 rehearsals), music director stipend ($200), choreographer stipend ($200 total), minimal set pieces ($150), and a inevitable miscellaneous items fund ($256). Any additional funds raised will go towards future productions of Going South.

    "Custody Sequence"
     

    We are excited about the perks we have to offer! Highlights include a weekly Insider Development Newsletter throughout this and future productions, your name listed *forever* as a Founding Supporter, an Original Song written for you, sheet music, and music downloads. 

    This production is funded by your generosity and our drive to present great new musical theatre, which is truly one of the great symbiotic relationships - join us on this journey!

    About the Team

    Katya Stanislavskaya (Book, Music & Lyrics) is a musical director, composer, lyricist and educator. In New York City, she has served as a musical director for Transport Group, Prospect Theater, 54 Below, Laurie Beechman Theater, and New York Musical Theater Festival. Katya's original musical theater pieces and cabaret songs have been performed in New York at venues such as Lincoln Center, Joe's Pub, Merkin Hall, 54 Below, Ars Nova, and York Theater. Katya is a member of the Advanced BMI Lehmann Engel Musical Theater Workshop, where she received the 2014 Harrington Award for creative achievement in musical theater. Other honors include the 2014 Dramatist Guild Fellowship, 2013 New Dramatists Composer-Librettist Studio, 2011 MacDowell Artist Colony residency, and the inaugural Audrey Residency at The New Georges.

    Kayla Friend (Director) is an actress, producer, and director originally from southern California. She came to New York by way of Turkey, where she was the founder of the Incirlik Fine Arts Society on the NATO base in Adana. Kayla received her B.A. in Theatre and Cultural Anthropology from California Baptist University and received training in devised theatre and movement through the Center for Alternative Theatre Training in Athens, Greece. Kayla is an Irene Ryan Nominee and an also an active philanthropist, volunteering with the National Organization for Victim Assistance (NOVA), the Accompany Project, and the United State of Women. Recent directing credits include Cagebirds by David Campton (The Producers Club), The Shadowlands by Ashley Griffin (LaMaMa Experimental Theatre Club), and Where Angels Fear to Tread by Kit Goldstein Grant (The Players Theatre).  Kayla is the founder and Artistic Director of THML Theatre Company. 

    Nevada Lozano (Music Director) is a musical theater composer and lyricist, as well as a professional music director, arranger, and pianist. He has worked with such artistic luminaries as Elvis Costello, Steven Pasquale, Jennifer Nettles, Patrick Wilson, and Nancy Opel, and has served in various capacities at the Public Theater, Theater for the New City, and NY Theatre Barn. Nevada has assisted in the development of several musicals, including A Face in the Crowd (Public Theater, dir. Des McAnuff); Love is Blind (NY Theatre Barn, dir. Joe Barros); and Colorblind (dir. Stanley Wayne Mathis). Music directing credits include: The Fourth Messenger (NYMF 2017), The Gold (NYMF 2016); The Lady of the Castle (Theater for the New City); Little Women, Godspell (A.D. Players); Next to Normal, Company, Avenue Q, Little Shop of Horrors (MJR Theatricals), and three recent Tamarie Cooper musicals at the Catastrophic Theatre in his hometown of Houston, Texas. Nevada is a proud member of the BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop.

    Georgina Bates (Choreographer) Georgina Bates is a NY based actor, dancer, and choreographer/director. Recently: "Unstoppable" (working title, film), The (Last) Station (Planet Connections Festivity, Outstanding Choreography nomination), The Master and Margarita (West End Theater), Somehow We End Up Here, Again (an evening-length multi-media work for HERE’s Sublet Co-Op Series). Georgina choreographed "Cloud Kumo," a film surrounding the aftermath of Hiroshima, which won a Student Academy Award, a CINE Golden Eagle Award, City Vision 2016, and Official Selection: Hiroshima Film Festival, NewFilmmakers NY. Other recent choreography credits: Somehow We End Up Here (CollabFest 2016 -Triskelion Arts), ACLU Freedom Concert (Holy Trinity), Crime and Punishment (West End Theatre), R/Evolution (Robert Moss Theater), Swimming at the Ritz (NJ Rep). Georgina’s work has also been presented at NYU, IDA Art Gallery, Pianos, Slake, and various world peace festivals at Madison Square Garden, City Center, Town Hall, Lincoln Center. M.F.A: Dance, NYU, Tisch School of the Arts, B.A. Theatre Performance, MMC. Member of the SDCF Observership Class 2016 -2017, League of Professional Theatre Women. www.georginabates.com. 

    John Albert Harris (Producer) is a producer, composer, and creator of cinematic graphic novels. John is the Director of Operations for the Argento New Music Project and a Marketing Associate with Victory Theatrical at The Players Theatre. He is a co-producer of the hit Off-Broadway play Puffs at New World Stages. John also works with female-driven non-profits The Nouveau Classical Project, a new music ensemble, and THML theatre company. John is currently producing North Pond, a new chamber musical by Ben Morris, musical theatre by Nevada Lozano, and 7Songwriters, a cross-genre concert series. www.johnalbertharris.com

    An artistic incubator since 1986, Dixon Place (Producer) is a Bessie and Obie Award-winning non-profit institution committed to supporting the creative process by presenting original works of theater, dance, music, puppetry, circus arts, literature & visual art at all stages of development. Presenting over 1000 creators a year, this local haven inspires & encourages diverse artists of all stripes & callings to take risks, generate new ideas & consummate new practices. The artist’s experience is given top priority through our professional atmosphere and remuneration, and their process is enhanced through the reaction of our adventurous audiences. Dixon Place is a local haven for creativity as well as an international model for the open exploration of the process of creation. If you have work that would be appropriate for Dixon Place, please read our open submissions policy. The Dixon Place Lounge is open before and after every show, and you can bring your drink in the theater! Bar proceeds directly support DP’s artists and mission.

      Risks & Challenges

      Theatre is, by nature, a risky business. Creating stories and putting them before an audience is an incredibly vulnerable task—one that requires thick skin, a soft heart, and the will to endure in the face of criticism. 

      THML Theatre Company is dedicated to the growth and development of projects such as Going South, and we are equipped with both positivity and realistic expectations. In our previous work with new playwrights and composers such as Kit Goldstein Grant (Where Angels Fear to Tread, The Nose), we were able to build a solid, dedicated audience that grew with each performance, as well as give meaningful creative feedback to the playwright as the piece continued to develop and grow. 

      THML Theatre Company, partnered with the musical and lyrical genius (we think so!) of Katya Stanislavskaya and the marketing and producing experience of John Albert Harris, is prepared to deliver a performance of Going South that will leave audiences wanting more - and we are dedicated to delivering more! THML Theatre Company has signed on with Katya and John to continue development for this piece through 2019, aiming for an extended Off-Broadway run and a tour through the South.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We understand that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

      • Spread the word! Like us on Facebook here - https://www.facebook.com/THMLTheatreCo/
      • Follow our journey! Follow us on Instagram at @THMLTheatreCo to check out our progress with rehearsals and casting! 
      • Share our fundraising efforts with your friends and family! Even $5 can help us reach our goal! 

      And that's all there is to it - help us bring Going South to the northeast this winter!

story:
Short Summary

"Summer of Stories" is produced by hereandnow theatre company in association with the Rosenthal Theater at Inner City Arts.  Since 1989, hereandnow theatre company has been committed to the idea that "Everybody has a story to tell,"  and this summer we will be presenting a series of eight plays, two of which be fully staged, over a  two-week period.  "Summer of Stories" brings together over 50 artists - actors, writers, and directors to bring these pieces to life.

What We Need & What You Get

To make this festival a success, we need to raise $6,000 for rehearsal and theater rental, marketing, and production costs (equipment, lighting, sound, video, etc.).  With your contribution, we would like to raise more than $6,000 so that we can compensate all of the artists involved with more than just the Equity minimum in the hopes of starting a trend of paying artists an actual living wage for their talents and their time.

The Impact

Since we began this project in 2016, we have involved the community in the process of creating theatre by having showcased 17 pieces, some of which have gone on to be produced elsewhere and developed into films,  and brought over 100 artists together.  With your support, our mission is to continue bringing new, diverse voices to the stage, as well as offering a creative forum for both artists and audience.

story:
Short Summary

GUNPOWDER was selected for the 2018 FailSafe Festival, a five-day festival of live performance, taking place in the Times Square/Hell's Kitchen area of New York City. FailSafe Festival provides a space for artists to push beyond what they consider "safe" to present, giving them an opportunity to show work that may not have a home elsewhere.

GUNPOWDER tells the story of two of the most notorious, influential, and wealthy entrepreneurs and burlesque performers of the young United States, while blurring the past and the present. Klondike Kate entertained miners in the Yukon, generating a fortune with her infamous dances and wit, and invested, lost, and invested again in theatre spaces and cinemas across the nation. Lillian Russell sang and danced her way to the top of American society, becoming one of the first obsessed-over celebrities. She shaped the fledgling Actors Equity Association, advocated for women's suffrage, and contributed to the passage of the restrictive Immigration Act of 1924. Kate is a stubborn, fiercely independent survivor who also gives away her fortune for love. Lillian is a loveable, excitable, brilliant woman, who is also a racist isolationist. The form itself of burlesque lampooned powerful elite and served as an economic avenue for its female starts’ independence while using blackface and redface to make a buck and a laugh. The show will explore these contradictions and paradoxes while engulfing the audience in satire, evocative dance, and live music.

What We Need & Why

This fundraiser will help pay for:

  • Rehearsal Space: where the magic of this play will come to life!
  • Cast & Crew Stipends: artists are never paid enough, but we strive to offer fair pay in exchange for the time, sweat, and heart that all of the creators pour into the process. 
  • Accessible Performances: tickets to the show during the festival are being offered as Pay What You Will. There should be no barriers to the enjoyment of art!

The Impact

Your donations will have a direct impact on the realization of this piece. The team of artists assembled to develop GUNPOWDER is immensely talented, but they cannot will it into existence with their passion alone--your support is vital to making this happen!

Risks & Challenges

We know we are going up against a lot of other causes and concerns in the world. This is likely not the first fundraiser you have seen advertised on social media--maybe not even in the last hour!

But if you are a believer in the power of a small group of people coming together and making something beautiful out of nothing, this is a great opportunity to join one such a small group. We welcome you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't help. If this describes you, please consider:

  • Getting the word out!
  • Share this page with people you know will love this project... 
  • Write your grandma a letter about it because she was totally a suffragette -- but also post it all over the social medias!

BIO: Playwright, director, and producer Natalie Stringer is a theatre maker currently enrolled in the Masters of Arts, Applied Theatre program at City University of New York. Natalie received a B.A. in International Studies and a B.A. in Drama with Honors from Seattle University, produced convenings with Theatre Communications Group, trained with Third Rail Repertory Company, the NHS Institute at Northwestern University, Interlochen Arts, and is an Equity Membership Candidate. She works throughout the city as a teaching artist with Marquis Studios, and as the Program and Development Manager with Global Arts Corps.
story_txt:
Short Summary
GUNPOWDER was selected for the 2018 FailSafe Festival, a five-day festival of live performance, taking place in the Times Square/Hell's Kitchen area of New York City. FailSafe Festival provides a space for artists to push beyond what they consider "safe" to present, giving them an opportunity to show work that may not have a home elsewhere.
GUNPOWDER tells the story of two of the most notorious, influential, and wealthy entrepreneurs and burlesque performers of the young United States, while blurring the past and the present. Klondike Kate entertained miners in the Yukon, generating a fortune with her infamous dances and wit, and invested, lost, and invested again in theatre spaces and cinemas across the nation. Lillian Russell sang and danced her way to the top of American society, becoming one of the first obsessed-over celebrities. She shaped the fledgling Actors Equity Association, advocated for women's suffrage, and contributed to the passage of the restrictive Immigration Act of 1924. Kate is a stubborn, fiercely independent survivor who also gives away her fortune for love. Lillian is a loveable, excitable, brilliant woman, who is also a racist isolationist. The form itself of burlesque lampooned powerful elite and served as an economic avenue for its female starts’ independence while using blackface and redface to make a buck and a laugh. The show will explore these contradictions and paradoxes while engulfing the audience in satire, evocative dance, and live music.

What We Need & Why
This fundraiser will help pay for:

Rehearsal Space: where the magic of this play will come to life!
Cast & Crew Stipends: artists are never paid enough, but we strive to offer fair pay in exchange for the time, sweat, and heart that all of the creators pour into the process. 
Accessible Performances: tickets to the show during the festival are being offered as Pay What You Will. There should be no barriers to the enjoyment of art!


The Impact
Your donations will have a direct impact on the realization of this piece. The team of artists assembled to develop GUNPOWDER is immensely talented, but they cannot will it into existence with their passion alone--your support is vital to making this happen!

Risks & Challenges
We know we are going up against a lot of other causes and concerns in the world. This is likely not the first fundraiser you have seen advertised on social media--maybe not even in the last hour!
But if you are a believer in the power of a small group of people coming together and making something beautiful out of nothing, this is a great opportunity to join one such a small group. We welcome you!

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't help. If this describes you, please consider:

Getting the word out!
Share this page with people you know will love this project... 
Write your grandma a letter about it because she was totally a suffragette -- but also post it all over the social medias!

Natalie received a B.A. in International Studies and a B.A. in Drama with Honors from Seattle University, produced convenings with Theatre Communications Group, trained with Third Rail Repertory Company, the NHS Institute at Northwestern University, Interlochen Arts, and is an Equity Membership Candidate. She works throughout the city as a teaching artist with Marquis Studios, and as the Program and Development Manager with Global Arts Corps.

story:
Sobre el proyecto:

En el Perú la maternidad todavía es vista por la sociedad y por el estado como una obligación de las mujeres, una bendición, una meta a la que deberíamos aspirar. Esta imagen idealizada, que los medios colaboran con proyectar, oculta las verdaderas experiencias que vivimos las mujeres en torno a la maternidad y la no maternidad. Creemos que el primer paso en la búsqueda de nuestros derechos y libertades es compartir nuestras experiencias entre mujeres.

Proyecto MATERNIDADES es una investigación escénica documental sobre los derechos sexuales y reproductivos de las mujeres en el Perú. El resultado del proyecto es una obra de teatro testimonial que pone en escena a seis mujeres, quienes comparten sus historias de vida a partir de sus distintas experiencias con la maternidad y la no maternidad. Esta obra de teatro es un espacio para reconocemos en las otras y en las problemáticas que compartimos.

El proceso de creación de MATERNIDADES tiene tres etapas:

1. Investigación: Realizamos entrevistas a diferentes mujeres en Lima sobre sus experiencias en relación a la maternidad y la no maternidad. También organizamos un espacio de encuentro colectivo: La Feria de la mujer chorrillana, donde conversamos con las mujeres del barrio de Chorrillos sobre sus decisiones de maternidad.

2. Laboratorio: Luego convocamos a seis mujeres entrevistadas en la etapa anterior a formar parte de un laboratorio de tres meses, en el que a la vez profundizamos en sus testimonios y compartimos dinámicas artísticas. Este ha sido un espacio increíble de encuentro y diálogo entre experiencias y posiciones absolutamente diferentes, pero que comparten mucho.

3.  Montaje: Actualmente trabajamos en la organización en escena de los testimonios y documentos recogidos durante el proceso, para crear una obra de teatro testimonial. Este año presentaremos el proyecto en dos funciones de ingreso gratuito. Las funciones serán en el Teatro de la Universidad del Pacífico el 25 y 26 de noviembre.

¿Quiénes somos?

Somos un equipo multidisciplinario de artistas escénicxs, plásticxs y audiovisuales que venimos trabajando desde hace más de un año en la creación y gestión de este proyecto. Leonor Estrada y Maricarmen Gutiérrez, directoras artísticas, son directoras de teatro, performers y activistas feministas. Leonor ha trabajado como directora adjunta de obras de teatro testimonial, como “Desde afuera”, dirigida por Sebastián Rubio y Gabriel de La Cruz y “Tregua”, de Sebastián Rubio. Maricarmen ha dirigido y participado en performances en espacios públicos en el marco de campañas por la despenalización del aborto en casos de violación en el Perú como Déjala Decidir y Todas somos Mariana.

Nuestro equipo

Testimoniantes: Gina Guerrero, Haydee Massoni, Hellen Meier, Lilith Albornoz, Olga Mori, Verónica Ferrari

Productora: Milagros Felipe

Director de arte: Jorge Baldeón

Dirección audiovisual: Gabriela Urco

Jefa de comunicaciones: Karen Bernedo

Asistencia de producción: Jimena Acuña

Asesorxs de gestión: Silvia Tomotaki y Alejandro Larco

Directoras: Leonor Estrada y Maricarmen Gutiérrez

Este proyecto es una iniciativa artística independiente que ha recibido el respaldo de artistas e investigadorxs y de instituciones como el Goethe Institute- Perú, Teatro de la Universidad del Pacífico, Centro Cultural de España en Lima, PROMSEX y El Centro Cultural Cine Olaya. El apoyo de estxs aliadxs nos ha permitido concretar las dos primeras etapas del proceso y garantizar el espacio y la cobertura de las necesidades técnicas para las presentaciones que tendremos en el mes de noviembre.

Tu donación nos permitirá concluir la última etapa del proceso de creación, el montaje. Lo recaudado en esta campaña será invertido en:

  • Cubrir los costos de movilidad y honorarios de las seis participantes
  • Cubrir los costos del diseño y producción de escenografía, vestuario y video del montaje.

Si te entusiasma el proyecto, comparte esta campaña en tus redes. Muchas gracias por ayudarnos a hacer realidad este sueño.

¡Te esperamos el 25 de Noviembre!

Para más información puedes escribir a proyectomaternidades@gmail.com o a milagros.obando@gmail.com

________________________

About the project:

In Peru, maternity is still seen by society and by the state as an obligation of women, a blessing, and a goal we should all aspire to. This idealized image, which the media helps to project, hides the real experiences that women live around maternity and non-maternity. We believe the first step to take in the search of our rights and freedom is to share our experiences among women.

The MATERNITIES Project is a performing documentary research about the sexual and reproductive rights of women in Peru. The project’s result is a testimonial play that puts on stage six women, who share their life stories from their maternity and non-maternity experiences. This play is a space to recognize ourselves among each other and the problems that we share.

The creation process of MATERNITIES has three phases:

Research: We interviewed various women in Lima about their experiences in regards of Maternity and non-Maternity. We also organized a space for a community meeting: La Feria de la Mujer Chorrillana (Women from Chorrillos Fair), where we talked with women from the neighborhood of Chorrillos about their maternity decisions.

Laboratory: We called six women, who had been interviewed in the previous phase, to become part of a three-month laboratory, where we deepen in their testimonies and share artistic dynamics. This has been an incredible space for encounter and dialogue between completely different experiences and positions, that share many things in common.

Production: We are currently working in the organization of the testimonies and documents collected throughout the process, to create a testimonial play. This year we will present the project twice and free of admission. It will take place in the Theatre of the Universidad del Pacifico the 25th and 26th of November.

Who are we?

We are a multidisciplinary team of performing, plastic and media artists, that have been working together for over a year in the creation and management of this project. Leonor Estrada and Maricarmen Gutierrez, artistic directors, are theatre directors, performers and feminist activists. Leonor has worked as assistant director of testimonial plays such as “Desde afuera”, directed by Sebastián Rubio y Gabriel de La Cruz, and “Tregua”, by Sebastián Rubio. Maricarmen has directed and participated in public space performances in the scope of campaigns for the decriminalization of abortion in case of rape in Peru such as “Déjala Decidir” (Let her decide) and “Todas somos Mariana” (We are all Mariana).

Our Team

Testimonies from: Gina Guerrero, Haydee Massoni, Hellen Meier, Lilith Albornoz, Olga Mori, Verónica Ferrari

Producer: Milagros Felipe

Art Director: Jorge Baldeón

Audiovisual Director: Gabriela Urco

Communications Manager: Karen Bernedo

Production Assistant: Jimena Acuña

Management Advisers: Silvia Tomotaki and Alejandro Larco

Directors: Leonor Estrada and Maricarmen Gutierrez

This project is an independent artistic initiative that has the backing of artists, researchers and institutions such as the Goethe Institute-Peru, Theatre of the Universidad del Pacifico, Cultural Centre of Spain in Lima, PROMSEX and the Cultural Centre Cine Olaya. The support of these partners has allowed us to fulfill the first two phases of the process and has guarantee space and coverage of technical needs in the presentations we will have in November.

Your donation will help us with the last phase of the creation process: The play’s production. The money raised in this campaign will go towards:

  • Covering transportation costs and payment of the six participants
  • Covering design and production costs of the scenography, costumes, and video of the whole production.

If you are inspired by the project, share this campaign in your social media. Thank you for helping realize this dream.

We hope you can join us on November 25!

For more information, you can reach us at proyectomaternidades@gmail.com or milagros.obando@gmail.com

story:
Who Are We?

The Theatre at the Cartographic Publishing House is a brand new theatrical project, founded by Charlotte Day and Vyacheslav Komarnitsky. For two years, Charlotte and Vyacheslav have been making theatre in New York, the UK and Australia under the aegis of Bad Neighbour Theatre. We have created work based on classic Russian, English, European and Asian literature, which aims to bend its source material into curious forms.

Now we are returning to St Petersburg, the city where we both learned how to make theatre in the first place, in the hopes of further honing our craft, and developing our audience.

The star of the show, however, is our space: the former Kartograficheskoe zavedenie A.A. Il'ina  (or Cartographic Publishing House) on the river Pryazhka embankment in Kolomna, where we plan to occupy a 98 sq. m. attic room.

Your financial support will help us complete the renovations necessary to turn our attic into a small, but functional, theatre.

What We Need

We aim to raise 6000 USD - a figure which is equivalent to almost a full year's rent.

  • But right now we are faced with some more pressing expenses, including obtaining the necessary technical equipment (at least 1000 USD - and this includes what we can get for free), electrical re-wiring of the space, re-plastering of walls and installing heaters (about 300 USD) before the onset of winter.
  • Our space, which is 98 square metres, will accommodate a minimum of 50 audience members. If we ran three performances per month in the space, at half capacity, charging 500 RUB per ticket (which is on the cheap end), we could earn back our month’s rent. This means that once we are able to build a small repertoire - perhaps inviting other young directors to join us - our theatre will be self-sustaining.
  • However, we will not be able to host any performances until our renovations are finished. This means that the space will not start earning until September at the very earliest. Our goal of 6000 USD, minus technical expenses, will enable us to pay for August (plus security deposit) and September. Looking further into the future, it may also help us pay our electricity bill (in the range of 1500-2000 for the year).

But as you can see, we are not letting ourselves off the hook. 6000 USD falls far short of covering all the expenses associated with running a theatre, and it will be up to us to make sure our theatre survives.

Which brings us to demand...

There is great demand for theatre of all kinds in St Petersburg - more so, we believe, than anywhere else on earth. Matisov Island and its immediate surrounds, where our space is located, is a culturally sparse area. And yet even this small corner of the city is rich in literary and cultural history - the poet Aleksandr Blok, for instance, lived just across the Pryazhka from us.

Furthermore, the building in which our theatre will be housed is soon to become a large, shared creative space - similar to the warehouse studios of Brooklyn and Queens that our New York readers may be familiar with. This will attract foot traffic and interest.

We, in turn, plan to open up our small section of the Publishing House to as many people as possible: inviting other young directors to work with us, hosting free movie screenings, concerts, discussions, you name it. The object is for our space to become a creative home, not only for us, but for the surrounding community, and indeed all who wish to join us.

Risks & Challenges

Making theatre is difficult. Audiences can be sparse, money can be short, technical hiccups (or full-blown catastrophes) can occur, actors can have off-nights, directors can fail miserably to realise their intentions, intentions can be misguided. Art, indeed, can be bad. It can fail to find itself in the right place at the right time. All of these and more are the risks of producing independent theatre.

The good news is that we are passionate young professionals, striving to overcome these hurdles, and actively developing strategies to cope with them along the way. Our two years in New York have given us a sharp edge. And we believe that by making high quality work in an exciting location, with adequate funding, intelligent advertising and sensible budgeting, we have a very good shot at success.
