story:
Who and What is No Peeking Theatre?

No Peeking restructures theatre by providing a 'Blind' Theatrical Experience.  The audience is blinded for the entirety of the show and the play is augmented with sensory and immersive elements that stimulate other senses such as taste, smell, touch, and hearing.  

No Peeking Theatre is comprised of a Board of Directors, a Design Team, A Full Cast, Stage Crew, and of course our current playwright!

This new structure has created accessibility to theatre in multiple ways. From Casting to our designers and production staff our mission is to recreate the "face" of theatre. We give volume to new voices with new stories, for all to access and identify with! 

THIS SUMMER, our goal is to raise $9000 to bring our latest production "The Shit Show", home to the playwright, in Los Angeles California! 

 

Los Angeles is a BIG STEP.

The money we raise is towards the travel, development, marketing, rental space, rehearsals, and everything that goes into making a No Peeking Production!  we have a cast of 9, and a crew of 8!  This is no easy feat and we NEED YOUR HELP! 

What's the Big Deal?

Premiering in Los Angeles will be one of our most ambitious moves in order to expand our company. As we are transitioning into a non profit THIS YEAR, we want to further our reach and share this accessible, diverse, innovative theatre with the world.  Los Angeles will be the first and most important step, but trust me it won't be the last! 

Our Biggest Obstacles! 

Three things we always need, no matter what show? 

SPACE, PROMOTION, AND A RELIABLE TEAM! 

Luckily, we already have a Board of Trustees that help guide No Peeking, a full cast of 9, and a full crew of 8 people!  So that just leaves Space and Promotion.  Both of these in Los Angeles are not easy nor free. Every single dollar counts, so even if it's just $5, you've helped in some way with our production!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are strapped for cash and you still want to help us succeed, SPREAD THE WORD!  If you're in LA, SPREAD THE WORD AND ATTEND THE SHOW!  If you're on the East Coast, SPREAD THE WORD!  If you're nowhere near us, SPREAD THE WORD!  Your family, your friends, your coworkers, your community, charity, church, meetup group, book club, writers group ANYONE you think might be interested in this company...spread the word. 

You can do this by sharing this link, reposting us on social media, sending out promotional links and images to others directly.  If it informs others, do it!  We are nothing without word of mouth! 

This a big project and we couldn't have even launched this campaign without the people who've helped develop it to this point!  Here are just SOME of the people involved! 

(Mariah Ralph, Rhonda Gibson, Justin Green, William Allen, Samille Ganges, Victor Johnson, Myles wright, Melrose Johnson)
story_txt:
Who and What is No Peeking Theatre?
No Peeking restructures theatre by providing a 'Blind' Theatrical Experience.  The audience is blinded for the entirety of the show and the play is augmented with sensory and immersive elements that stimulate other senses such as taste, smell, touch, and hearing.  
No Peeking Theatre is comprised of a Board of Directors, a Design Team, A Full Cast, Stage Crew, and of course our current playwright!
This new structure has created accessibility to theatre in multiple ways. From Casting to our designers and production staff our mission is to recreate the "face" of theatre. We give volume to new voices with new stories, for all to access and identify with! 
THIS SUMMER, our goal is to raise $9000 to bring our latest production "The Shit Show", home to the playwright, in Los Angeles California! 
 

Los Angeles is a BIG STEP.
The money we raise is towards the travel, development, marketing, rental space, rehearsals, and everything that goes into making a No Peeking Production!  we have a cast of 9, and a crew of 8!  This is no easy feat and we NEED YOUR HELP! 

What's the Big Deal?
Premiering in Los Angeles will be one of our most ambitious moves in order to expand our company. As we are transitioning into a non profit THIS YEAR, we want to further our reach and share this accessible, diverse, innovative theatre with the world.  Los Angeles will be the first and most important step, but trust me it won't be the last! 

Our Biggest Obstacles! 
Three things we always need, no matter what show? 
SPACE, PROMOTION, AND A RELIABLE TEAM! 
Luckily, we already have a Board of Trustees that help guide No Peeking, a full cast of 9, and a full crew of 8 people!  So that just leaves Space and Promotion.  Both of these in Los Angeles are not easy nor free. Every single dollar counts, so even if it's just $5, you've helped in some way with our production!

story:
About the Show...

From the classic John Thompson lesson books, daily piano practicing and ticking metronomes, Cynthia enjoyed her cheerful Colorado childhood of music-making. All it took was picking up a random New Yorker magazine in her pediatrician’s office to awaken her artistic soul and fixate her desires on New York City and its ​esteemed​ Manhattan School of Music.

Realizing her musical “holy grail”, however, proves to be a bit more difficult than she innocently expected. As she struggles with her self-sabotaging demons, shaky memorization, insufficient technique and the fear that no one truly wants to listen to her play, she masters resilience.
She endures sweltering practice rooms, music-hating neighbors, condescending teachers AND a falling piano. These and other obstacles confront this naive, wide-eyed young classical pianist who tackles the Big Apple!

In this autobiographical show, Cynthia embodies the youthful determination of her younger self as well as the many idiosyncratic characters who inspired her, each of whom impresses in their own unique kindly, worldly, insightful, brilliant, intimidating and arrogant way. She thrills her audience with musical impersonations of world-famous classical pianists as she remembers hearing them at the legendary Carnegie Hall. ​AND​...she beautifully demonstrates her own musical sensitivity and formidable technique performing live classical piano music, featuring Bach, Beethoven, Brahms, Chopin, Debussy and Schubert. www.VelvetDetermination.com

About the Artist...

Cynthia Shaw​, pianist, singer and actor, lives in Brooklyn, NY. She was born and raised in Pueblo, Colorado and moved to New York to attend the esteemed Manhattan School of Music. Since graduating, she has dedicated her life to music and performance. She has musical directed over 30 regional and off-Broadway shows and particularly specialized in accompanying singers, instrumentalists and choirs. CAREER HIGHLIGHTS include: backup vocals for Paul McCartney (Carnegie Hall) and Björk (Riverside Church). Singing with the New York Philharmonic when they won three Grammy Awards and playing piano for Garrison Keillor and ​The Prairie Home Companion​ at Town Hall and on NPR. Cynthia is also an accomplished actor. Favorite theatre roles: Mrs. Winemiller (​Summer & Smoke​, Terry Schreiber, director), Liz Fuller (​Me and Jezebel,​ Kentucky Repertory Theatre), Arkadina and Ranevskaya (​Mr. Chekov and Mr. Porter,​ Medicine Show Theatre) and many other Off-Broadway theatres in New York. Her film work has been presented at Cannes Festival Corner, The Film Society of Lincoln Center, The Soho International Film Festival and The Big Apple Film Festival, to name a few. Her one woman show, ​Velvet Determination​, won 2018 “Best Festival Debut” at NYC’s United Solo Festival and 2019 “Best Solo Show” at The Pittsburgh Fringe festival. ​www.cynthiashaw.us

Here's Where Your Contribution Will Go...

  • Airfare to Galway for Cynthia and David - $1,600
  • Accommodations and food for 10 days in Galway - $1,400
  • Publicity fliers and posters - $200

What Your Support Means to Me...

Your contribution will help us get to Galway to share this story of hope and determination that has already received some awards for which I am grateful!

  • Winner United Solo Festival "Best Festival Debut".
  • Winner Pittsburgh Fringe Festival "Best Solo Show".

Other Ways You Can Help...

If you can't contribute, I totally get it!  If you want just send me a wave or a wink or a high five!

  • Share this campaign to friends who might be able to contribute.
  • Share ideas for possible other places for me to perform my show!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
What is Embrace?

Embrace is a new musical theatre festival hosted by the MA Musical Theatre course at Goldsmiths, University of London. It is a well-established festival that was first commenced in 2009, to showcase the year’s new musicals and to put on a show-stopping end to the master’s degree.

 

 

Who We Are

 

We are studying Musical Creation at Goldsmiths on two separate pathways: writing and producing. Thirteen talented creators have gathered from all around the world to collaborate on five different musicals. Each of us brings various theatrical backgrounds, which allows us to create new and diverse musical theatre.

We have five productions in progress, and each of us has taken a specific role in the team: producer, writer, composer, director, choreographer and designer. We also collaborate with many other professional creative members outside of the course for the festival.

We are not the actors who shine on stage. We are the ones who shine backstage, unseen by the audience. Even so, all of us are working with pride and responsibility to create what we love. Although our shows will only be onstage for a limited time, we wanted to create musicals that will remain in your heart, forever!

 

 

What We Created

We are excited to present these five new musicals:

-  Mary Shelley

-  Drought Quintet

-  Last Minutes

-  Dawn Of Silence​

-  Naïa

 

Mary Shelly

Book & Lyrics: Paloma Herinckx
Music: Alexandre Diaconu
Director: Mikolaj Chrobot
Producers: Mikolaj Chrobot & Nicole Sciberras

 

Drought Quintet

Director: Jerry Li
Book & Lyrics: Ivy
Music: Lukas McCabe
Producers: Yulu Zhang & Angela Zheng

 

Last Minutes

Book & Lyrics: Deborah Vogt
Music: Orlando Byron
Dramaturg: Minji Kim
Producers: Asako Kajiwara & Sooji Koo

 

Dawn Of Silence

Book: CB Yale
Lyrics: Paloma H. Avila
Music: Lyndon Samuel
Director: Kevin Russell
Producer: Alejandra Rojas (AR Productions)

 

Naïa

Book & Lyrics: Eole Bonnineau
Music: Lukas McCabe
Director: Tiffany Criticos

 

Our Journey

Here is our progress so far, and the exciting schedule for what’s coming up!

October 2018 – Team up

February 28th 2019 – First workshop

July 1st 2019 – Second workshop

July to August 2019 – Audition

August to September 2019 – Rehearsals

September 17th to 21st 2019 – Embrace: New Musical Theatre Festival

    

 

Why We Need Your Support

We have a venue, rehearsal rooms and the skills to make this a reality. However, our finances are limited. We desperately need your support to cover the costs for the components that really give a musical its magic, such as stage sets, costumes, and props.

Also, we would like to pay our actors and the creative staff who are not a part of the course. Behind the spectacle onstage, so many people are involved in helping a musical come to life. What you see onstage is the result of hours and hours of their work and their love for musicals.

Your contributions will help our imaginary world come alive and for us to show our gratitude toward people who are involved in the project.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We will share the contributions equally with 5 productions.

 

In return, you can get:

-  A shout out on our Twitter and Instagram

-  A digital recording of one song from each show

-  Your name mentioned on the programme (both paper and digital)

    *We will send you the digital copy.

-  Subscription to our newsletter

-  A ‘Behind the Scenes’ and ‘Thank You’ video

-  A directing and acting tutorial video

-  An exclusive invitation to the show (2 complimentary tickets), as well as a CD containing all songs from all the shows

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute financially, you can still help by:

-  Sharing this Indiegogo link on social media

-  Keeping updated by visiting our website:

    http://embracefestival.co.uk

-  Following our social media:

    twitter: https://twitter.com/EmbraceFestival

    Instagram: www.instagram.com/embrace_musicalfestival/

story:
Sleeping Giant

"Mable, I think you'll find that people don't need to be made to do horrible things. In fact, I think you'll find that many people are just looking for a reason to do horrible things. And as soon as that reason comes along, off they go to do the things that would shock you."

- The Butterfly King

From the deliciously twisted mind of writer Steve Yockey (TV's Supernatural and Scream) comes a brand new pitch black comedy, Sleeping Giant. When Ryan's firework-filled marriage proposal awakens an ancient creature in a nearby lake, residents of the surrounding town become consumed by stories about "the thing" and the strange effects it is having on those who touch it. 

Starring Tony Award-winner Daisy Eagan, Adam Silver (Showtime's Masters Of Sex), Rick Cosnett (The CW's The Vampire Diaries and The Flash), and Katherine Skelton and from director Michael Matthews (2010's Edinburgh Fringe hit The Bacchae) and producers Nathan Frizzell (last year's hit Tilda Swinton Answers an Ad On Craigslist), Christopher Sepulveda and Mark Giberson, this creepy little play is a little too much like our world right now. 

Our Aim

Producing at The Edinburgh Fringe Festival- especially when traveling from outside the UK- can be an expensive proposition. We are seeking to raise $10,000 to help us cover only part of our total budget- which includes:

  • Production costs
  • Travel for both cast and production staff
  • Lodging for both cast and production staff

 

Your help will ensure that we produce a thrilling, cutting-edge production of this terrific new work by such an exciting author. Sleeping Giant is a play that deserves to be seen by audiences near and far. Please note also that, as we are producing Sleeping Giant in association with the non-profit Celebration Theatre, everything that is contributed to this campaign is tax-deductible and will go directly to production costs and fees. 

A Chance To See Sleeping Giant in Los Angeles!

We will be producing a one night-only benefit performance of Sleeping Giant for a private audience in Los Angeles on Wednesday, July 24th, 2019 in West Hollywood, CA. Please follow us on social media to learn more and get tickets:

  • Instagram: SleepingGiantPlay
  • Twitter: @Giant_Play
  • Facebook: Sleeping Giant Play

Thank you for your support. 

Sincerely,

The Sleeping Giant Team

story:
Theatre Momentum needs your help!

TM has been producing dramatic improv theatre in Chicago for the past 11 years, and we opened up our new studio, Pendulum Space, 4 years ago. We're at a point where we need to reach out to the community at large to lend us a hand to get over our next financial hurdles. Every little bit helps!

We're seeking to raise $10,000 to take care of renovations to our studio, and to help us get ready for our upcoming season, the opening of our Dramatic Improv Training Center, and our Dramatic Improv Festival next October! There's a lot on the horizon, and your dollars make all the difference in making it happen.

Want to make a donation? Well, get yourself a reward for helping us out! Check out the sidebar for more details. Any amount can help, and we love our donors!

Where does the money go? 

With your help, we will...

Renovate our studios.
Our rehearsal/performance studio, Pendulum Space, has been our home for the past 4 years, and it's due for some much needed repairs.  Our studios have the lowest rental rates in Chicago, and we intend to keep it that way for as long as possible. Your donation will go toward keeping our studios in working order.

Produce our 6 new shows:
Coming up on our production schedule for next year are 6 new shows. Your donation will help us get these off the ground and pay for all the overhead to get these performances into production. Shows like...

Scarred for Life (March 22-May 4): a two act play using real people's "scar stories" as the foundation of characters within the play. The real-life stories will act as monologues for our actors.

On Air (May 31-July 13): a serialized drama, set in a radio station in the 1940’s. Real radio drama scripts from the era will be used during the show with full foley and live music. The off-air relationships will fill in the majority of the show, with those stories continuing from week to week.

Mixtape (August 9-September 21): A one-act drama that explores the complex subtext behind the songs chosen for a mixtape, and the history and subtle meaning behind each song.

Voyeur (October 11-November 23)  a unique immersive performance, in which the audience can follow the story from room to room as they choose. Every person will witness a different performance, depending on the choices they make.

Einstein (January 22-March 2): Our 2 resident ensembles are developing their own unique dramatic improv longform performances, to premiere in January. Other shows to follow, schedule TBD

Produce the 15 Hour Project (March 9)
Our take on the traditional 24-hour theater project. Starting with improv actors who may never have worked together, we develop 3 improv shows from scratch, rehearse them, and perform them, all in under 15 hours. Your donation will help us keep this affordable for students and free to audiences.

Open our Dramatic Improv Training Center!
This is a unique training center that no other theater in the country has. Students will get 5 levels of training to teach them the Theatre Momentum style of dramatic improvisation. They'll learn about Improv and Physics, True-to-Life Characters/Relationships, Improv as Writing, and TM's signature show structures. And students will build their own show from scratch! This is a huge undertaking, so your donations will help with promotions and for needs-based scholarships for students.

Host The Dramatic Improv Festival (October 3-6)
This is the first of its kind, an entire festival/conference dedicated to bringing together the best dramatic improvisors in the world to cross-pollinate, perform, learn, and network. It's something we're looking forward to very much. Your donation will help us to secure venues and promotions, and give us the foundation to make a rich and wonderful weekend of learning and artistry.

 

So, as you can see, we have lots that needs your help. Every little bit helps, and we hope you'll make a donation, or at least share this campaign to help us spread the word. Thanks!

story:
Who We Are:


J.U.S.T. Toys Productions produces passionate and provocative theatrical experiences by inviting outstanding professionals from Europe to collaborate with American theatre makers. Our mission is to initiate cross-cultural discussions, foster collaborations and enrich our community with a diverse cultural heritage.

To read about the artistic team and review our past productions visit:
http://www.justtoysproductions.com

"THE DOG THE NIGHT AND THE KNIFE":

In its heart of hearts, Marius von Mayenburg’s play The Dog, The Night, and The Knife is a dystopian love story.

In the nameless Kafkaesque town in the middle of the endless night time is stuck at 5.05 (or is it S.O.S?). The character of "M" is hunted down and trying to survive until morning. A dystopian Reality Trip ridden by blood-thirsty strangers, shape-shifting characters, rampant wolves and humans, and fatal knife wounds. "M" is trying to make sense of the absurd and hallucinatory world. In this town, desire to love translates into desire to possess. In this town, your lover is your prey. In this town, I want you translates into I want to eat you. Quite literally.

That is until M meets Younger Sister. Haunted by the same demons of destruction and bloodthirst as everybody else, Younger Sister discovers a new, unfamiliar feeling towards M –the one that softens your heart and makes you drop the knife prepared to stab your lover, a feeling that is surprisingly and terrifyingly selfless. 

The one that translates I want you into I want you to be happy.

What We Need & What You Get

We are a young company run entirely by the two founding women. Hence the incredible success our company had in the past 3 years we could not be where we are without our community's support. 

YOU are the wind in our sails. Let us keep sailing!

"The Dog The Night and The Knife", this Bi-coastal production with a NY premiere/run and an LA run is by far our biggest endeavor.  

Our company is honored to work with extraordinary artists, which brings us to a growing audience. More than 1000 people are expected to see  "The Dog The Night and The Knife" during 2019. 


WHAT THE FUNDS ARE FOR:

Artists Fees
Theater Rental Space
Costumes & Props
Publicity & Marketing

***Help us reach our goal by March 1st 2019!

story:
Our Story

It is a pleasure to meet you!! My name is Tamara Adira and I’m artistic director of Arte y Pasión, a San Antonio based company known for pushing the boundaries of flamenco and Spanish dance and one of the most contemporary Spanish dance companies in the country.  Every performance is a chance to build on our joyful and experimental approach while allowing us to repeat and perfect our work.  We see our work as an opportunity to generate abundance for the arts community in greater San Antonio, and we’ve been around for over 10 years. 

We have launched this campaign to give you, our public, the opportunity to contribute directly to our upcoming season.  Due to funding cuts to the arts, government closures and funding freezes, we have noticed funding grind to a slow trickle for arts across the country.  At a time we need the most to speak out on human rights crises here in our backyard, it is crucial to us that we keep moving forward, as our expression is our work.  

In this light, we have decided that 2019 would be the year we focus entirely on human rights issues.   Your contribution will empower and enable us to continue.  

What We Need & What You Get

We have 60 days to run this campaign.  Since I told myself “Go Big or Go Home,” we are shooting for the stars and are asking for $18K. If we fall short of this, we will also make it work.  Depending on how much this campaign makes, we will in turn scale the size and impact of our season.  

A small production can be made for approximately $2-4K, and a medium sized one $12K.  We would like to put on 5-6 small productions over the upcoming season.  Your funds will go to these places, including but not limited to: 

  • Renting the theater: the spaces we work in have utility bills, upkeep, and staff to pay.  As much as they would like to give us their space for free, we wish to compensate them for what they provide us with. 
  • Compensating our artists:  Your funds will pay for hours and hours of rehearsal time, equipment, costumes, study time, and artistic honoraria. Many of our artists only do this work for a living. Your contribution will help these artists continue to pursue their work and continue to perfect their art.
  • Travel: Your funds will help defray costs of travel for visiting artists. 
  • Classes and continued study: Your contribution will enable us to continue our studies and continue to improve our work. 
  • Administrative costs: Your funds will defray the costs for our proposal team, who works hours and hours preparing documents for each production, press releases, publicity, and administrative support. 

We have amazing perks which we are offering, which will help us come closer to our goal, while being very fun for you as well! 

The Impact

This project is valuable to me, and it is valuable to the world because we are using the art of flamenco as a vehicle to spread the message of kindness, peace, and compassion.  

The art of flamenco is here and strong in San Antonio for a definitive reason. When the Spaniards looked for hospitable land here in the New World, they settled here.  Flamenco prevails as testimony to a civilization evolving in complexity. San Antonio emerges parallel to Spain in many ways for her climate, culture, and landscape, with the art of flamenco very much a presence in our daily lives.  

A true sign of advancement in a civilization is the arts.  Arte y Pasión, a member of San Antonio Dance Umbrella, has been a major player in the dance and music community of San Antonio and Texas since 2010. We explore evolution and specific subject matter while preserving the foundation of the great art form, inscribed in 2010 by UNESCO on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.  We have participated as an a DreamWeek Partner and with the Artist Foundation. 

Our Track Record

While we've been producing work since 2009, here are the recent projects we've done, on Human Rights issues: 

  • 2019  Estrellas. A project on genetic memory in descendants of holocaust survivors.
  • 2018  Aguitas. A project telling the universal story of Immigrants through the ages. There is a comparison between 1942 Germany and what is now happening at our border. 
  • 2018  Sanctorum. a performance-ceremony for the internment of a musical time capsule,the San Antonio College (SAC) Multicultural Arts Conference, SA300 San Antonio Tricentennial - A project comparing occurrences at the Mexican Border with 1942 Germany, and the devastation of human trafficking, following the deaths of children in a truck found in San Antonio. 
  • 2017 Tribus. We Flamenco Fest - a project focusing on the different tribes of Humanity and how we co-exist and depend on each other to live.  
  • 2017   Nascent|Nation.  The Brick at Blue Star Arts Complex, San Antonio TX - a focus on the American Minority Experience, with separate discrete installations for Jewish, African American, Woman, and Mexican. 
  • 2017, 2019 Estrellas.  The Brick at Blue Star Arts Complex, San Antonio TX - A focus on the genetic memory of American descendents of Holocaust survivors.
  • 2016   A Glass of Wine.  The Brick at Blue Star Arts Complex, San Antonio TX - a focus on the guilty pleasure of a glass of wine amidst the chaos of the American election. 
  • 2016   Colores. The Carver Jo Long Theater, San Antonio TX – produced by and on the season of The Carver Community Cultural Center - a project about the colors of all of us. 
  • 2016, 2017  Una Flor en el Cruce.  The Carver Jo Long Theater, San Antonio TX, San Antonio Luminaria - a project about the strength of a root system that pushes a flower up through the concrete of a road system, producing the flower in the crossing. Dedicated to all those who had to push up against any sort of resistance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute funds, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  Please, get the word out, use the Indiegogo share tools, and make some noise about this campaign!

Yours with love,

Tamara Adira

story:
What does Pastiche mean?

•  A pastiche is an artwork that copies the style of another work or that combines various, distinct styles together into one work. A pastiche can also be a musical medley, or the piecing together of various songs.

•A piece of art, music, literature, etc. that intentionally copies the style of someone else’s work or is intentionally in various styles, or the practice of marking art in either of these ways.

 

Overview

Hi, I’m Britt Quentin, creator and writer of Pastiche.  I’ve been in the entertainment  industry professionally for over 25 years as a performer, vocal arranger, record producer, artistic director, music teacher, and writer.  I recently finished a 10-year stint as Resident Director for a long-running, successful show in London’s prestigious West End.  This culmination of experiences have led me to create Pastiche.

This show is a modern ‘nod’ to Broadway, using the melodies and lyrics of these songs in a new and interesting way.  Whilst all of the songs are indeed from Broadway Musicals, most people won’t realize this  because these songs are fairly familiar to the general public.  The twist is,  these songs are re-arranged, remixed, or mashed-up with  top-40 songs from other decades.  This is  a concert-style, trendy, production show that is equal parts artistic, innovative, and classy, yet edgy, unapologetic, and highly entertaining.

The show is written for 8 singers, and these highly skilled vocalists will tilt the scale towards classy and poetic as they sing in elaborate harmony together, while maintaining dynamic individual solo voices and stage personas.  These singers are combined with commercially-trained, but technically advanced dancers who will tilt the scale towards edgy and commercial entertainment.  A live band, including a horn section, supports this outfit which stylistically covers everything from Pop, Rock, and R&B, to Jazz, Swing, and Salsa.  This creation is truly where artistic excellence meets bold, ‘in-your-face’ entertainment.  This is not a typical Cabaret or Tribute show recreating visual imagery and scenes we’ve seen before from the original stage productions.  It feels more like a concert, less like a legit broadway show.  This is something new and progressive combining theatre, music videos, and commercially televised dance shows, with the sounds of your favorite vocal groups and the aesthetic of top-40 concert tours from today’s biggest artists.

The goal right now is to raise money to film a short (promo-style) video of the show to have something tangible to show producers and production companies.

 

History

I started writing this show back in 2013 while I was Resident Director on another show in London.   During this time, I was commissioned to write a couple of vocal arrangements for a European singing group, and I noticed the chosen songs had a similar theme.  They were all Jazz Standards that originated as ‘show tunes’. The group disbanded before I finished the charts, but I was intrigued by the underlining theme, so…I kept writing.  I’ve always loved vocal ensembles of any style:  The Carpenters,  Earth, Wind, and Fire, The Beach Boys,  any Motown group,  The Manhattan Transfer, The Rascal Flats, Take 6 ( to name a few).  These sounds are always present  in most of what I create.  This idea and the sound created for Pastiche has turned into a combination of all the things that I love:  great entertainment, ensemble singing, extended harmonies, arena shows, dance, music videos, and the magic of theatre.  I couldn’t be more excited about it!  I want people to experience entertainment in a new way with this show…in a way that challenges them, moves them, impresses them, inspires them….and not only in the way that entertains them .

 

The Team

I’ve met many incredibly talented people on my journey, and I’ve recruited  some of these creative treasures to help me construct this short video.  This team of seasoned singers (and professional dancers) were all sought-after, hard-working soldiers of the entertainment industry, pre Covid, and all have beautiful souls passionate about bringing this project to life.

Aubrie Hamrick

From Denver, Colorado, Aubrie has been singing all her life,  everything from opera and Disney to classic rock and Motown. In the last few years she’s had the opportunity to perform with Hans Zimmer at 1STBANK Center, Ramin Djawadi in the Game of Thrones Concert Experience, and with Cirque Dreams Holidaze. She made her Red Rocks debut with Megan Burtt and the Cure for Love in 2016, and in 2018 she had the pleasure of working with the incredible Susan Draus on her new productions, Reunion ‘85 and Reunion ‘69.  Aubrie is honored (and thrilled!) to be apart of the Pastiche journey!

 

Samantha Johnson

Samantha is a singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and actress originally from Southeastern Massachusetts and currently living in Las Vegas.  Formerly of ‘Thriller Live’ West End and world-touring productions, Samantha placed as a semi-finalist on Season 10 of American’s Got Talent and went on to self-release her debut EP 27UNDERGROUND.  She now stars in 'Vegas! The show' and Michael Jackson ONE by Cirque du Soleil, both on the Las Vegas Strip.

 

Jill Marie Burke

Jill is a Los Angeles - based professional singer, and has portrayed Disney characters such as Princess Jasmine, Ariel, & Pocahontas, and is also a Jingle singer for the popular "Priceline Negotiator!" commercials.   For the last 20 years, she’s been The National Anthem vocalist for the Anaheim Angels.   Jill also has her own band playing tribute to Pat Benatar, called “LIVE FROM EARTH”, and debuted Pat Benatar as a headliner in ‘Legends in Concert’ on the world-famous Las Vegas Strip.

 

Taylor O’Donnell

Known for her exploratory use of vocal timbre and texture in her musical stylings, Taylor O’Donnell uses her roots in R&B, folk, jazz, rock, and classical music training to communicate her unique musical dialogue. Highlights of Taylor’s career have been an appearance on the Oprah Winfrey Show working with producer David Foster, performances at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center in NYC, her time working with Grammy award winning producer Rudy Perez in Miami, and has been a featured soloist with symphony orchestras throughout New England.  Taylor is known as the front-woman for retro-soul band, Mother Superior & The Sliding Royales, the electronica duo Novel/Novella, and is the lead soprano in the Boston-based vocal group, Vintage Vocal Quartet.

 

Britt Quentin

This dynamic vocalist, producer, director, musician, and prolific song-writer has traveled the world on the laurels of his music, touring with many different ensembles over the years.  His formal training in voice, piano, and violin, in conjunction with his experience in bands and vocal ensembles, gives him a unique perspective on the execution of music and entertainment.  Britt’s also had the honor of sharing the stage with a host of artists from pop superstars like Stevie Wonder, Sheryl Crow, Babyface, Lionel Richie, Kid Rock, and John Meyer to Jazz legends like Natalie Cole, Herbie Hancock, and Kenny G.  Now living in Las Vegas, he recently finished a 10-year run as Resident Director of ‘Thriller Live’ in London, and is the creator and writer of ‘Pastiche’.

 

Fletcher Sheridan

Fletcher Sheridan has been singing professionally for over 25 years, and has made a name for himself as an outlier of versatility with his background, which spans the classical, jazz and pop worlds.  Fletcher’s credits are a veritable who’s who of the musical world – John Williams, Michel Jackson, Sir Paul McCartney, and Bobby McFerrin to name a few. He has sung on countless movie scores, most recently contributing his vocal talents to the scores of Lion King, Mulan & Call of the Wild. His TV credits include multiple spots for Family Guy, The Simpsons, Glee, and Elena of Avalor.  In the choral/classical world, Fletcher was a member of the prestigious Los Angeles Master Chorale, and sang with the Grammy-Award® winning Los Angeles Chamber Singers. Bringing all of his experiences together, Fletcher has become a sought-after vocal arranger and vocal producer. He has gone on to contract vocal sessions for film, TV, and live entertainment.

 

Jarrett Johnson

Jarrett is a Grammy Award-winning singer/songwriter living in Los Angeles, CA.  He’s traveled the world with various acts including Michael Bublé and Take 6, been featured on projects by Quincy Jones, David Foster, and Childish Gambino, and performed behind numerous artists like Billie Eilish, Alicia Keys, Kristen Chenoweth, Jamie Foxx, and Cynthia Erivo.

 

What we need 

Creatively, most of the show is conceived, all the music is written, and the majority of the project has been digitally staged.  Your support will go towards funding the video needed to show potential producers and investors an idea of what the show will ultimately look like.  Your generosity will go towards getting the team to Las Vegas, rehearsal space, theatre rental, equipment rental, hotels, audio/video needs, and team stipends. And remember, you don't have to  donate an amount listed and receive perks associated with that amount, any amount is is acceptable and you don't have to sign up for perks!

 

Risks and Challenges

Creating anything new has its natural challenges.  But, at this point,  the only challenge for me is raising the funds to logistically get the video filmed!  The team is ready to go.  Luckily, most of us have worked together before on previous shows, or other gigs.  Everyone is very experienced with what we’re trying to achieve and I’m confident we’d be able to overcome any artistic or technical  challenges that could potentially set us back.

 

Ways you can help

While a financial donation, big or small, will help, it’s understandable during this time of uncertainty that not everyone is in a position to give monetarily.  So, you can always help by spreading the word and sharing the campaign page with others!!

 

Thank you for helping me bring "Pastiche" to life!

Known for her exploratory use of vocal timbre and texture in her musical stylings, Taylor O’Donnell uses her roots in R&B, folk, jazz, rock, and classical music training to communicate her unique musical dialogue. Highlights of Taylor’s career have been an appearance on the Oprah Winfrey Show working with producer David Foster, performances at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center in NYC, her time working with Grammy award winning producer Rudy Perez in Miami, and has been a featured soloist with symphony orchestras throughout New England.  Taylor is known as the front-woman for retro-soul band, Mother Superior & The Sliding Royales, the electronica duo Novel/Novella, and is the lead soprano in the Boston-based vocal group, Vintage Vocal Quartet.
 
Britt Quentin
This dynamic vocalist, producer, director, musician, and prolific song-writer has traveled the world on the laurels of his music, touring with many different ensembles over the years.  His formal training in voice, piano, and violin, in conjunction with his experience in bands and vocal ensembles, gives him a unique perspective on the execution of music and entertainment.  Britt’s also had the honor of sharing the stage with a host of artists from pop superstars like Stevie Wonder, Sheryl Crow, Babyface, Lionel Richie, Kid Rock, and John Meyer to Jazz legends like Natalie Cole, Herbie Hancock, and Kenny G.  Now living in Las Vegas, he recently finished a 10-year run as Resident Director of ‘Thriller Live’ in London, and is the creator and writer of ‘Pastiche’.
 
Fletcher Sheridan
Fletcher Sheridan has been singing professionally for over 25 years, and has made a name for himself as an outlier of versatility with his background, which spans the classical, jazz and pop worlds.  Fletcher’s credits are a veritable who’s who of the musical world – John Williams, Michel Jackson, Sir Paul McCartney, and Bobby McFerrin to name a few. He has sung on countless movie scores, most recently contributing his vocal talents to the scores of Lion King, Mulan & Call of the Wild. His TV credits include multiple spots for Family Guy, The Simpsons, Glee, and Elena of Avalor.  In the choral/classical world, Fletcher was a member of the prestigious Los Angeles Master Chorale, and sang with the Grammy-Award® winning Los Angeles Chamber Singers. Bringing all of his experiences together, Fletcher has become a sought-after vocal arranger and vocal producer. He has gone on to contract vocal sessions for film, TV, and live entertainment.
 
Jarrett Johnson
Jarrett is a Grammy Award-winning singer/songwriter living in Los Angeles, CA.  He’s traveled the world with various acts including Michael Bublé and Take 6, been featured on projects by Quincy Jones, David Foster, and Childish Gambino, and performed behind numerous artists like Billie Eilish, Alicia Keys, Kristen Chenoweth, Jamie Foxx, and Cynthia Erivo.
 
What we need 
Creatively, most of the show is conceived, all the music is written, and the majority of the project has been digitally staged.  Your support will go towards funding the video needed to show potential producers and investors an idea of what the show will ultimately look like.  Your generosity will go towards getting the team to Las Vegas, rehearsal space, theatre rental, equipment rental, hotels, audio/video needs, and team stipends. And remember, you don't have to  donate an amount listed and receive perks associated with that amount, any amount is is acceptable and you don't have to sign up for perks!
 
Risks and Challenges
Creating anything new has its natural challenges.  But, at this point,  the only challenge for me is raising the funds to logistically get the video filmed!  The team is ready to go.  Luckily, most of us have worked together before on previous shows, or other gigs.  Everyone is very experienced with what we’re trying to achieve and I’m confident we’d be able to overcome any artistic or technical  challenges that could potentially set us back.
 
Ways you can help
While a financial donation, big or small, will help, it’s understandable during this time of uncertainty that not everyone is in a position to give monetarily.  So, you can always help by spreading the word and sharing the campaign page with others!!
 
Thank you for helping me bring "Pastiche" to life!

story:
What is The Bad'Uns: Clown Acts of Contagion?

Women in dangerously, dangerously bad moods... portrayed by clowns.

The all-women clown troupe Clowns Ex Machina has a new production!

Inspired by legends of “the Bad-uns” – famous women criminals, outlaws and killers – this clown-theatre show examines notoriety, morality, defiance, and the social constraints of womanhood.  Mischievous, startling, and sublimely ridiculous, this world premiere contains interwoven acts of song, dance, verbal wit, and incredible humor.  
All women, all funny, being bad. 


Coming to the Tony-award winning theatre LaMaMa November 7th - 17th, 2019.
 

All The Stuff We Need 

Your money will go to all of these wonderful necessities!

  • Rehearsal space
  • Artists’ fees
  • Backstage Clown wranglers
  • Turning on the lights
  • Catchy Advertising things
  • Red noses
  • Screws, duct tape and twine (and other stuff )
  • Ticket takers
  • Potential overdue fines when returning library books (a.k.a. dramaturgy) 

    ... and somebody’s got to feed the baby! (babies, actually--there are a few)

 

Why Donate to Clowns Ex Machina?

“The human race has one really effective weapon and that is laughter.”  -- Mark Twain

The physical, funny, bewitching, satirical work of Clowns Ex Machina is ripe for these days we live in.  Kendall Cornell and her troupe of all-women clowns use the ancient art of clowning to stir the pot of the collective unconscious and shake our deepest assumptions loose.   With their newest show The Bad’uns, they put our society in a dunk tank and land hit after hit with their unruly and sometimes unexpectedly heart-breaking clown-theatre.

The New York Times said they are “reminders that the greatest clowns try to make people laugh to help stave off existential horrors.”   
Eva Yaa Asantewaa called their work “kaleidoscopically-dizzying physical theater of the absurd with a wicked steel edge that organizes itself just below an insinuating charm.”   

 

Other Ways You Can Help These Clowns

  • Buy tickets to the show
  • Tell your friends  (do you know someone with a warehouse of red noses to donate?) 
  • Follow Clowns Ex Machina on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook 
  • Visit our website ClownsExMachina.com
  • Visit LaMaMa's website
  • Spread the news
  • If you'd like to give a different way... go to our website's Donate page. 

 

 

amazing photos by Vanessa Lenz

story:
Hey! What's this all about? Well, let us tell you.

Hi, my name is Sarah. I was born and raised in Chicago and I’ve never known life without dance, but I turned my life upside down when I moved to Nashville two years ago to follow my dream. Now, I am creating a space that allows other artists to realize their dreams. I need your help.

Dance is about movement, but too often, we find ourselves trapped within opposing structures, like ability vs. disability, professional vs. amateur, written vs. improvisation, mature vs. youth, ground vs. air. At least, that’s how I felt – so I created Satellite Dance. 

Satellite Dance is a performing arts company that focuses on the exploration of contemporary dance from the ground and air. (In other words, we’re really into aerial dance!) We’re also so much more. We’re founded and powered by women, plus one woke man. We’re proud to promote inclusivity in a completely, unapologetically bold way, which only silks hanging from a ceiling can provide. We also believe in the healing power of movement. If you take a look inside our studio, you’ll see how movement has already brought our growing community together.

Speaking of, it’s only been two years, but our artists made it clear: they want more opportunities to engage in the performing arts community and to share their love of aerial dance with the community at large. I couldn’t be more excited to make that happen, but without your help, we’re stuck.

With your contribution, we can bring the power of movement to so many more artists in the greater Nashville area, who are just waiting to be self-discovered. 

What We Need & What You Get

We’re fundraising for $34,500. 

The money that we raise will be used to fund: 

  1. Four (4) additional performance opportunities per year for our Youth, Community and Professional programs
  2. Rehearsal stipends for choreographers and professional guest artists (because we take care of our own, Hunnie!)
  3. Performance expenses, including costumes, lighting and sound rentals, space rentals, and music licensing

We have so many artists in our community and we have awesome perks when you donate, including serious swag from pins to t-shirts, a surprise special gift from one of our artists, season tickets to Satellite performances, a dance in your honor (in fact, come dance with us!), advertising space on our website, and more!

We know we can. However, if we don’t reach our entire fundraising goal, our funds will be happily used to support: 

  1. Additional performances, scaled-down in size and both rehearsal and space rental time
  2. Performance outreach to populations in need, including local hospitals and community centers

The Impact

Here’s our reality today:

All performances are currently being held at So Fly Studio with donated space and materials, from aerial rigging to lighting to music to insurance, which means that Satellite time is forfeited when studio space is reserved for paid services. 

All of our participants, from the aerialists to the stage manager, are volunteers. These dedicated folks don’t receive any financial compensation for their time and commitment.

We’re losing out on opportunities to learn from, and work with, guest artists. With no financial compensation, we’re perpetuating the “work for exposure” issue.

The impact of these funds will instead ensure that:

  1. Satellite Dance can stand alone and have the budget to sublease, securing its own space for both rehearsal and performances for even more artists. 
  2. Satellite Dance can provide volunteer participants with some actual, tangible benefits (not just the warm-fuzzy feels!) that will impact their daily lives.
  3. Satellite Dance can offer contracts to guest artists, helping to address and then solve the “work for exposure” issue, at least within our community. 

Risks & Challenges

I run a small business. I get reality checks daily, so I personally have at least two burning questions that are always top of mind:

What if we don’t raise enough money?

What if no one comes to the performances?

However; because I already run a small business, I’ve got us covered thanks to prior experience in producing these performances as well as a strong network of support: 

We successfully produced (5) evening-length performances since April 2018. They were no high-school production value performances either. We were grateful and proud to partner with professional lighting experts and photographers, including a stage manager for run of show. We invited two guest artists from the Nashville community to pull in attendees outside our passionate community, and provided two shows: one for youth, one for adults. We also offered advanced ticket sales, to encourage a faster sell-out timeframe and guaranteed full house. Additionally, my experience in running similar performances provides me with an understanding of actualized costs to more accurately forecast future fees and expenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't financially contribute, we would greatly appreciate you spreading the word about Satellite Dance and our goal.

  1. Please share this campaign with your friends and coworkers.
  2. Donate materials to our performance space: e.g. chairs, lights, costumes, set pieces!
 

Thank you so much for reading through some or all of this. We couldn’t do it without you!

Sarah Atenhan

President & Artistic Director

story:
Mark Bentley Cohen and Lianna Walden at Grand Central Station in New Yrok

Hello! Thank-you for visiting and thank-you for supporting TWO risk-taking artists today.

This is an original play about us, our personal journey.  Confusion, marriage, almost divorce, revealing bisexuality, risking an open-relationship, jealousy, fear and the discovery of love - this one-man show tells it all!

We have been through an incredible exploration together. We have been married now for 20 years now, have two teenage kids, and are more in love than we have ever been. Knowing that there was little information out there, this was a journey we needed to talk about.

This may be the only piece of true theatre I've seen in 15 years in Vancouver. Remarkable, thought-provoking, psyche stretching.... Go see it!"   - Jeffery Lando (Film Writer/Director)

We have shown the play in Vancouver,  Seattle, Berkeley and Minneapolis. Now we are heading to New York and this is a BIG ONE. We need your help.

Great job. The performance was so raw and real. We loved it!
-Kamala Devi (Speaker, Coach, star of HBO “Polyamory: Married & Dating)

BUDGET
We'd like to continue doing this work. We need your support right now to do so.

Presenting the show in New York is a big deal, and the timing could not be more perfect. The budget is $8,500 US. The recent depreciation of the Canadian dollar to the US means these costs have increased by over 20% for us, putting the budget at $10,200 CDN. 

We'll be using the money to pay for the hard costs of producing the show, food, lodging, and transport. The numbers break down as follows:

Transportation

$1,700

Production Costs

$2,900

Hotel

$2,200

Food

$1,700

Total:

$8,500

 
"Mark Bentley Cohen's one-man show is a tell-all, oft-erotic description of a married fellow’s attempt to incorporate man-on-man sex into his 12-year heterosexual marriage. Irreverent and refreshingly candid." - Michael Harris from the Globe and Mail- theatrical pick of the week (Canada`s National Newspaper) 

SPECIAL PERKS
We offer COACHING sessions. After going through the journey ourselves, we began offering workshops and discussion groups for people who wanted to discuss alternative relationships. From this, we moved into coaching and counseling individuals. We are both passionate about helping other people find authenticity in their sexual and intimate relationships. 
Ask us anything! Your journey is as personal and unique as you are.
Mark's Counsilling / Lianna's Coaching

OTHER WAYS TO HELP
Your contribution is vital, as every bit helps.

If you are unable to make a financial contribution, you can help in other ways:

  • spread the word through your own media channels by sharing the campaign details.
  • come to the show and bring a group of people
  • have us come out to your area to perform
  • tell friends, colleagues, acquaintances about the project
  • set-up speaking engagements with Mark and/or Lianna with your organization, school, group while we are in New York, back home in Vancouver, or anywhere else
  • hold a book reading, or have us come and perform the show at your event or for your organization
  • write us a nice, supportive letter or review if you have seen the show
  • hold your own discussion about alternatives relationships and tell us about it!

We thank everyone for all the amazing support we've received to date, and continue to receive.


OUR STORY by Mark Bentley Cohen

After a lifetime of struggling with my sexuality I finally came to terms with the fact that I am and always have been bisexual. For better or worse I found myself 15 years into an ailing marriage with two teen-aged kids when I came to this realization.

In the fall of 2009 I reluctantly drove my wife up to the top of Cypress mountain to tell her what I'd come to learn about myself. I pulled over and parked on the shoulder of the deserted road. Unable to speak, I stared out my side window to gather my courage and savour the final moments of our previous life together, knowing that things were about to change between us, irrevocably. 

That night Lianna and I decided to throw our old marriage over the cliff of Cypress mountain, freeing each other to explore emotional and sexual landscapes beyond our fenced-in monogamous garden.

No longer held down by the ballast of monogamy, Lianna and I leapt off the cliff together and immediately began to soar. What we discovered in the great land beyond was so surprising, so amazing, so counter-intuitive and contrary to all we've been led to believe about life without monogamous borders that we knew we had to talk about it with others.

Opening our relationship had saved our marriage, not ruined it. We began to flourish both individually and as a couple, discovering new levels of love, intimacy and connection deeper than any we had ever imagined possible.

"Bi, Hung, Fit... and Married" is the theatrical version of our story, and represents one of the many leaps we've been taking ever since our drive up to Cypress mountain. "Bi, Hung, Fit... and Married" is much more than an one-person show, however; it encompasses an entire project, the scope of which reaches far beyond the theatre.

In 2010 I began writing "Confessions of a Bisexual Husband", the book version of our story, upon which the play is based. As a formerly-closeted married bisexual man I had an insider's view into that secretive world. I knew there were so many others out there suffering from the same feelings of shame, fear, emotional stress, guilt, anxiety, and depression I had.

I also knew that I could help them, that our story could provide much-needed hope by offering a workable relationship alternative.

There is only one officially sanctioned relationship narrative in our culture: boy + girl + love = 4-ever. Every TV show, novel, movie, popular song, advertisement, news article tells us that lifelong heterosexual monogamy is the pinnacle of human interaction, the very thread with which our social fabric is sewn, and any other form of relationship is pejorative at best, and punishable by death at worst.

Consciously or not, we all want to participate in this narrative. We unknowingly use it to measure the value of our place in society, our emotional and psychological fitness, maturity, sexual propriety, and our very self-worth. Let's face it, if you're 40 and single, YOU'VE GOT ISSUES!

The sad irony is that lifelong, heterosexual monogamous unions work for only a very small percentage of the population. And if you add the qualifier of "happy", that number drops significantly. The results of this misconception are devastating. For the first time ever there are more single adults in the US than married. This means the majority of us are wondering what is wrong that they we cannot conform to his narrative?

The message of our project is clear:
There is nothing wrong with you. It is the narrative which is in need of change.

In 2010 I started a support group called "Bisexuals in Vancouver" on Meetup. Soon after I became a volunteer facilitator at our local queer resource center, combining their bisexual support group with mine. I'm now in my fifth year of running free meetings twice a month for bisexuals to share stories and experiences. I continue to be motivated and inspired by the countless lives which have been transformed by this group.

I also began writing a popular blog on these subjects, counselling bisexuals, and offering myself as a resource to helping professionals who do not understand – or even acknowledge the existence of – bisexuality and consensual non-monogamy.

Lianna and I began giving workshops on non-monogamy together, running discussion groups for couples, giving lectures, presenting to organizations, attending conferences, participating in documentaries, putting on the show, being interviewed by the media – all of which has been self-funded.

When "Bi, Hung, Fit... and Married" premiered in 2012, I'd been writing alone in a basement for two years. I had no idea what the reaction would be to the material. It was to be the first time complete strangers would encounter our story. Would they go running from the theater aghast? Hurl insults? Invite us back to their place for a drink?

We were certainly not prepared for the teary-eyed outpouring of love and appreciation we received from the audience. "This is the first time I've ever heard my story being told," they said. "Thank you for giving me a voice. For making me feel whole again."


With much appreciation for all those who have become a part of this project, we thank you for understanding, and for doing what you can.

Mark + Lianna

one of the many leaps we've been taking ever since our drive up to Cypress
mountain. "Bi, Hung, Fit... and Married" is much more than an
one-person show, however; it encompasses an entire project, the scope of which
reaches far beyond the theatre. 
In 2010 I began
writing "Confessions of a Bisexual Husband", the book version of our
story, upon which the play is based. As a formerly-closeted married bisexual
man I had an insider's view into that secretive world. I knew there were so
many others out there suffering from the same feelings of shame, fear,
emotional stress, guilt, anxiety, and depression I had. 
I also knew that
I could help them, that our story could provide much-needed hope by offering a
workable relationship alternative. 
There is only one
officially sanctioned relationship narrative in our culture: boy + girl + love
= 4-ever. Every TV show, novel, movie, popular song, advertisement, news
article tells us that lifelong heterosexual monogamy is the pinnacle of human
interaction, the very thread with which our social fabric is sewn, and any
other form of relationship is pejorative at best, and punishable by death at
worst. 
Consciously or
not, we all want to participate in this narrative. We unknowingly use it to
measure the value of our place in society, our emotional and psychological
fitness, maturity, sexual propriety, and our very self-worth. Let's face it, if
you're 40 and single, YOU'VE GOT ISSUES!
The sad irony is
that lifelong, heterosexual monogamous unions work for only a very small
percentage of the population. And if you add the qualifier of
"happy", that number drops significantly. The results of this
misconception are devastating. For the first time ever there are more single
adults in the US than married. This means the majority of us are wondering what
is wrong that they we cannot conform to his narrative?
The message of
our project is clear:There is nothing wrong with you. It is the
narrative which is in need of change.
In 2010 I started
a support group called "Bisexuals in Vancouver" on Meetup. Soon after
I became a volunteer facilitator at our local queer resource center, combining their
bisexual support group with mine. I'm now in my fifth year of running free
meetings twice a month for bisexuals to share stories and experiences. I continue
to be motivated and inspired by the countless lives which have been transformed
by this group. 
I also began writing
a popular blog on these subjects, counselling bisexuals, and offering myself as
a resource to helping professionals who do not understand – or even acknowledge
the existence of – bisexuality and consensual non-monogamy. 
Lianna and I
began giving workshops on non-monogamy together, running discussion groups for
couples, giving lectures, presenting to organizations, attending conferences,
participating in documentaries, putting on the show, being interviewed by the
media – all of which has been self-funded.
When "Bi,
Hung, Fit... and Married" premiered in 2012, I'd been writing alone in a
basement for two years. I had no idea what the reaction would be to the
material. It was to be the first time complete strangers would encounter our
story. Would they go running from the theater aghast? Hurl insults? Invite us
back to their place for a drink? 
We were certainly
not prepared for the teary-eyed outpouring of love and appreciation we received
from the audience. "This is the first time I've ever heard my story being
told," they said. "Thank you for giving me a voice. For making me
feel whole again." With much appreciation for all those who have become a part of this project, we
thank you for understanding, and for doing what you can. 
Mark + Lianna

story:
April 16th- 25th, 2015: Touch Me Philly Productions Presents two weeks of theatre and events exploring the topics of  Street Harassment & Rape Culture. 'Reasonable Fear' is a project unafraid to discuss these topics head on and ask "What's next?" You can help make this show an amazing & enriching experience by donating today!

**Eight short plays were chosen from our open submission call to create our Main Stage Theatrical Production. This show will be presented six times: April 16-18 & 23-25 at 8:00 PM.

**We'll also be offering a variety of other presentations, shorts, workshops, and films during these two weeks.  Check back here regularly as we will be adding TONS of resources and event details! This series coincides with both Sexual Harassment Awareness Month and Street Harassment Awareness week.

But.. what IS Reasonable Fear?

  “a reasonable person” or “reasonable fear”-  This is a key legal principle that makes regulating verbal street harassment challenging. These phrases provide guidance for judges and jurors in interpreting the law. Because our laws are meant to be generally applicable to society, they are often written according to how a "reasonable person" is expected to react to a given situation.

  For example, if a law prohibits actions that would make a "reasonable" person fear for his or her safety, the fact that I was scared by your action is not enough to establish that you broke the law. Your action would have to be something that would cause fear for the average, "reasonable" person – not just the person that was actually made afraid.

  Because the majority of lawmakers and judges in the United States have historically been older white men, and older white men don’t typically experience street harassment, or if they do, they are rarely afraid as a result, the fear associated with street harassment has not always passed the "reasonable man" test.[http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/strategies/...]

                                                                          ****

 So, we’re supposed to feel protected by laws made to assume we’re reasonably afraid of only the same things that they do?  As reasonable women, we say the standard needs to change! 

Touch Me Philly Productions is looking for caring community members, local  businesses, and you to get involved with 'Reasonable Fear.' Unfortunately Street Harassment and Rape Culture not only exist but are far too prevalent in today’s society.

By getting involved as a donor, you help to ensure that this conversation happens in a meaningful and productive way.  Our goal is to continue this important discussion and help make our daughters, sisters, mothers, friends & selves feel SAFER in the streets of The City of Brotherly Love.

DID YOU KNOW? Most theatre companies in Philadelphia operate on budgets that are only 30% or LESS based on ticket sales! That's right- over 70% of the money required to produce fantastic arts events has to come from other places than admissions.  We need donors like you to create these meaningful, fun, and exciting pieces and share them with all of you


HOW WILL YOUR MONEY BE SPENT

There are many expenses to every show! A show dealing with important issues like street harassment & rape culture is no exception! As we raise money here and through our other efforts it goes towards various nexessary costs. Our modest initial goal of $2000 for this campaign is far from what it takes to produce a series of this magnitude. We can use so much more than a mere $2000 to make this show better and better, and with your help, perhaps we will! 

Here is a break down of some of the major initial costs of producing a series like this:

-Venue Rental

-Insurance

-Curation of pieces/Writer's Stipends

-Actor's Stipends

-Stage Manager's Stipend

-Set Design & Construction

-Lighting Design & Operation

-Sound Design & Operation

-Advertising/Promotion/Printing

-Costuming

And that is just the bare bones of a project like this! Reasonable Fear will provide multiple events and types of entertainment and education, so the costs only branch out from this list. As we recieve donations we will let you all know exactly what we're spending the money on AS WE GO! We'll update regularly with videos and pictures so you'll get to see your dollars working hard to bring this important event to life!

Thank you from all of us working to make “Reasonable Fear” a series that makes a difference.  If you have any questions, please shoot us an email!  Info@TouchMePhilly.com.  We appreciate you taking the time to read this and consider donating your venue and/or funds toward this important project!

Join us in making this event an instrument of that change! Thank you.

-Alyson Rodriguez Orenstein & Amanda Sylvester

Co-Owners, Touch Me Philly Productions, LLC

story:
Short Summary

Adolescent Anarchy (AA) is a start-up theatrical program in Des Moines, Iowa. AA was founded in 2012 by nine students from the Des Moines area who have come together sharing a common passion for the theatre. Our project's mission is to build a foundation of involvement for teens in the theatre by innovating the way theatre is viewed and produced. This year Adolescent Anarchy presents Big Fish: The Musical, which will be performed in the Viking Theater at Grandview University. You may be thinking, "This seems like a challenging project for young adults to handle!" However, our goal with Adolescent Anarchy is to prove teens are capable of handling much more than given credit for. We want to prove kids and young adults can rise to the occasion, and create a production not only on par with past productions across the country; but one that will exceed all expectations of what "children" are capable of.

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise the $6,000 dollars necessary to fully stage this production. The set, the costumes, the sound, and the makeup- everything a fully staged musical needs. DM Young Artists' Theatre fully supports this project and has provided us with space to rehearse as well as a home for Adolescent Anarchy's headquarters. Each member of the production team also works with the help of a mentor. These are professionals in each of the positions we, as teenagers, are taking on, who can advise us on our respective jobs, giving us help where we need it.

The Impact

As everyone knows, putting on a real production takes real money. This money will fully costume all cast members, buy all the supplies necessary to build the set, and allow us to purchase and/or build the props we will need.

Adolescent Anarchy used Kickstarter in 2013 to fund our first production, Lord of the Flies. Our budget for this production was $4000 and we were lucky enough to reach that goal and end with $4500, allowing us to expand our original concepts into something greater.

Hopefully you find this as exciting as Adolescent Anarchy does! We hope that you'll consider donating to our cause; so we can not only produce this show, but leave a legacy  for future teens hoping to pursue their dreams of theatre. If you have any further questions about how the funds will be used, feel free to email us at adolescentanarchy1@gmail.com. 

Risks & Challenges

There are obvious risks with a venture such as this. For example . . .

"What if you get the money, but nobody is interested in auditioning?"
Adolescent Anarchy has stirred much interest in the Des Moines theater community. In past year we have had no trouble finding a talented and well rounded cast. This year we are reaching out to more high school drama programs and trying to get more youth involved in the project.

"Do you really think this is an attainable production for such a young age group?"
Adolescent Anarchy has put on multiple successful productions in the few years of our existence. Every year we have succeeded in putting on a fully reimagined and well attended production. Though this is the biggest challenge we have given ourselves, the skills and lessons we have learned in these past years have fully prepared us for a production of this scale.

No only are we learning independence from this experience, we are also continuously gaining experience from professional mentors in our respective theatrical fields. We also discuss all actions and plans with David A. VanCleave, Artistic Director of DM Young Artists' Theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

There is a lot more than money that goes into a production:

One very important volunteer position is that of an actor. Our auditions are on February 8th, 2015 at 6 pm. Actors will need to bring 16-32 measures of a prepared song with either a CD or piano accompaniment. Though Adolescent Anarchy is a teen led initiative, we plan on casting people of all ages, as we have done in the past. We will be casting around 10-12 women (ages 18+), 10-12 men (ages 18+), and 2-5 boys (ages 8-17), and 2-5 girls (Ages 8-17).

Backstage is just as important as being onstage. We will need a crew to do shift work as well as someone to run lights and sound.We also will need help with set builds and assistance with costuming. If this interests you, please email us at adolescentanarchy1@gmail.com.

If none of these options interest you, we would love for you to attend Big Fish, showing May 1-3 and May 8-10 as well as getting the word out about our project!

story:
Hello and thank you for your interest in Sleeping Beauty The Musical.

My name is Ian Curran and I started writing this new musical version of the traditional fairytale in the hope that I could inspire an audience whilst admittedly trying to make a quick buck. 

Still I wanted to create a show that was an engaging family show. Not a show that parents begrudgingly took their children to watch but one that everyone could enjoy. I wanted to create something with artistic integrity that would not condescend to its audience or belittle its subject matter but still provide a fun night at the theatre.

I asked a Musical Director friend Simon Hanson if he'd be interested in collaborating and thankfully he and his writing partner Peter Vint were looking for a new project and said "yes." I sent them lyrics; they replied with melodies and it soon transpired that this show could be something very special. 

We have workshopped the hour version of the show in London and are currently finishing off the remaining few songs that will see the show become a full scale musical. 

This campaign is to raise money to get the show from its current pre-production stage into production. Any donation you make will go directly into the show. At this stage we are looking to pay an animator to create animated backdrops that will not only move the plot along but will also be engaging to this new generation of iPad audiences.

We need studio space, recording facilities, theatre hire and all that goes into creating a high quality professional theatrical experience.

ANY money that you can give, however small the donation, will be gratefully received and used to get my dream on stage.

Please share this page and spread the word wherever you can.

Thank you.

Ian Curran.

story:
GREAT NEWS!!  

With your help we have already raised enough to cover the registration fee for appearing in The Fringe.  Please do consider helping us to raise the rest of the funds we need to cover the cost of our venue for the performances in August.  

The project


We are Tibetan Buddhist monks from one of Tibet's most important monasteries - Tashi Lhunpo.  After the Chinese occupation of Tibet, a few of our senior monks followed His Holiness the Dalai Lama into exile and re-established our Monastery in Southern India. Tashi Lhunpo monastery in Bylakuppe is now home to just over 300 monks, and has once again regained its reputation as an important centre for learning and for the preservation of the culture and traditions of Tibetan Buddhism.


This summer we are coming to Europe to share our culture with people from other parts of the world.  With the help of our UK Trust we will be bringing performances of the masked dances from the Gutor Festival at Tibetan New Year, the unique music and chant from Tashi Lhunpo, and our traditional monastic arts of sand-mandala making.  As part of our visit, we are visiting the Edinburgh Fringe for a week from 17th-22nd August at a new venue for us, Greensides Royal Terrace.

We need to raise money to pay the costs of hiring the theatre for the performances and workshops, and to support us during our week in the Edinburgh Fringe.

This is a wonderful opportunity for us to meet new friends and supporters and to share our art, music and dance with people of all ages and backgrounds.  Without letting people know what we do, we may soon lose our extraordinary culture, which is so difficult to preserve in exile.  In addition to the performances themselves, we are planning to run workshops every morning, in which people can learn more about Tibetan monastic arts, meet and talk to us, and to understand even more about our endangered way of life. 

But in Edinburgh, we are competing against about 10,000 alternative shows and performances who are all looking for audiences, so we need to make sure that people know we are here, and persuade them to come and see us.

What We Need                      

We need to raise £2,700 to pay the hire fees of the Greenside Royal Terrace venue. We also need to pay the registration fees for our performances and workshops to the Edinburgh Fringe of £300, and any extra funding that we raise will be spent on the advertising and promotion of our performances.  

We have been offered free accommodation in Edinburgh, but we still need to buy our food, and cover the costs of our travel and transport.  

The Impact

Monks from our monastery have been visiting the UK and Europe since our charitable trust was established in 2003.  We have built up a great community of friends and supporters, who have made it possible for us to continue our study in India.  


Over the previous years, we have managed to take enough money back to the monastery to build a new Debate Hall, which means that our priceless study can continue whatever the weather, in the hottest part of the summer or in the monsoon season.  

Now our aim is to continue to support the monastery through funds raised during our tour, to build new hostels for the young monks, who due to over-crowding often have to sleep more than ten to a room, which makes it difficult for them to study hard at a very important stage of their lives.  Our contribution also supports elderly monks, whose only home is now the monastery, and for whom we care as if they were our family until the day they die. The tour income helps supply money for the food fund, the school, the clinic, which not only cares for the monks, but also the local population.  


Risks & Challenges

We must register our show in the Edinburgh Fringe by 8th April, otherwise we will not be included in the Festival Programme.  The average audience attendance figure at the Edinburgh Fringe is 2!  Our venue's average attendance for shows is 25 - and this is the first time that the Greenside Royal Terrace venue has had workshops and performances like ours in the space.  We need to make a proper impact through advertising and promotion to make our performances stand out, and if we don't, then we will end up making a loss on the week.  

Encouragingly when we have performed at the Edinburgh Fringe in the past in other venues, we have averaged around 85% audience capacity for our performances, which is an impressive record.  We have experience of contacting the press, and are prepared to go out onto the Royal Mile with our flyers to make sure that people know where we are and what we are doing.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can help us with a donation - however small - towards our goal, that would be wonderful.  If it is not possible, then please 

  • Spread the Word! If you can't donate, please let others know we are here! 
  • Share this page on your Facebook page and Tweet the news that we are coming to Edinburgh in August 2015
  • Send us a tweet on Twitter @tashimonks 
  • Like us on www.facebook.com/tashi.lhunpo.monks and share our updates with your family and friends
  • Consider becoming a long-term sponsor of one of Tashi Lhunpo Monastery's monks - for details see http://www.tashi-lhunpo.org.uk/
  • Keep in touch with us through our website at www.tashi-lhunpo.org.uk
  • Come to one of our performances during the 2015 tour - details on our website at www.tashi-lhunpo.org.uk
