We need to raise £2,700 to pay the hire fees of the Greenside Royal Terrace venue. We also need to pay the registration fees for our performances and workshops to the Edinburgh Fringe of £300, and any extra funding that we raise will be spent on the advertising and promotion of our performances.  

We have been offered free accommodation in Edinburgh, but we still need to buy our food, and cover the costs of our travel and transport.  
The ImpactMonks from our monastery have been visiting the UK and Europe since our charitable trust was established in 2003.  We have built up a great community of friends and supporters, who have made it possible for us to continue our study in India.  Over the previous years, we have managed to take enough money back to the monastery to build a new Debate Hall, which means that our priceless study can continue whatever the weather, in the hottest part of the summer or in the monsoon season.  Now our aim is to continue to support the monastery through funds raised during our tour, to build new hostels for the young monks, who due to over-crowding often have to sleep more than ten to a room, which makes it difficult for them to study hard at a very important stage of their lives.  Our contribution also supports elderly monks, whose only home is now the monastery, and for whom we care as if they were our family until the day they die. The tour income helps supply money for the food fund, the school, the clinic, which not only cares for the monks, but also the local population.  


Risks & Challenges
We must register our show in the Edinburgh Fringe by 8th April, otherwise we will not be included in the Festival Programme.  The average audience attendance figure at the Edinburgh Fringe is 2!  Our venue's average attendance for shows is 25 - and this is the first time that the Greenside Royal Terrace venue has had workshops and performances like ours in the space.  We need to make a proper impact through advertising and promotion to make our performances stand out, and if we don't, then we will end up making a loss on the week.  
Encouragingly when we have performed at the Edinburgh Fringe in the past in other venues, we have averaged around 85% audience capacity for our performances, which is an impressive record.  We have experience of contacting the press, and are prepared to go out onto the Royal Mile with our flyers to make sure that people know where we are and what we are doing.  

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can help us with a donation - however small - towards our goal, that would be wonderful.  If it is not possible, then please 


Spread the Word! If you can't donate, please let others know we are here! 
Share this page on your Facebook page and Tweet the news that we are coming to Edinburgh in August 2015
Send us a tweet on Twitter @tashimonks 
Like us on www.facebook.com/tashi.lhunpo.monks and share our updates with your family and friends
Consider becoming a long-term sponsor of one of Tashi Lhunpo Monastery's monks - for details see http://www.tashi-lhunpo.org.uk/

Keep in touch with us through our website at www.tashi-lhunpo.org.uk

Come to one of our performances during the 2015 tour - details on our website at www.tashi-lhunpo.org.uk

story:
The ensemble of thirteen classical trained actors 

bring to life the story of the banished royal Rosalind, who escapes to the Forest of Arden to seek freedom in a new world of fools, runaways, and lovers.  


PERFORMANCES:

JULY 31st - 8:00pm
AUGUST 1st - 2:00 & 8:00pm
AUGUST 2nd - 2:00pm

*The Production will be performed at The Stella Adler Studio of Acting (Studio 1)


BUY TICKETS HERE--http://www.eventbrite.com/e/no-stones-as-you-like-it-tickets-16293429085?aff=es2

What We Need

The Production is operating on a tight budget so we are asking for $2000 to help support and fund the following investments:

  • Costumes
  • Creative Team Stipends
  • Props
  • Weapons
  • Insurance
  • Supplies and other resources (scripts, makeup, etc.)

story:
Short Summary

The Boys Next Door is a one-act play written by Tom Griffin and directed by Griffin Johnston and Vaughn Sherman, both juniors at Catalina Foothills High School. In this heartwarming show about four mentally handicapped adults and their caretaker, they learn what it means to laugh and love in a world that isn't always fair. The main goal of doing this show is to help spread awareness of people with similar situations as our characters take on the journey to laugh and love like everybody else. We aimed to perform a show outside the "norm" with a deeper meaning that would leave an impact on the audience.

Cast and Crew

Arnold Wiggins: Griffin Johnston

Norman Bulansky: Vaughn Sherman

Jackie Palmer (adapted from Jack Palmer): Stefanie Tedards

Lucy P. Smith (adapted from Lucien P. Smith): Savannah Runge

Barry Klemper: Justyn Zeider

Sheila: Jacqi Miller

Various Roles: Margot Vazquez

Stage Manager: Gabriela Yadegari 

Production Assistant: Maxwell Webb 

What We Need & How You Can Help

Altogether we'd like to raise $13,500. We are trying to send 9 people to Lincoln, Nebraska for the international competition. This results in a cost of $1,500 for each person. If we do not reach our goal all proceeds will go to the Catalina Foothills Theater Department to be used in the betterment of the program.

The Impact 

Our goal with performing the show is to spread awareness of the handicapped. We took on the challenge of truly transforming ourselves into these characters and helping the audience see life through their eyes. After watching our performance at the Arizona State Thespian Festival, a judge commented that we "made handicapped people proud."

Risks & Challenges

Some of the challenges we've faced through doing this show were how to portray a handicapped person without making fun of the character. Right from the beginning it was made clear that by no means were we trying to make fun of anyone, but to instead show people what life is like for those with lives like theirs.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us out by spreading the word about our campaign! Tell your friends and family! We also have a website where you can keep up to date with the cast and crew and hear about any future updates!

story:
I'm taking Ina on the road!

Ina's story will be shared in 2015 at the Las Vegas Fringe Festival, the Hollywood Fringe Festival, the Capital Fringe Festival (DC), and in Ina's hometown of Chicago! Tourin' ain't as cheap as it used to be and I can't do it on my own, so eliciting the assistance of friends and family! My expenses include travel for my stage manager and me, housing expenses, rental car fees (I have sooooo many props to transport!), gas, festival entree fees, programs, mailers, flyers, rehearsal studio fees, and who knows what kind of other unexpected expenses.

You helped me make my NYC debut a success in October, so let's continue this streak through 2015!

Thank you!
xoXOxo
~Melissa

story:
Solee

I am a 12 year old aspiring ballerina, who spends over 12 hours a week in a dance studio (Tuesday - Saturday).  I'm also an "A" Student.

I started dancing at the Hudson River Performing Arts Center (HRPAC), in Fishkill NY at the age of 3.  Each year I was permitted to participate in ballet, tap, and jazz.  In the recent years, I have increased the number of dance hours each week and expanded the styles of dance I study to include lyrical, modern, and pointe.  I am also a member of the HRPAC Ballet Repertory Company and the HRPAC Dance Company.  I still can't seem to get enough.  To me a day without dance is a boring day.  Although I try to take advantage of all that is offered at HRPAC, Summers are bitter-sweet since dance classes in the summer are limited at my dance school.

This year I decided to audition for summer intensive programs.  I believe my hard work and dedication paid off.  I have been offered the opportunity to attend summer programs with the American Academy of Ballet (AAB), Joffrey Ballet School (JBS), and the Ailey School.   I am honored by the recognition from each of these prestigious programs.  It excites me even more to think of the experience I will be able to have under the guidance of so many talented dance instructors.

Please help me on the path to realizing my dream to dance professionally.  A summer intensive program will help me continue to work on my technique at the hands of world renowned teachers, choreographers, and dancers.

It was a very difficult decision, but based on program availability I decided to attend a combination of AAB and JBS.  With the help of my parents chaperoning and my extended family offering some housing, I have a plan to attend 4 weeks.  The cost for each week averages approximately $1,000 - including tuition, housing, meals, and transportation.  If I do not raise enough to attend any of the weeks, the money will be used to attend a program that is run by my local ballet school.

Thank you for any assistance and encouragement you can offer.

story:
On the day Edgar Allan Poe was buried, a scurrilous obituary appeared in the New York Tribune. Within a year, Rufus Griswold published a biography further slandering his character and beginning many of the misconceptions and myths we still hold about Poe.  

We thought it only appropriate to start our show with Poe's death.

We meet Mr. Poe in the twilight between life and death, in the realm between heaven and hell, where past shadows loom large and the final defense of your actions and character is the only thing present.  

Madman. Drunk. Addict. Philanderer. Caught in the maelstrom of life's shadows, Mr. Poe will defend himself. We are the judge and jury. Will he succeed? 

 

Our Story

We started TMRTCo. in 2011 as an experiment to see if a small theater company could help in the revitalization of our town.  

What Makes Us Unique

We wanted a different approach; as a collective of local artists, amateurs and professionals, we banded together to form our troupe. Our vision was to offer original scripts that were fresh and exciting. Many of us have backgrounds in visual arts and some have technical backgrounds so part of our focus became the integration of strong visual effects to drive our story lines.  

Our Unorthadox Production Methods

Because we always workshop our shows, we abandoned the idea of a set season,  instead taking whatever time we needed to perfect a production. We also decided that a small and intimate number of audience members would allow us to extend the run time for each production ("Miss Lilly's" ran for 2 years). This approach allows more time between productions (developing our next show) as well as bringing the sense that there is always something to do in Downtown Mount Holly.

Bringing the Production Process to the Community

Part of our process is to perform public readings of our new works. We perform these readings in local coffee shops, bars, empty store fronts; anywhere we might draw in a new audience or possible members. 

As part of this we always include a question and discussion period, giving us feedback on what is working (or not working) while educating the general public on our specific approach to theater. We are also looking for ways to open up other parts of our process to the public (invites to rehearsals or technical workshops).

Currently we have three shows we are working on. The first is "The Poe Project" which is ready for production as soon as we raise the money. 

The second is "Lady Dunsworth's Dilemma," a contemporary farce based on the Victorian Parlor comedies. "Lady Dunsworth" got its start as a 30 minute sketch for a local festival. We received such wonderful feedback that now we have decided to develop it into a full length play. 

Our third show has at the working tittle "When A Liberal Education Goes Bad."  It exists in the form of an outline, character studies and several written scenes. It is best described as a dark and bloody romp, an absurdist's view of the coming revolution and the making of a mass murderer.  

___

The Poe Production: The script is written, the show cast, and the director is in place. Initial rehearsals have begun and we are already experimenting with the shadow portion of the show. We have been playing with live silhouettes combined with mechanical cutouts, overhead projectors with ink and water, soft fabric puppets submerged in fish tanks, and even video projecting directly onto the actor's face.  

We are excited about the possibilities we have been discovering. 

We are already in pre-production at our Mount Holly, NJ location. We project to start performing the show by the beginning of October, 2015 (plenty of time for Halloween season).

Our Needs: Although we are inventive and used to cobbling together our technical needs, it would be nice to have some new equipment to help us raise our professional standards.  

(Enlarge image)

Our time is cheap (actually free) so all donations will go directly into the materials and equipment we need to produce this show. 

(Enlarge image)

Any money raised past our goal will be used to enhance the theater space itself.  While none of us mind a dirty old warehouse, we do consider the needs of our audience. It would be nice to offer some comfortable seating, perhaps on risers or to hang fabric over the cinderblock walls; some sort of house lighting would also be nice.

story:
Wanted: Help to make our Orchestra Pit, "a Little Pit Bigger!"

Thriving Amateur Dramatics society  (with good sense of humour, loves an audience and lovely assets ) seeks gorgeous generous piles of cash for fun times! Would enjoy excavation and renovation of old dank and tiny orchestra pit and conversion to shiny new exciting musical and theatrical facility.  Likes to support the community, and have fun doing it and would love to meet the money of awesome people who share their interests.
  • We would like to renovate our very small unsuitable orchestra pit so we can improve the condition for our musicians in our shows, productions and events
  • We want to do it in a way that will allow for flexible seating and staging options depending on the needs of the production
  • We want to continue to support the community, and talents of our members by providing high quality shows and opportunities to develop.
  • We need to raise at least £10,000 to do this!
For more details read on!

So what's this all about anyway?

Picture the scene - you are a part of a successful thriving amateur dramatics group lucky enough to have the freehold to their own small but much beloved theatre: a theatre that survives by putting on quality performances from musicals, plays, shows and standup comedy right through to panto for the local community, all through the voluntary efforts of members passionate about the theatre.  The Wells Little Theatre, home of the Wells Operatic Society, is a wonderful resource and a dream come true for any amateur dramatics society with one main drawback. The orchestra pit is...well, the pits!

Wells Little Theatre, small but perfectly formed! If it looks a bit familiar, it might be because some scenes  from Hot Fuzz were filmed  here - indeed some of our members got to be extras in the film! The pit is so small it is barely visible  from this angle.

This gives you an idea of the proportional  size of the pit. 
We feel quality live music in performances is something that gives a real theatre experience; it raises the quality of our productions and gives a fantastic experience for performers and audience alike.  As such, we love having an orchestra pit for live musicians, but unfortunately, the current orchestra pit is something that needs considerable renovation to make it fit for purpose. To put it bluntly, it is cramped, cold and claustrophobic. We shoehorn musicians into it and they spend the equivalent of the three hours of a performance night trying to play quality music while semi-crouched, trying not to get their eyes poked by enthusiastic violinists and courting pneumonia from the dank conditions!

The current pit - as you can see, the  minimum of drums take up nearly half the space. Now imagine trying to fit up to nine very uncomfortable musicians into this tiny area with keyboards and guitars, violins, wind instruments...

In all seriousness, the Wells Operatic Society has recognised that renovating and improving the orchestra pit will attract more quality musicians to play in the Wells Little Theatre. (We are at a point where many musicians will refuse to play in the Pit due to the conditions.) Our plans also include ways to make this space much more adaptable and flexible. It would allow for some innovative staging that has a lot of potential directors very excited about the possibilities it could offer on a wider scale. This would benefit not just the musicians but the whole theatre and allow us to offer more to the community and allow even more of our talented members to develop their skills in live performance.
All we need is your help! 

The Nitty Gritty

What we want...what we really, really want is...

A solution that will give us a flexible size of orchestra pit and staging, depending on the needs of different productions. Is this impossible? No!

We have a plan - and a cunning plan it is too.

We are proposing to create a flexible space of 1.6meters in front of the current pit wall. This space will have two rows of removable seating. Which allows for additional performance space on multiple levels. On top of this, this area will also have a removable floor that will cover an extended pit. This will give us the option of expanding the pit in 0.8 meter sections giving us three potential pit configurations. A second entrance to the auditorium would be made  available to accommodate this change. The exciting thing about this is that it allows for a huge amount of flexibility.

The cost of these improvements is £27,000. We hope to receive £17,000 from the Arts Council from an application we have submitted, and it is down to the theatre to find the remaining £10,000.

As a not-for-profit organisation, any revenue from ticket sales have already been ploughed back into the theatre itself so we are pretty much starting from scratch. The theatre always needs improvements, new equipment and basic maintenance so all funds are used positively. Anything you can spare will be gratefully received and we will be working hard as a society to raise this money in as many ways as we can manage.


But what will this do? Really?

Those of us in the Wells Operatic Society pride ourselves in giving talent a chance to shine, and including everyone in our performances and theatre community. Modesty aside, our frequent nominations and wins in many of the South West's amateur dramatics awards are  an indication of how well we 'punch above our weight' when it comes to comparing the quality of our shows against many other societies with greater resources at their fingertips. We give many children and young people their first experiences of live performance and are fortunate enough that those who have decided to that this is their passion have secured prestigious further education places and scholarships which are in no small way due to their experiences at the theatre. We would like to continue and improve upon that record by updating and upgrading the facilities we have the best we can.
Having the capacity to attract quality live music opens up a lot of possibilities and benefits not just for members but for the local community as well. We really are all inclusive - there are very few other places where such a diverse mix of people can form such a tight knit social group. We have had members aged from 5 to 85 on stage in the same show, for example!
The Wells Operatic Society has been in existence since 1902, so we are not likely to vanish overnight!  It was in 1979 that the society was offered the chance to buy the building's freehold and the members of the time did a truly epic amount of fundraising and managed to achieve this incredible goal. Since then we have a track record of keeping the society going, running the building, making improvements and all of this managed by unpaid volunteers.
Fundraising this amount of money will always be a challenge - and  if the Arts Council funding is not secured this will raise the level of difficulty even higher! However, we believe that the theatre needs improvements to keep it attractive to members and the local community and this particular aspect is first on our theatre improvement list. If people are incredibly generous, who knows, we might get heating in the changing rooms next! (I know! Unimaginable luxury!) Or upgrades to the auditorium seating....or new lighting equipment! The point to be made is, no-one's generosity would be wasted . There are always requirements and we will appreciate anything and everything you can spare us.

Er..well, I'd love to help but I'm a bit strapped for cash at the moment...

We know the feeling! Actually, if you want to help in other ways, we'd really appreciate help in getting the word out.  Have a word with that millionaire who lives down the road (what do you mean you don't live down the road from a millionaire?!) or share on facebook, twitter, - anywhere you can think of! Draw it to people's attention, use the Indiegogo share tools, or carrier pigeons, or even skywriting should you happen to have a plane! When we say any help is appreciated we mean it!

Thank you for reading (if you made it this far, you have an honorary medal!) and we do hope you can spare us  even a small amount to aid us in our fundraising efforts.

Would enjoy excavation and renovation of old dank and tiny orchestra pit and conversion to shiny new exciting musical and theatrical facility.  Likes to support the community, and have fun doing it and would love to meet the money of awesome people who share their interests.

We would like to renovate our very small unsuitable orchestra pit so we can improve the condition for our musicians in our shows, productions and events
We want to do it in a way that will allow for flexible seating and staging options depending on the needs of the production
We want to continue to support the community, and talents of our members by providing high quality shows and opportunities to develop.
We need to raise at least £10,000 to do this!

For more details read on!
So what's this all about anyway?
Picture the scene - you are a part of a successful thriving amateur dramatics group lucky enough to have the freehold to their own small but much beloved theatre: a theatre that survives by putting on quality performances from musicals, plays, shows and standup comedy right through to panto for the local community, all through the voluntary efforts of members passionate about the theatre.  The Wells Little Theatre, home of the Wells Operatic Society, is a wonderful resource and a dream come true for any amateur dramatics society with one main drawback. The orchestra pit is...well, the pits!


Wells Little Theatre, small but perfectly formed! If it looks a bit familiar, it might be because some scenes  from Hot Fuzz were filmed  here - indeed some of our members got to be extras in the film! The pit is so small it is barely visible  from this angle.


This gives you an idea of the proportional  size of the pit. 
We feel quality live music in performances is something that gives a real theatre experience; it raises the quality of our productions and gives a fantastic experience for performers and audience alike.  As such, we love having an orchestra pit for live musicians, but unfortunately, the current orchestra pit is something that needs considerable renovation to make it fit for purpose. To put it bluntly, it is cramped, cold and claustrophobic. We shoehorn musicians into it and they spend the equivalent of the three hours of a performance night trying to play quality music while semi-crouched, trying not to get their eyes poked by enthusiastic violinists and courting pneumonia from the dank conditions!


The current pit - as you can see, the  minimum of drums take up nearly half the space. Now imagine trying to fit up to nine very uncomfortable musicians into this tiny area with keyboards and guitars, violins, wind instruments...
In all seriousness, the Wells Operatic Society has recognised that renovating and improving the orchestra pit will attract more quality musicians to play in the Wells Little Theatre. (We are at a point where many musicians will refuse to play in the Pit due to the conditions.) Our plans also include ways to make this space much more adaptable and flexible. It would allow for some innovative staging that has a lot of potential directors very excited about the possibilities it could offer on a wider scale. This would benefit not just the musicians but the whole theatre and allow us to offer more to the community and allow even more of our talented members to develop their skills in live performance.
All we need is your help! 
   The Nitty Gritty What we want...what we really, really want is...
A solution that will give us a flexible size of orchestra pit and staging, depending on the needs of different productions. Is this impossible? No!
We have a plan - and a cunning plan it is too.
We are proposing to create a flexible space of 1.6meters in front of the current pit wall. This space will have two rows of removable seating. Which allows for additional performance space on multiple levels. On top of this, this area will also have a removable floor that will cover an extended pit. This will give us the option of expanding the pit in 0.8 meter sections giving us three potential pit configurations. A second entrance to the auditorium would be made  available to accommodate this change. The exciting thing about this is that it allows for a huge amount of flexibility.
The cost of these improvements is £27,000. We hope to receive £17,000 from the Arts Council from an application we have submitted, and it is down to the theatre to find the remaining £10,000.
As a not-for-profit organisation, any revenue from ticket sales have already been ploughed back into the theatre itself so we are pretty much starting from scratch. The theatre always needs improvements, new equipment and basic maintenance so all funds are used positively. Anything you can spare will be gratefully received and we will be working hard as a society to raise this money in as many ways as we can manage.

    But what will this do? Really?
Those of us in the Wells Operatic Society pride ourselves in giving talent a chance to shine, and including everyone in our performances and theatre community. Modesty aside, our frequent nominations and wins in many of the South West's amateur dramatics awards are  an indication of how well we 'punch above our weight' when it comes to comparing the quality of our shows against many other societies with greater resources at their fingertips. We give many children and young people their first experiences of live performance and are fortunate enough that those who have decided to that this is their passion have secured prestigious further education places and scholarships which are in no small way due to their experiences at the theatre. We would like to continue and improve upon that record by updating and upgrading the facilities we have the best we can.
Having the capacity to attract quality live music opens up a lot of possibilities and benefits not just for members but for the local community as well. We really are all inclusive - there are very few other places where such a diverse mix of people can form such a tight knit social group. We have had members aged from 5 to 85 on stage in the same show, for example!
The Wells Operatic Society has been in existence since 1902, so we are not likely to vanish overnight!  It was in 1979 that the society was offered the chance to buy the building's freehold and the members of the time did a truly epic amount of fundraising and managed to achieve this incredible goal. Since then we have a track record of keeping the society going, running the building, making improvements and all of this managed by unpaid volunteers.
Fundraising this amount of money will always be a challenge - and  if the Arts Council funding is not secured this will raise the level of difficulty even higher! However, we believe that the theatre needs improvements to keep it attractive to members and the local community and this particular aspect is first on our theatre improvement list. If people are incredibly generous, who knows, we might get heating in the changing rooms next! (I know! Unimaginable luxury!) Or upgrades to the auditorium seating....or new lighting equipment! The point to be made is, no-one's generosity would be wasted . There are always requirements and we will appreciate anything and everything you can spare us.
    
Er..well, I'd love to help but I'm a bit strapped for cash at the moment...

 We know the feeling! Actually, if you want to help in other ways, we'd really appreciate help in getting the word out.  Have a word with that millionaire who lives down the road (what do you mean you don't live down the road from a millionaire?!) or share on facebook, twitter, - anywhere you can think of! Draw it to people's attention, use the Indiegogo share tools, or carrier pigeons, or even skywriting should you happen to have a plane! When we say any help is appreciated we mean it!
Thank you for reading (if you made it this far, you have an honorary medal!) and we do hope you can spare us  even a small amount to aid us in our fundraising efforts.

story:
Our names are Bryan Blaskie, Manny Hagopian, and C. Ryanne Domingues. We are in the process of creating and producing a new musical entitled Assistants for the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival, and we need your help!


But first, a little bit about us:

Bryan Blaskie (Co-Writer and Producer) is a pianist and composer from Columbus, Ohio. Music director: 110 in the Shade (Actor’s Co-op, Ovation Award Best Musical Intimate Theatre), The Max Factor Factor (Celebration/New Musicals, Inc), Tonya Harding: The Musical (Upright Citizens Brigade), Musical Mondays Los Angeles. He is a co-founder and music director of A Little New Music. Composer: iWish (ANMT, UC Irvine, Studio C Artists), Victorian Courting & Zombies (UCB, iO West, Hollywood Fringe). He graduated from Denison University and has studied with the Academy for New Musical Theatre. He currently serves as a staff accompanist for the American Musical & Dramatic Academy and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in Los Angeles.

Manny Hagopian (Co-Writer and Producer) is a songwriter, musician, composer, and comedy writer in Los Angeles. Based out of Boston Mass, Manny grew up playing in rock bands before he made his move out the LA to tackle musical theater. Well, he sort of fell into that. He has studied at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in LA and NYC and is a writer for the iO West theater. Manny is known for music and lyrics from Tonya Harding The Musical, Boston Boys: The Musical, Back To The Future 2: The Musical, and for his work as Writer's Assistant on the video game Titanfall.

C. Ryanne Domingues (Director and Producer) hails from the East Coast, where she spent many years in Philadelphia helping found Simpatico Theatre Project. While with Simpatico, she held the position of Producing Artistic Director for five years and directed a variety of shows, including Stop Kiss, Angels Fall, Getting Out, Long Days Journey Into Night, and Pyretown. She has also worked with a number of other Philadelphia companies including Wilma Theater, InterAct Theatre Company, and Plays & Players Theatre, among others.  Since moving to the West Coast in 2010, she has worked with New Musicals, Inc., California Shakespeare Theatre, South Coast Repertory Theatre, Little Fish Theatre Company, SkyPilot Theatre Company, and Utah Shakespeare Festival. Ryanne was a participant in the 2008 Lincoln Center Director’s Lab in NYC, and completed her MFA in Directing at the University of California, Irvine. www.ryannedomingues.com

Lindsey Norris (Stage Manger) With a recent BA in directing, performance, and design from Boise State, Lindsey recently moved to L.A. and attended the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, receiving a secondary Associates in 2015. Before moving to Los Angles, Lindsey was a stage hand for The Morrison Center in Boise, where she was a house electrician, stage manager and house manager for many years. She has had the privilege of working house crew for traveling shows that came to the Morrison Center such as; Wicked, Mama Mia,  and Les Miserables, along with many others. She also worked the house tech crew for the Tech of War Horse before its National Tour. Recently in Los Angles she has been stage managing for the 2015 Company at The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, and is honored to be apart of the amazing team working on Assistants.

Federico Cibils (Assistant Stage Manager and Assistant Director) Though originally from Cordoba, Argentina where he was born a grew up, Federico has lived in many different places around the world such as Spain, Great Britain, Mexico, The Netherlands, and now, the U.S.A. After achieving a bachelor’s degree in Industrial Design, he decided to turn his life around and give acting, a life long dream, a try. He recently moved to Los Angeles where he enrolled in The American Academy of Dramatic Arts.

Daniel Amerman (Nick) is a graduate of Yale University, where he studied Theater and English.  LA Theater: BoomerMania (El Portal Theatre), WindChimes (Company of Angels), Down In the Face of God (The Vagrancy).  TV: Arrested Development (pop-star Mark Cherry), The Office, Glee, CSI:NY.  www.Daniel-Amerman.com

Ali Axelrad (Liz) is originally from southern California and thrilled be back on an LA stage, having spent the last five years in NYC. NY Credits: ..Spelling Bee (Olive), The Seagull (Nina), and King John (Blanche). Other favorite stage credits include: Fiddler on the Roof( Chava/Sierra Repertory Theater), Peter Pan (Wendy/Stephen Sondhiem Center), LIttle Women (Amy/ Chance Theater) and the national tour of Pippi Longstocking (Annika). Many thanks to the entire Assistants team! More info at www.aliaxelrad.com

Abigail Eiland (Tara) can be seen in film, television, and theater and has played the head of a T-Rex before, which is still, in this writer’s humble opinion, her finest work. Besides Abigail’s role as a biped, her favorite projects include: Life on Mars (CBS), Criminal Minds (CBS), Daddy Knows Best, a comedic series starring Steve Rannazzisi from FX’s The League, The Last Five Years (Cathy) and Welcome to Santa at Pacific Resident Theater Company. She’ll also soon be seen in the new movie, The Interpreters, playing the hired gun, ‘Reasonor’. In addition to being a performer, Abby is also a writer. Her favorites include: The hilarious webseries Classy Parties, about 2 girls who run a bachelorette party business, the soon-to-be-released On The Err, about a struggling college radio show, and Los Angeles 10101,  which was an official selection at the Atlanta International Film Festival. To everybody I love - thank you, thank you, thank you, from the bottom of my heart.

Christopher Renfro (Isaac) is thrilled to be making his Hollywood Fringe Festival debut with such an awesome team! He is currently on tour, playing to thousands of kids across Southern California as Jay in Jay and E and the ZigZag Sea with Kaiser Permanente Educational Theater. Past credits include My Little Brony (Off-B'way, Playroom Theater), The 39 Steps (UC Irvine), and Spring Awakening (Landis Performing Arts Center). BA in Drama from the University of California, Irvine. Thank you to everyone at UCI, in my troupe, Ryanne and Mady. You guys will get your coffee soon!

Andrew Thomas (Nick Understudy) Raised in Huntington Beach California, this 24 year old is very excited and honored to join the cast of Assistants! He trained and graduated from The American Academy of Dramatic Arts in Hollywood where he attended for 2 years. The roles he's played have ranged from Gabe from Next to Normal to George from Our Town. Assistants will mark his official professional debut as an entertainer and he hopes he will make a very good first impression!

Now that you know a little bit about us, it's time to explain what we are hoping to accomplish. Our goal is to raise money to produce the new musical Assistants in the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival. Here's what the show is about:

Following a group of hopeful assistants, this world premiere musical comedy explores the superiority complex of Hollywood and the glamorous lifestyle that seems to elevate its participants above “ordinary” people. Through a string of heartfelt songs, four industry aspirants maneuver around long hours, degrading work, and hostile environments in the name of their big dream. All alone in the bustling city of L.A., the characters find that in order to survive, they may need some assistance of their own.

And so, we ask the question everyone wants to know: Why do you need to support THIS show NOW?

One of the reasons that you should help with THIS show is that it is a world premiere. With more movies being made into plays, and more plays being made into movies, it is rare that a genuinely new idea gets to flourish and be supported in the entertainment industry. Supporting the development of new work ensures that the artistic world will continue to grow and change with our society, rather than be merely a reflection of the past. In addition, this show is being developed by a group of people who have extensive experience in this area, and can therefore guarantee not only the show's success, but the quality of the work.

The reason you should support this show NOW is because Assistants is a show that is incredibly relevant to the Hollywood industry TODAY. With multimedia constantly growing and Twitter feeds bringing people their news, it is time for a show to reflect how our current, fast-paced society has had an effect on the entertainment business. Doing the show in this year's Hollywood Fringe Festival gives us access to new audiences and marketing opportunities that we may not have otherwise.

What will your donation go towards?

Your donation will help cover costs of the production, such as the following:

Theater Rental: $1,500.00
Fringe Festival Registration Fee: $250
Marketing Fees: $150

In addition, you will help to pay each actor, director, writer, and stage manager for their work during 70 hours of rehearsal, 10 hours of performance, and countless hours of writing. You will also help pay our design consultants for their contributions and our brilliant sound engineer for helping us to create our original cast recording. These artists have put an enormous amount of time and energy into honing their craft, and we are incredibly grateful that they have chosen to be part of this production. Please help us pay them a fraction of what their time and talent is worth.

Thank you so much for taking the time to review our campaign! Any little bit helps! If you cannot afford to donate at this time, you can also help by spreading the word about our show! Dates, times, and ticket prices are as follows:

Saturday, June 6, 2015 (Preview) at 9:00pm
Friday, June 12, 2015 at 11:30pm
Thursday, June 18, 2015 at 7:00pm
Saturday, June 20, 2015 at 5:00pm
Sunday, June 28, 2015 at 5:00pm

The show runs 90 minutes and will perform at the Actors Company/Let Live Theater, located at 916 N. Formosa Avenue in Hollywood. For tickets and more information, please visit https://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/2191?tab=details

You can also visit our Facebook Page by searching AssistantsTheMusical, or on Twitter @assistantsmusic. Also, feel free to share this Indiegogo page with your friends and family as well!

story:
Short Summary

My name is David McDonald. I am a documentary filmmaker, director of the films "Woodstock Revisited," and "The Culture Wars," and video contributer to publications like The New York Times and Chronogram Magazine (for clips of my work, see the "Gallery" page.)

About three years ago, I stumbled onto a story that was so incredibly good that I found it very hard to believe no one had told it before. Apparently, the world-famous artist Marc Chagall had spent a portion of his life living in New York, both in the city and Upstate, in the 1940s. The story of his American exile had pretty much been wiped out of the history books because of concerns of a scandal at the time. Far from being scandalous, the tale was truly poignant. I decided to make it mine.

Three years later an I had finished a 106 page screenplay. Time to get it out to Hollywood! But wait, things don't come that fast, especially if you don't have a track record there. A few months ago, we did a staged reading of the first 15 pages or so in New York City.  It was absolutely buzzing with electricity. The actors playing the roles quickly embodied their characters. To my utter surprise, the whole thing not only worked, it worked beautifully. 

At around the same time, a friend of mine who is affiliated with a theater space in Upstate New York floated the idea of making the space available while we labbed the production for an eventual theatrical run. Again, it was an idea I had not conceived of before, but the more I thought about it, the more logical the idea seemed to be! And what fun it would be too! From finding the actors, blocking out the action, building the sets, and transforming some of the filmic special effects into theatrical action. When a young Marc Chagall goes to the synagogue with his father and imagines the old men floating out of their pews...how would we do that on stage? A wonderful set of challenges. 

The story of Marc Chagall's life...always on the run...a man without a real country...represents to me what I view to be possibly the single-greatest allegory of the Jewish diaspora of the 20th century.  When people experience it for the first time, the one response I always get is: "I cannot believe this story hasn't been told yet!" It is such an affecting and powerful story, whether it's on film or it's on stage, it's going to move people. I want to share it with the world. You can help me make that happen! 

What We Need & What You Get

Well, obviously, we are going to need a theater, or something resembling one. Although some theaters have offered us a space to lab the production, they cannot be expected to host us without some recompense. The goal of this project is to create a living, breathing marketable production. That production will then hopefully be monetizable for whatever theater space chooses to host us down the road, but I foresee the "lab" part and the rehearsals taking two months of preparation, and only if we work on this intensely.

Then there's the question of finding the right actors and crew, none of whom should be expected to work for free. Set builders will be needed, etc. I intend to direct but I will seek out experienced stage people to manage the production. 

Further costs will include things like copyright clearances for Chagall imagery, legal rights in general, and compensating our musical composers for their time and work.  Those who are familiar with my film work know that music has always played  a big role.

PERKS

Feel free to contact me personally if you have something particular in mind for yourself. Here are the basic perks:

$20 - Friend

Free ticket to any performance.

$50 - Supporter

2 tickets to any performance

$100 - Big Supporter

5 tickets to any performance

$1,000 - Believer

Signed copy of the screenplay and 5 free tickets to any performance

$5,000 - Big Believer

Credit, signed copy, dinner with the producers and cast, and ten free tickets to any performance

$10,000 - Associate Producer

Credit, signed copy, dinner with the producers and cast, and points on the theatrical production, to be determined between us.

$15,000 - Co-Producer

Credit, signed copy, dinner with the producers and cast, and further points on the theatrical production, to be determined between us.

$20,000 - Heavyweight

All of the above, plus host of the opening night production and party. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are two primary ways you can help, both equally important. The first, obviously, is through contributing money. Do that and you have a friend for life. Seriously.

The other way you can help -- and I can't emphasize how helpful this would be -- is simply by sharing the project and spreading the word. I mentioned this before, but Chagall's plight during the two world wars -- having most of his own work stolen, and  then having to fight to get it back -- is one of the most powerful stories of the Jewish   diaspora ever. People hear about this project and their jaws drop. I need you to get this story out to each and every person you know who may be affected by it. You will be surprised by how much it touches your friends as well. It is a story that can become part of the shared canon of an entire culture. I am blessed to have discovered it. And I am blessed to share it. Please share it as well...
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is David McDonald. I am a documentary filmmaker, director of the films "Woodstock Revisited," and "The Culture Wars," and video contributer to publications like The New York Times and Chronogram Magazine (for clips of my work, see the "Gallery" page.)

About three years ago, I stumbled onto a story that was so incredibly good that I found it very hard to believe no one had told it before. Apparently, the world-famous artist Marc Chagall had spent a portion of his life living in New York, both in the city and Upstate, in the 1940s. The story of his American exile had pretty much been wiped out of the history books because of concerns of a scandal at the time. Far from being scandalous, the tale was truly poignant. I decided to make it mine.


Three years later an I had finished a 106 page screenplay. Time to get it out to Hollywood! But wait, things don't come that fast, especially if you don't have a track record there. A few months ago, we did a staged reading of the first 15 pages or so in New York City.  It was absolutely buzzing with electricity. The actors playing the roles quickly embodied their characters. To my utter surprise, the whole thing not only worked, it worked beautifully. 


At around the same time, a friend of mine who is affiliated with a theater space in Upstate New York floated the idea of making the space available while we labbed the production for an eventual theatrical run. Again, it was an idea I had not conceived of before, but the more I thought about it, the more logical the idea seemed to be! And what fun it would be too! From finding the actors, blocking out the action, building the sets, and transforming some of the filmic special effects into theatrical action. When a young Marc Chagall goes to the synagogue with his father and imagines the old men floating out of their pews...how would we do that on stage? A wonderful set of challenges. 

The story of Marc Chagall's life...always on the run...a man without a real country...represents to me what I view to be possibly the single-greatest allegory of the Jewish diaspora of the 20th century.  When people experience it for the first time, the one response I always get is: "I cannot believe this story hasn't been told yet!" It is such an affecting and powerful story, whether it's on film or it's on stage, it's going to move people. I want to share it with the world. You can help me make that happen! 
   What We Need & What You Get Well, obviously, we are going to need a theater, or something resembling one. Although some theaters have offered us a space to lab the production, they cannot be expected to host us without some recompense. The goal of this project is to create a living, breathing marketable production. That production will then hopefully be monetizable for whatever theater space chooses to host us down the road, but I foresee the "lab" part and the rehearsals taking two months of preparation, and only if we work on this intensely.
Then there's the question of finding the right actors and crew, none of whom should be expected to work for free. Set builders will be needed, etc. I intend to direct but I will seek out experienced stage people to manage the production. 
Further costs will include things like copyright clearances for Chagall imagery, legal rights in general, and compensating our musical composers for their time and work.  Those who are familiar with my film work know that music has always played  a big role.
PERKS
Feel free to contact me personally if you have something particular in mind for yourself. Here are the basic perks:
$20 - Friend
Free ticket to any performance.
$50 - Supporter
2 tickets to any performance
$100 - Big Supporter
5 tickets to any performance
$1,000 - Believer
Signed copy of the screenplay and 5 free tickets to any performance
$5,000 - Big Believer
Credit, signed copy, dinner with the producers and cast, and ten free tickets to any performance
$10,000 - Associate Producer
Credit, signed copy, dinner with the producers and cast, and points on the theatrical production, to be determined between us.
$15,000 - Co-Producer
Credit, signed copy, dinner with the producers and cast, and further points on the theatrical production, to be determined between us.
$20,000 - Heavyweight
All of the above, plus host of the opening night production and party. 
Other Ways You Can Help
There are two primary ways you can help, both equally important. The first, obviously, is through contributing money. Do that and you have a friend for life. Seriously.
The other way you can help -- and I can't emphasize how helpful this would be -- is simply by sharing the project and spreading the word. I mentioned this before, but Chagall's plight during the two world wars -- having most of his own work stolen, and  then having to fight to get it back -- is one of the most powerful stories of the Jewish   diaspora ever. People hear about this project and their jaws drop. I need you to get this story out to each and every person you know who may be affected by it. You will be surprised by how much it touches your friends as well. It is a story that can become part of the shared canon of an entire culture. I am blessed to have discovered it. And I am blessed to share it. Please share it as well...

story:
Creation Of New Theatre Performance

We are a Slovak theatre consisting of mentally challenged actors and we need to raise funds to create a new performance.

Hi! Divadlo z Pasaze,(Theater of the Passage) is a community-based theatre from Slovakia, the only one there that sustains a company actors composed of people with special needs.The theatre is trying to bridge artistic and social spheres through performance and has been working in Slovakia since 1995.

We are coming up on our 20th anniversary and want to create a special performance to commemorate the occasion. The total budget is about $12,000. The money will be used to pay salaries of the theatrical team - director, scenographer, musician, actors, sound and light technician, and materials for the scenography, costumes, lights and sound. The main theme of the new play is the S. Beckett´s Waiting for Godot . The actors are telling stories about their theatre from its founding untill now, while they are waiting for the director which is not coming...

By supporting us, you will be helping spread a human message we have believed in since our founding, that the difference is not a hurdle, and that mentally challenged people, usually hidden and stigmatized, have dignity and contribute to the world. They have a huge spiritual richness and through the theatre express their feelings, desires, humor and emotions.

We are now facing hard economical times and need your support to forge ahead and create, rehearse and perform our new play. We would appreciate it if you could make a donation and spread the word to your friends. 
Since we were founded, we have created 23 performances, made two full-length films, the documentary Protected Territory about a tour of the theatre through USA, made 5 TV-documentaries, organized 6 editions of an international biennale theatre festival, theater exhibitions, toured and made workshops in Denmark, Finland, Lithuania, Czech Republic, Latvia, Germany, Portugal, Spain, United States, and France. Having been invited by an American theatre director, we made a three-week tour around the United States (Iowa, Texas, New York). Our performances are for adults and children and they always have a moral and human message. To see short descriptions go to: http://www.divadlozpasaze.sk/divadlo/en/stagings


As a perk to our donors we will send them a DVD of the film Protected Territory - documentary about the theatre tour in USA. 
Thank you!! 


For our team Matúš Petričko, main director, and Eva Ogurčáková, dramaturgical director

story:
Aloha!  We are the kupuna (a Hawaiian word meaning “elder”, though we refer to ourselves as women of a "certain age") of Hālau KaUaTauhine.  We study and perform under the guidance and direction of our Kumu Hula, Māhealani Uchiyama. 

Hālau Ka Ua Tuahine is named after the “sister rain” of Mānoa Valley, Oʻahu. Based in Berkeley, California, we have won numerous awards and perform locally and internationally including appearances at the Hollywood Bowl, the World Conference on Hula (Hawaiʻi Island, Maui, Oʻahu and Kauaʻi), Heiva celebrations in Tahiti, French Polynesia, and at Te Papa Tongarewa, the National Museum of New Zealand.

Māhealani Uchiyama is an award-winning dancer, musician, composer, choreographer, recording artist and teacher. She is from the lineage of Kumu Joseph Kamohaʻi Kahāʻulelio. An advocate for cultural understanding, she is the founder and Artistic Director of the Māhea Uchiyama Center for International Dance in Berkeley, California.


In 2010 many of us, including Kumu Māhealani,  competed in the San Jose International Tahiti fete.  We were honored to have won one of the top prizes in our division.


In September we will travel to Maui to participate in the 10th Annual Kū Mai Ka Hula Hula Competition.  Generally there are many more opportunities for young dancers to perform and compete on the international hula stage. As we believe that hula is a lifelong study, the opportunity to share in Hawaiian culture can extend into our golden years.  Participation in this competition is an honor for us.  It is also a great personal expense.  This is where you can help.

What we need:

Please join us in our efforts to raise the $10,000 necessary to compete.  These expenses include musician and cultural consultant honorariums, lole (custom designed and crafted costumes, including appropriate  fresh flower adornment) for ten participants,  rehearsal space rental on Maui, and a contribution to the travel & accommodation expenses for our performers. The travel expenses include round trip plane tickets from California to Maui and lodging for one week.

Over the summer we have raised some funds by selling Hawaiian plate lunches and handcrafted merchandise. We are on our way, but will need to generate much more to meet our needs. Through your kind and generous support, we hope to make the competition a reality.


What you get:

In addition to knowing that you have made a tax-deductable donation to support the arts and world dance – we have many great thank you gifts!!

~ a special hula dance workshop taught by Kumu Māhealani, Kumu Māhealani award-winning cdʻs, our official competition practice pāʻū (dance skirt) along with a beautiful hand-crafted pāʻū holder, a copy of the Hula Haumāna handbook, and a VIP post competition salon event where we will perform and share our Maui experience.

ʻIke (Knowledge)

Members of Ka Ua Tuahine are trained in the traditional way.  ʻIke (knowledge) is passed down from a kumu hula to his or her dancers and musicians, generation after generation.  This is a lineage of knowledge that we all hold sacred. Living and dancing by example for our younger dancers is a gift that we Kupuna can also pass on.  Hula is life.

If you would like to support the arts, world dance, Hawaiian culture, or dancers of a “certain age” – this is your chance.

If you canʻt contribute - sharing our campaign with friends, family, or your mailing list, would be a huge help.

Mahalo loa nui, (Thank you very much)

The Kupuna of Hālau KaUaTuahine


"Me Ke Aloha Kuʻu Home O Kahaluʻu" used by permission

http://www.olomanamusic.com

story:
Who I am?

Hi! I´m Eliana Lopez , an accomplished  actress in my native country of Venezuela. Before I moved to San Francisco to have a family, I spent my life shuttling between studios, rehearsals and national or international tours. Six years ago, I married an American politician from San Francisco and came with him to start a new life, a new family. We began to construct a life together, had a son, and I began a long process of adjustment to a new culture.  It wasn’t easy but, in spite of a lot of bumps on the road, my husband and I were figuring out how to blend two very different cultures and emotional styles.  Then, almost overnight, my life was turned inside out. Suddenly, a private argument with my husband exploded into a citywide controversy about domestic abuse.  Without my consent or control, my personal life as a political wife became a political football.  San Francisco advocacy groups and political factions in the city administration, including forces aligned with our powerful Mayor, tried to turn me into a a symbol of female victimhood and to derail the career of my husband, who is a well known progressive reformer.    

In Venezuela, I was used to being in the public spotlight.  But here, in San Francisco, as I watched the news, I was a spectator of my own life. Everybody was talking ABOUT me, but not WITH me. I felt used, powerless. For the first time I experienced what it feels to be voiceless. 

It took me almost two years before I could sit and watch everything that we endured as a family without getting emotional. In 2014 I decided to tell "my story" and do something that would allow me to heal and forgive. The medium that I know best  is theater, so in collaboration with my brother Alfonso Lopez, we wrote the script for this play.

As an actress and artist I´m taking this nightmare and turning it into something positive, not just for myself but for anyone who is concerned with the injustices and political  and social biases that impact immigrants in the United States.  This story of of self-transformation and human growth reflects the experiences of many of those trying to adjust to a new culture just as it portrays the obstacles many reformers confront when they challenge powerful political interests.

Through the most difficult moments in this experience, the Latino community and the community of color stood fiercely beside me. Their strong support and outrage against what I was facing, helped to change the course of the story and it was an invaluable source of strength for me. It is why I want to make this show a bilingual one. Just as interracial families and immigrant communities live between two languages so two this theatrical performance is told in both Spanish and English, with supertitles so that everyone who comes can understand.

In collaboration with the "Victoria Theater" we bring back  to you “WHAT IS THE SCANDAL,” a one woman show, in which I will play a dozen characters and will expose current issues. Definitely, It is not only my voice, but it is the reality of many others as well. 

The proposal:

Like every art project we need the support of all of you to make it happen. One year ago we decided to raise $ 18.000  to produce a three week run of "What Is The Scandal?" in San Francisco. Thanks to contributions from many generous sponsors we reached that goal.  Now we need your help to raise $ 10.000  more to make this new show a reality and bring it to a broader audience.  To do this,  we need to organize our community to bring them to the Theatre. Some members of our community can not afford to pay for a ticket. It is why we are reaching out to organizations and offering half prices tickets and group rates. In some cases, we are also offering free tickets.

Your contribution, a deeply appreciated gift, will go toward the cost of 50% of the production and 50%  sponsor tickets to the community.

  • Salaries to our Artistic, Technical, Front of House: •  Director •  Designers (Set, Lighting, Costumes, Props) •  Composer Royalties • Stage Manager  • Running Crew - Community Organizer 
  • Sponsoring tickets for  Students, Seniors, Monolingual members of our community, LGBT and more. 
Your gift is FULLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE! Make a difference with your gift! We really appreciate your support! 
Let´s spread the word!

We can´t do this without you. We know that not everyone can donate large amounts, but believe us when we say, we appreciate anything you can do! 

1- Share this information through whatever media you can! Share, share and share: Facebook us. Tweet us. Instagram us.

2- Come to see the show with friends and family.

3- Spread the word.

2- Come to see the show with friends and family.
3- Spread the word.

story:
Full Spectrum Theatre Company's mission is to expand our perceptions of who "looks" and "sounds" American in order to highlight our connections beyond the surface of race, ethnicity and accents.  Through racially integrated casting and artistic excellence, our repertory of plays and musicals focus on universal themes with no forced cultural associations, other than being set in today's America.  By presenting "every day" American characters with integrated casting, we believe our audiences will not only "see" a diverse ensemble on stage, they will also "see" characters that are easily relatable through the universal experiences of family dynamics, friendships, and growing pains. The "full spectrum" of racial and ethnic diversity also encompasses the "full spectrum" of the human condition and ultimately ties us all together as fellow Americans.
 
We chose Rabbit Hole because it's a beautifully written Pulitzer Prize winning play by David Lindsay-Abaire.  It's also traditionally cast with a singular race and we believe the story is just as effective and relatable when you see it presented with talented actors who happen to look different from each other.
 
www.fullspectrumtheatre.com
 

 

A production of this caliber also comes with huge expenses, and we need your help to cover these big costs!

 

Putting up a show of this caliber has some big costs!

  • The Davenport Theatre Rental: $9,000

  • The rights for the play: $1,600

  • Rehearsal space for 128 hours in NYC $3000

  • Stipends for a cast of 5 wonderfully talented and hardworking actors and crew of 10 people

  • An elaborate set with a long list of props, some of which include food items that must be fresh every night on stage

  • Printing programs, posters and postcards

  • Advertising in newspapers, magazines and on the internet

  • Rental for a van during load in and load out

  • Accident insurance

...The list keeps going and going!

As a THANK YOU for your incredibly generous contributions, we've put together a list of exciting perks!

 

We Have Added A New Perk!!

Color Me Beautiful! And Strong. $300

High Fashion Colorist Eric Muroski (Featured in Glamour, Allure & Martha Stewart|Whole Living) and Personal Trainer Joe Cortes of IronLIFE Fitness have joined forces and are generously donating to Custom Hair Color Service and Personal Training Sessions to cover all your Beauty & Fitness needs! And we will throw in 2 VIP tickets to our show for good measure.  (Actual Value: $625)

**You will receive 2 vouchers, delivered within 1-3 business days of payment

 

 

Eric Muroski a colorist from Marie Robinson, Sally Hershberger, and Aveda Soho, has branched out on his own. He now works from his "pod," housed within a quiet, casual salon in fashionable Flatiron. Eric's goal is to deliver high end color, without pretension, attitude or a hefty price tag. Though his color can be seen in Film, Television, Stage, and Print, NYC to LA - Eric's approach is very relaxed. His chill and upbeat demeanor disguises an exacting attention to detail that is the hallmark of his style, meticulously tailoring his work to the needs of each client. Eric fixes his keen eye on the interplay between color, texture, and movement - the building blocks of beautiful, wearable color.  Featured in:  Allure Magazine; Glamour Magazine “When hair color is perfect, it looks like water on a sunny day -- equal parts movement, dimension, and shine”  Eric Muroski ~ Whole Living|Martha Stewart   www.ericmuroski.com

 

The Finer Details:  Voucher Valid until 2/28/2016; Limit 1 per client (may be used as gift); Tip not included (please Tip based on full value); Appointment time based on stylist’s availability; give 1-2 week notice; Best for short to long lengths, thin to medium thick, straight or wavy hair.  Good for Single or Double process, Highlights, Balayage and/or Gloss (Max value: $250  Addt’l fees may apply)

To Book Your Appointment:  Call/Text: 917.518.5908 or Email: ermuroski@gmail.com  Instagram: @ericmuroski

SUZIE CHO

(Artistic Director of Full Spectrum Theater Company/Producer/Actress)

Suzie Cho is a producer whose credits include the development of Broadway's Irena's Vow at the Walter Kerr Theatre, the original New York premiere of Murder in the First (winner of two Innovative Theatre Awards), and was lead producer of The Baby Dance with Invictus-Pub Theatre Company.  When she's not producing or acting, she works as a diversity trainer with the Anti-Defamation League.

Her acting credits span across film, television and stage, including Law and Order, Inside Amy Schumer, Spike Lee's 25th Hour, as well as national commercials.  She produced The Baby Dance with Invictus-Pub Theatre Company and played the principal role of "Wanda."   For two years, she managed and was a player on the improv comedy team Fly By Night. She's an active member of 68 Cent Crew Theatre Company, where she recently played the role of "Denise" in How Many Likes.  Her union affiliations include Actors Equity Association and Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

www.suziecho.com


ASHLEY FORD

(Co-Founder of Full Spectrum Theater Company/Actress)

Select stage credits include the National Tour of Alfred Hitchcock's The 39Steps (Female Lead, u/s), Celeste Romano in Western Canada's longest running production Tony n Tina's Wedding for Hoarse Raven Theatre, both Cabaret (Fraulein Kost) and Lend Me a Tenor (Maria Merelli) at Playhouse on Park, for which she received two nominations for Best Featured Actress on BroadwayWorld.com. In NYC, she has performed with Secondhand Theatre, Racoco Productions, M.A.D Air, Monarch Theatre, Altruistic Theatre, TNC and The Circus Warehouse in the development of new & experimental works in Dance, Movement & Theatre.  She is a co-founding member of Secondhand Theatre Co which devises new & innovative works on both stage & screen. 

www.ashley-ford.com

MARIA RIBOLI

(Director/Producer)

Maria Riboli has been active in the acting world since the age of 6. She is an actress, director, and producer. Some of her credits are: “Baaahhh!!!”, “Want&Need”, “Family of strangers”, “Panic at the Riverside Motel”, “Catch-30”. Her latest film "Locked in you" is now hitting the festival circuits all around the world. Maria directed it, produced it and starred in it as Clare.She is now in post-production with the short film, she directed and produced, “Meet me here”. 2015 is going to be a busy year for her, with two more short films to direct and produce, a web series  (‘Blue Wall’ by Sheila Mitchell Simmons) where she’ll be back in front of a camera with a very juicy roll, and then back directing “Rabbit hole” on stage in NY for the Full Spectrum Theater Company.

Maria is also an acting coach (Maria Riboli Acting Studio), a voice over artist and the spokesperson for the world-renowned beauty brand "Borghese".

www.mariariboli.com
 

Thank you for visiting our page, watching our video and reading about our story! It means so much that you took the time to look into our project and SUPPORT us!

Your donation will make a difference and you're now a part of Full Spectrum Theater Company!

We look forward to bring Rabbit Hole to life and to see you at the theater!

story_txt:
Full Spectrum Theatre Company's mission is to expand our perceptions of who "looks" and "sounds" American in order to highlight our connections beyond the surface of race, ethnicity and accents.  Through racially integrated casting and artistic excellence, our repertory of plays and musicals focus on universal themes with no forced cultural associations, other than being set in today's America.  By presenting "every day" American characters with integrated casting, we believe our audiences will not only "see" a diverse ensemble on stage, they will also "see" characters that are easily relatable through the universal experiences of family dynamics, friendships, and growing pains. The "full spectrum" of racial and ethnic diversity also encompasses the "full spectrum" of the human condition and ultimately ties us all together as fellow Americans.
 

We chose Rabbit Hole because it's a beautifully written Pulitzer Prize winning play by David Lindsay-Abaire.  It's also traditionally cast with a singular race and we believe the story is just as effective and relatable when you see it presented with talented actors who happen to look different from each other.

 
www.fullspectrumtheatre.com
 

 A production of this caliber also comes with huge expenses, and we need your help to cover these big costs!
 
Putting up a show of this caliber has some big costs!

The Davenport Theatre Rental: $9,000
The rights for the play: $1,600
Rehearsal space for 128 hours in NYC $3000
Stipends for a cast of 5 wonderfully talented and hardworking actors and crew of 10 people
An elaborate set with a long list of props, some of which include food items that must be fresh every night on stage
Printing programs, posters and postcards
Advertising in newspapers, magazines and on the internet
Rental for a van during load in and load out
Accident insurance

...The list keeps going and going!
As a THANK YOU for your incredibly generous contributions, we've put together a list of exciting perks!

Eric's goal is to deliver high end color, without pretension, attitude or a hefty price tag. Though his color can be seen in Film, Television, Stage, and Print, NYC to LA - Eric's approach is very relaxed. story:
Synopsis

                                              Elegante’…A mostly true story

  Vincent Avigone is twenty-three years old, lives in Brooklyn N.Y. and works as the “pasta guy” in his family’s Italian restaurant. He works there with his four uncles...Uncle Johnny, Uncle Ray, Uncle Mike and Uncle Unc. His entire family including his mother Marie, Aunts Annmarie, Maryanne and Antionette live within three blocks of each other in the same neighborhood in Brooklyn. Vincent doesn’t know exactly how he feels about the direction in which he sees his life heading. It’s nothing he can quite put his finger on but, he thinks there must be something different, something other than the world in which he lives.

Marcy Slotnick is a Jewish girl from Long Island who with her family, happens on one particular Mother’s Day in 1991 to patronize Vincent’s family’s restaurant. Marcy is a no non-sense girl who knows exactly who she is and where she’s going. She’s a strong, independent young woman who’s looking forward to graduating with a degree in speech-language pathology. Marcy has her whole life ahead of her and everything is going according to plan...until that one particular Sunday in May...when she meets Vincent.

What follows is a sweet, funny, touching story of two people from different worlds, whose obstacles, including family pressures and cultural differences draw them into an unlikely love story. A love story with some pretty rough edges at times...this is Brooklyn remember.

Allow yourself for a few moments to be taken to a small family trattoria in Brooklyn circa 1991. Enjoy the sounds of a bustling restaurant; the loud voices coming from the kitchen mixed with the even louder ones across the kitchen table of a Jewish household in Bellmore Long Island. Be a fly on the wall and enjoy witnessing what happens when a strong willed Jewish Princess meets a sweet, unsure of himself Italian boy next door. There’s a place just up the street and around the corner where all are welcome...all are family. It’s a place called Elegante’.

WHERE YOUR DONATIONS GO
I have BIG plans for this show. I'm not looking for this to be a one time, month long run. I intend this to be just the first run in many that will take the show from off Broadway, to Broadway, to the Tony Awards, to television, the movies, action figures and beyond. Well maybe not action figures. I believe in this play and the story it tells enough to think it appeals to a very wide audience and can be enjoyed for years to come. With this in mind I intend on making this first run of Broadway quality in terms of the sets, lighting, talent, etc. The following is a list of items we need to make this show all it can be.
1. A GREAT THEATER:

I'm planning on approximately a 100 seat house. This is big enough to give us off-Broadway status yet intimate enough to convey the feeling of a nice family restaurant in Brooklyn.

2. SETS:

The show takes place mostly in the kitchen, dining room and bar of the restaurant. I intend to build a full bar and working kitchen-counter with various food prep stations. Both of these scenery pieces will be on wheels, making them easier to move on and off the stage. Other set pieces such as Marcy's bed, both families’ kitchen tables, nightclub set, and additional set pieces will be needed.
3. PROJECTION SCREEN: 

The most impressive and significant part of the set will be a large projection screen on the back wall of the stage. This screen will act as the background for each scene. For instance, the scene inside the restaurant will include live footage that has been previously recorded at an Italian restaurant rolling as the background.  During the scenes, the actors and set pieces will be in the foreground while the video of restaurant patrons will be seen in the background, giving those scenes a more realistic look. This feature is unique, original, and promises to be very exciting… it's going to be awesome!
4. EQUITY STATUS:  

The plan for this production is that it carry an Off-Broadway equity status which will help give the production more legitimacy. That necessitates salaries for cast/crew for each rehearsal and performance.
5. PUBLICIST:

In order for this show to get the exposure it deserves, it will need the proper promotion. Elegante is very much a New York story and in turn, will attract and appeal to real New Yorkers.  It is our intention to draw the interest of people who are influential and notable, concerned with promoting authentic New York theater.

6. PROMOTIONAL MATERIALS:

Most theatrical productions will incur promotional expenses. This includes advertising, playbills, flyers, etc.

7. MUSIC:

Elegante takes place in 1991. I believe music is the only true time machine we have. The soundtrack is as important as any character in the play. It sets the tone and moves the story along. With that in mind, I have carefully chosen specific songs from the time period for each scene to communicate the story effectively.  This is briefly demonstrated in the music chosen for our promotional video.  Purchasing the rights to use artists’ music is a cost.

A TRUE NEW YORK STORY 
Every character in this play is a real person or based on a real person. There is a Ray and a Mike and an Unc and Coma; and I did work with them in a restaurant called Elegante. Marcy and her family are also real and most of the incidents in the story are true events that took place. Almost all of the events and situations depicted in the play occurred.  I simply put them to paper.
Elegante' takes place in Brooklyn and Long Island New York, 1991. This was a time of big hair, Z Cavariccis, Good Fellas, and neon colored clothes. Elegante’ illustrates the look and feel of that time. It represents what it was like living in those areas and working in an Italian restaurant.  Many people can relate to the struggles and conflicts within Vincent and Marcys’ families. This multi-dimensional story will be portrayed true to life. This quality boldly comes across in the script. One need not be from New York or of Italian or Jewish decent to relate to these characters or their story... if you have a family or have ever struggled with love, Elegante' has something for you. 

One Man's Efforts

Up until now, I have had a few friends help along the way, but I am essentially supporting this project by myself.  I do not have a team or theatre group behind me. I am just one man trying to produce and share his work. Writing Elegante’…a mostly true story was a labor of love. Please help me bring it to the stage.

Sincerely,

James Aronson

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't financially contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. You can share this campaign with everyone you know on Social Media; Facebook, Twitter, and more! Indiegogo has some VERY easy "share tools" for you to do just that! 

I’m trying to do this all on my own so, I NEED ALL THE HELP I CAN GET! It is my plan to take this show all the way to Broadway and beyond. Anything you can do in the way of helping me achieve this goal would be GREATLY APPRICIATED.

Thank you, 

James Aronson

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

James Aronson is a graduate of the American Musical and Dramatic Academy located in New York City. Over the years he has appeared in numerous stage productions both in New York and Long Island as well as a number of independent films and television shows. James is an actor, writer, musician and has completed works in several different genres. Along with writing and performing original works as a musician, he has penned 5 children's books and two graphic novels. Elegante'... a mostly true story is his first full length play. James considers this work to be the one closest to his heart as it is the true story of how he and his wife Marcy met.

Thank You                                                                                         CAST
Marcy Aronson - Co Producer                             Elizabeth Shuldiner - Marcy                       Charlie Loboscio - Videographer                        Chris Simiri               - Vincent
Joe Loboscio - Video Editor                                 Alberta J. Thompson - Vincent's Mother
