members of We Do Theatre are; Lorne Taylor, Ryan Cork, Jennifer Maw, Claire Brewster,
Luci Cook, Ryan Richards, Nick Smith and Kaitlin Wray.

  We are looking to raise enough money to cover our first venue costs, costume purchase/hire, and any props we may use for our current play Shoot Get Treasure Repeat. With any support we receive we can really start to get our much loved performances off the ground and also create a platform for future performances. Please spread the word to all of your friends and family. Any amount you give will allow us enough to put on this incredible contemporary play. Thank you for all of your support!!Please Note * we will draw a raffle where Two of our donors will receive a free ticket to the performance.

story:
HAS THIS HAPPENED TO YOU? A charming person approaches. Beautiful, respectable, full of wit, dazzle and promises. But when they've gone, you see, as if for the first time, that there is only sawdust in their wake. 


Too late, you realize that you are the victim of a scam. Ladies and gentlemen, it's an unfortunate truth: there will always be golden tongued liars to charm you right out of your pants (with wallet intact!). If you're lucky, the encounter will leave you merely embarrassed. If you aren't, you might well be out your money, love, time or attention.


But don't fear! Maxwell Fink and Sarah Swanson, themselves reformed and chastened criminals, will blow the rag and bone man's secrets wide open!


You'll never be vulnerable again! Let Maxwell and Sarah show you how to see through the fakes and frauds! Don't sleep, friends. Stay wide awake, and you'll never again fall for a HOAX.


Magician Brian M. Kehoe and playwright Annelise Montone team up once again for HOAX, an unique theater/magic hybrid that follows up on their successful 2015 collaboration, Planchette. HOAX brings us Maxwell Fink and Sarah Swanson, traveling performers who claim to share the secrets that will protect you from predators­- but, in this day and age, who can you trust?


This summer, 2016, remember: Don't be a sucker. 

BUDGET

Ladies and gentlemen, for your consideration: should you require a gesture of goodwill and confidence for your admirable support, we have provided a graphic for your edification. Pictured above are the various delights your contributions will go towards. As you can see, all are beneficial to your entertainment and overall enrichment! Help us in supporting and sustaining local Baltimore theater. We look forward to seeing you in the summer!

story:
Quintessence Theatre 

in association with An Táin Arts Centre and the New Theatre Dublin present

VESSEL

A powerful piece of theatre from one of Ireland's most exciting new companies, residents of An Táin Arts Centre, Dundalk. Exploring issues of bodily autonomy, right to life and abortion this raw, moving and topical creation is a must see event, coming to Dublin this April...but we need your help to do so.

PERFORMANCES: 4th-9th April 2016 The New Theatre, Temple Bar

Imagine…Imagine you were needed to give life to another. An innocent. 

Imagine a world where your body is not considered entirely yours.

Imagine a place where the State could tell you: We will use your body to give life to another.

You’ll survive. You have no choice, no voice.

A life depends on you.

You are not a human being…You are more than that. You are less than that.

You are a Vessel.


Inspired by recent deaths and controversies surrounding the 2013 Protection of Life during Pregnancy Act Quintessence Theatre used their innovative physical ensemble story-telling to tackle one of the most urgent, emotive and divisive human rights issue in modern Ireland, expressionistically exploring what it means when absolute Right to Life overrides bodily autonomy.

Drawing on women's true stories and lived experiences, devised in just two weeks, combining verbatim text, movement, spoken word and dance, Vessel originally  played a sell-out run at An Táin Arts Centre, Dundalk in November 2015. Now we are bringing it to Dublin to reach a wider audience and contribute more broadly to the desperately needed social conversation, to amplify women’s voices, shatter the national silence, and ask the question: what would you do?


We can't however do this alone and therefore are urging anyone who is interested and affected by this issue to help us bring this production to our nation's capital by donating anything you can - every little helps!


Your money will directly cover the costs of bringing a production such as this to Dublin, including: venue hire, prop purchases, printing costs, music licences, and actor's expenses. Helping us uncover all our upfront costs will allow all profit from ticket sales to go directly to the talented artists behind the project.

 

About the Company

As a company Quintessence seeks to explore the human condition through the most theatrical means available to us: the actor themselves, and their imagination. We harness the full potential of the actor’s body through heightened physical approaches, mime and a playful ensemble. We seek to surprise, move and provoke our audiences, entertaining them and creating dynamic, innovative, visceral and compassionate story telling that touches on issues at the heart of Irish society here and now. Previous productions include The Picture of Dorian Gray, Alice in Wonderland and Vessel. We are excited to be bringing our work to Dublin to share with you all.

story:
Short Summary

Animus Theatre Company, Inc. is an ensemble of artists that develop new work and realize the full potential of infrequently produced plays.  We challenge you, our audience, to confront interpersonal and global issues through a deeper sense of mutuality with characters and circumstances witnessed on stage.

Our company is made up of over 20 artists from varying performance and production backgrounds–from on and off Broadway to feature film and television– all united by the common goal of creating work that connects artists and audiences and reminds us all what it means to be human.

Theater offers audiences a safe place to be 'taken away'.  It's a place to escape their daily life and shift focus from one's self to a larger, more important calling.  It's a place to start conversations and begin to change the world around us.  Without you, our audience, there is no theater.  Please support Animus' 2015-2016 season as we continue our journey and do our part to bring important issues to the forefront.  

The year kicked off on November 2 with our Second Annual Animus All Day Reading Series of The Works of John Patrick Shanley at Broadway's Circle in the Square Theatre. - 12 hours of nonstop readings featuring some of Mr. Shanley's lesser known works.  This year's fest followed on the heels of our 2014 success featuring Leslye Headland’s Sin Cycle, also at Circle in the Square Theatre.  The cast of the 2014 Fest included Alexis Bledel (Gilmore Girls) and Headland, as well as Rebecca Faulkenberry (Broadway’s Spiderman) Jonathan Judge-Russo (“Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt”), Virginia Kull (“Gracepoint”) Eric William Morris (Mamma Mia), Keith Nobbs (“The Pacific”), Jonny Orsini (Fish in the Dark) Elena Ricardo (Mamma Mia), Margo Seibert (Rocky), Wrenn Schmidt (“Boardwalk Empire”), Zachary Spicer (Wit), and Sarah Steele (The Country House).

Following our Animus All Day Reading Series, get ready for our free Animus New Play Reading Series taking place at the Gene Frankel Theatre in Noho.  Here we will feature five new works from five exciting up and coming playwrights.  Did we mention it's FREE?!  Did we mention there is a BAR?!  All readings are followed by an informative Q&A with the playwright.  

Rounding out the year is our 2015-2016 Mainstage Production.  Animus Theatre is proud to announce we are working with award-winning playwright Theresa Rebeck to present a collection of her short plays.  The Bar Plays (Speakeasy, Big Mistake, Drinking Problem); Kate and Frank; What We're Up Against; and Great to See You represent a wide lens of some of Ms. Rebeck's earliest works, magnifying the resilience we all struggle to hold, and the myriad voices we choose to share.  This upcoming season will mark the first collaboration between Animus and Ms. Rebeck, providing audiences an opportunity to witness six lesser-produced works by another of the industry's finest writers.


What We Need and What You Get


To continue our mission, we need to raise a minimum of $25,000 from you, our audience.  With your generous support, along with support we have already received, we will reach our goal of $50,000 to bring you our 2015-2016 season–a season full of thought provoking theater and events.   

As a thank you, we are offering great perks, including: show tickets, free drinks, invites to see our rehearsal process, mention in our programs/website, and even a chance to read narration at one of our 5 new play reading series. 

We are grateful for anything you can give and promise to provide you, our community, with theater they deserve. 


Risks & Challenges

Theater in and of itself is a risk–it takes determination and resilience to be heard.  Over the past 3 seasons, Animus has become a proven force to be reckoned with in the Off-Broadway community.  Our voice is growing and with this comes challenges.  To simply secure a stage and insurance for our Main Stage production alone costs Animus well over $15,000.  Once we add on rehearsal space, set design, lighting, rights for performances, AEA payments and crew, we are over $30,000. 

Our one day marathon reading series wasn't cheap–we were on Broadway, you know!  Costs for the one day festival for stage, insurance, coordination of over 40 actors, rehearsals, publicity, print and equipment takes us well above $8,000. 

Rounding out the rest of the year with free readings, workshops, and other live events, Animus provides an affordable theater experience. 

Animus Theatre Company is growing.  Get Involved.

story:
BIO

Rhode Island born and raised, Briana Assante began dancing at age 5.  She danced for Carolyn Dutra and A Triple Threat Performing Art Center throughout high school.  Briana attended Rhode Island College where she received a B.A. in  Dance Performance. She performed with the Rhode Island College Dance Company for 4 years.  There, she had the pleasure of learning from and working with many talented artists such as Adele Myers, Adrian Hawkins, Nathan Andary, Danny Buraczeshi, Bridgman Packer, and so many more.  After graduating college, Briana focused on choreography and theater.  She performed and/or choreographed for Imagine Productions with the Center for Dynamic Learning, The Artist Exchange, The Bradley Playhouse, and The Courthouse Center for the Arts. In doing this, she realized how much she loves working with children.  Briana now works for theater companies and dance studios in the Rhode Island and Massachusetts area such as Arts Alive, Loral Sims School Of Dance, and Supreme Perfection Studios.  She is also a member of Metamorphosis Dance Company and performs as a  Living statue with Ten31 Productions of Pawtucket, Rhode Island. She can’t wait to share her love of dance and theater. 

 My Mission

As little kids some of us dream of being astronauts, superheroes, doctors, or unicorns.  I have always dreamed of being a dance teacher.  It is my dream to bring the magic and wonder back into dance.  As time has gone on dance studios have become so competitive and harsh.  The love and fun has been torn away leaving it cold and scary.  I believe that in every job that must be done there is an element of fun.  I want to create a dance space where children, teens, and adults can come to learn and be creative.  I want to teach how to love the art of dance on all levels not only from a competitive stand point but from a recreational standpoint as well.  All ages are welcome to join in the fun and love your imagination again! It takes a lot to believe in yourself.  It’s very scary to put yourself out there and to speak your mind.  Today we are all so stuck in our technologies that we forget about everyday interaction.  Bringing in a dance studio that involves all ages and styles can help us open up again.  It will help us to interact on many levels instead of burying our faces in a computer screen.  Life is out there waiting so go and get it.  Join me on my journey.  Open different doors, you may find a you you never knew was yours. 

*Inspired by Mary Poppins*


What We Need & What You Get

I would need to raise a minimum of $8000.00 to get the studio up and running.  I would love to go above and beyond my goal.   This will include funding for floors, mirrors, and overhead such advertising, equipment, and building costs. 

What Classes Will We Offer?

Just The Two of Us - A  chance for a Parent and/or Guardian to take class with their little one

Creative Movement - Potty trained to 4 years old

Dance Movement Therapy  - For children with special needs, helps build coordination and  social skills

Ballet -All ages, multiple levels

Tap - All ages, multiple levels

Jazz -All ages, multiple levels

Hip Hop -All ages, multiple levels

Musical Theater  - All ages, multiple levels

Modern / Contemporary - All ages, multiple levels

Lyrical - All ages, multiple levels

Assorted Fitness Classes - Adults Only

If the final goal is not met funds will still go towards opening the dance studio. 

The Impact

 What will make this dance studio a success?

We will  have a class for you!  If  you are 1 year old to 100 years old you are welcome. 

We will have many different styles of dance.  We will have family oriented classes as well as competitive class. 

We will offer exercise programs.  This is for someone just looking to get in shape or stay in shape.

We will hold classes for special needs children.  We will have a knowledgeable registered Dance/Movement Therapist on staff who is certified to educate your child.

We will be a family oriented business.  It will be family run and supported.  We will treat you like family. 

Bonus! 

 We will offer photography.  Not only will you get to take dance classes you can also get your  end of the year costume pictures,  head shots, family portraits, ext  done here!

We will offer the space out for rental.  All dancers and actors need a space to practice.  My space will be available at affordable rates so all dancers and actors will have a home to come to and express their passion and love for dance and theater. 


Risks & Challenges

Risks include competitors, and lack of clientele. 
Aside from having a degree in dance performance, over the years I have immersed myself in the studio and dance environment.  I have held many jobs in the dance and theater community from running the front desks, teaching classes, working behind the scenes, making costumes, building sets, and working backstage. I have more classes to offer than my competition and I am a fresh new face on the dance studio scene.  I will spend my time advertising and promoting my business.  I am a determined, passionate individual. I set my mind to something and I make it happen.  It has been my dream to share my love of dance and I wont stop until I achieve my goal.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! Anything helps even your kind words.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Jon Christie and I am a Dallas born playwright now making his way in Los Angeles. Almost two years ago I raised money so that I could produce my original play "Happy No Year," and thanks to the support of Indiegogo donors I was able to make that whodunit murder mystery dream a reality.

Part of that online campaign mentioned pushing this play forward into the Hollywood Fringe Festival that following summer. Well, I'm a year late but I am finally making that happen! And with the original cast agreeing to reprise their roles, this next run is destined for greatness! But now that I am in the heat of the preparation phase for the festival, I am getting a better understanding of what it is going to take to produce this and where I need funds to go.

What We Need & What You Get

I am raising $2000 to help cover the registration fee and the advertising. I didn't spend very much on advertising during this play's inaugural run because I didn't have  much competition around the holidays (except for The Nutcracker and ten versions of A Christmas Carol.) But when it comes to the Fringe Festival, advertising is everything. I have to let theatre goers know about my play in a sea of shows or no one will know it exists- flyers, banners, online ads - all are vital to make this run successful, and the cost adds up quickly.

Yes yes, the goodies - in exchange for supporting this noble cause, I can provide tickets to the show for those who are local, and fun Fringe "toys" for you out-of-towners like Fringe buttons and ornaments.

The Impact

The truth is, one way or another, Happy No Year will be in this year's Fringe Festival. However, if our goal is not met, it will be a fruitless and low attended run. I have a friend here who will help explain what your impact will mean to us.

This is  Dave.

Dave produced a play in the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival. But Dave forgot to advertise. So Dave's play flopped. And Dave's cast didn't like that.

Help us to not be like Dave.

Risks & Challenges

The only risk involved with this production is going over budget (and it is a small budget.) But so far all of the unforeseen budgeting concerns have all been marketing related. 

Then again, there's always the concern of the cast killing each other over who gets top billing. But let me deal with that. You can help alleviate our primary risk by providing us with the capital needed to navigate the festival's vast marketing plain.

Other Ways You Can Help

Other than that, just help spread the word! Donation or not, we need all the help we can get letting folks know we're here and we're ready to entertain! So don't be stingy with that share link, or you'll end up like this guy.

Yeesh...

Almost two years ago I raised money so that I could produce my original play "Happy No Year," and thanks to the support of Indiegogo donors I was able to make that whodunit murder mystery dream a reality.
Part of that online campaign mentioned pushing this play forward into the Hollywood Fringe Festival that following summer. Well, I'm a year late but I am finally making that happen! And with the original cast agreeing to reprise their roles, this next run is destined for greatness! But now that I am in the heat of the preparation phase for the festival, I am getting a better understanding of what it is going to take to produce this and where I need funds to go.
  What We Need & What You GetI am raising $2000 to help cover the registration fee and the advertising. I didn't spend very much on advertising during this play's inaugural run because I didn't have  much competition around the holidays (except for The Nutcracker and ten versions of A Christmas Carol.) But when it comes to the Fringe Festival, advertising is everything. I have to let theatre goers know about my play in a sea of shows or no one will know it exists- flyers, banners, online ads - all are vital to make this run successful, and the cost adds up quickly. Yes yes, the goodies - in exchange for supporting this noble cause, I can provide tickets to the show for those who are local, and fun Fringe "toys" for you out-of-towners like Fringe buttons and ornaments.The ImpactThe truth is, one way or another, Happy No Year will be in this year's Fringe 
Festival. However, if our goal is not met, it will be a fruitless and 
low attended run. I have a friend here who will help explain what your impact will mean to us. This is  Dave.

Dave produced a play in the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival. But Dave forgot to advertise. So Dave's play flopped. And Dave's cast didn't like that.

Help us to not be like Dave. 
  Risks & ChallengesThe only risk involved with this production is going over budget (and it is a small budget.) But so far all of the unforeseen budgeting concerns have all been marketing related.  Then again, there's always the concern of the cast killing each other over who gets top billing. But let me deal with that. You can help alleviate our primary risk by providing us with the capital needed to navigate the festival's vast marketing plain.
  Other Ways You Can HelpOther than that, just help spread the word! Donation or not, we need all the help we can get letting folks know we're here and we're ready to entertain! So don't be stingy with that share link, or you'll end up like this guy.Yeesh...

story:
Bullet point break down:

Who we are: We are a group of young professional theatre artists seeking to bring Canadian work to the British fringe circuit.

The Project: Tuesdays and Sundays is a darkly poignant narrative inspired by Canada's eastern culture.

Why we need you: We're looking to break even while paying our creatives a living fee. Fringe festivals demand substantial startup funding before anything is recouped from the box office.

Check out our website for more information!

The Hard Details:

Who we are: We are a collection of young professional theatre artists who are deeply passionate about bringing Canadian work to the UK and Europe. We believe in bringing together cultures from both sides of the pond to explore our shared heritage, and our collective future. The founding members of Theatrum Veritatus hope to bring "Tuesdays and Sundays" to the Brighton Fringe.

The Project: Put together in September 2014, this production has at its roots the desire to question and explore the roles of gender by looking back to what was once perceived as the norm. What are our responsibilities as different genders in a relationship? How can we expose and challenge the gender politics of our own society by looking to the past? "Tuesdays and Sundays" invites its audience to confront some of our most basic assumptions about relationships, and shows us the darker and more complex facets of love.

 "Tuesdays and Sundays" was written by celebrated Canadian playwrights Medina Hahn and Daniel Arnold, and is based on a true story.

Why we need your help: Festivals and venues are becoming increasingly expensive and for start up companies like us who are self funded it is very hard to get projects up and running. As arts funding has been cut and there is more competition is out there, it is really important for creatives like us to seek alternative forms of funding and crowd funding is one of our best options. It's also a great way for us to thank you directly for your contributions.

Your donation would be helping us cover costs to produce the show. The main cost for the show is venue hire with secondary costs relating transport, expenses, rights and royalties. As a non-profit venture we are hoping break even and to pay the small fee for the creatives to thank them for their hard work and dedication.

Any additional funds will be rolled over onto our fundraising for the Camden Fringe.

Every little bit counts are we are very grateful for any help that you can extend our way!

story:
Short Summary


Hi!
My name is Patrick Barry, AKA Patch, and together with Greg, Emily, Marie, Nessy and Georgia, we are the cast and team of Cutting Edge's, offering at the 2015 Ventnor Fringe which we will be perfroming from the 13th to the 16th of August (for more on the Fringe visit http://ventnorexchange.co.uk/vfringe).
We are presenting two shows: 'Condensed Histories: Highwayman, Jugglers and Fools', a one-man comedy show written and performed by Greg, and 'The Hanged Man', a six-hander play written by myself. The 'Condensed Histories' production is fully financed and will not be receiving any direct funding from this project, although all of the advertising materials will be promoting both shows.

'The Hanged Man' has never been performed before, so I guess you might say the Fringe performance is the world premier! The production's potential is entirely unexplored but given our enthusiasm, The West End, Broadway, and Hollywood might yet see it produced - who knows!!! We certainly intend to take it on tour when and where ever we can after a successful run at the fringe. 

'The Hanged Man' is a black comedy focusing on a married couple who love each other but have lost their spark and are on the cusp of a potentially devastating phase in their lives. The husband sustains his contented existence by shirking the responsibility of real life and any meaningful relationship with his wife and children. His wife, recognising domestication and marriage has devolved her personality and potential into something far inferior to her aspirations, knows things can only get worse unless things change... It is on this brink that we meet two mystical beings determined to witness the married couples recognition of failure, Are the Mystical beings benign, or does their lurking cover something more sinister?  


Producing 'The Hanged Man' is a first for Cutting Edge, stepping out to produce a show under our own banner. We started out as (and remain) a community group focused on the art of Stage Fighting, Over the last ten years we have supported many local theatre companies (It really is surprising just how many pantomimes, Shakespeare plays, and other historical dramas are produced on the island!) with fight choreography and sourcing of props and equipment, 

A fight rehearsal for Island Savoyard's production of Pirates of Penzance.  

Adlib's and Vectis Ventures, production of Robin Hood at Robin Hill.

We now believe it is time for us to take the plunge and invest in the stage-weapons that we usually source from elsewhere, this will enable our community group to revamp the level of service and equipment we can offer, as well as allowing us to produce more shows under our own Cutting Edge name, and provide excellently entertaining, swashbuckling shows and events!! 


Patrick Barry

I like sword fighting, I can’t deny it; I like theatre with drama, humour, and action, and I also like supporting The Ventnor Fringe. This will be the fourth year I have performed there and the second year performing a piece written by me... The first being The Return of the Musketeers, a grand Swashbuckler following (yes, you have guessed)  the adventures of Dumas’s greatest heroes, D’Artagnan, Porthos, Aramis and Athos (and of course that most auspicious hero – Captain De’Treville, played by Greg!! Not forgetting our heroines and villainesses played by Emily and Nessy!!!).  

'The Hanged Man', is not a costume drama – it is set in the modern day, it’s not an all action adrenalin pulsating seat of the pants piece instead I might describe it as a quirky look at a marriage on the brink of sinking (Titanic like). Greg’s take might be slightly different to mine... 

But no play of mine would be complete without the sword-fighting I so love!!! And 'The Hanged Man'? Well, that is no different. 'The Hanged Man' has a sword fight that is integral to the plot, or, to be more precise, it has a three way light sabre duel, that needs to look absolutely awesome and only the best Battle-Ready Light Sabres will inspire the impact the audience deserve... 

Greg Chapman, Condensed Histories: 


What struck me when I first read The Hanged Man script was the way it shows the importance of the smallest of actions, the way that those actions might be examined and judged worthy of interest to supreme powers...   

Ok, slight lie. The first thing that struck me was the epic potential for a three way lightsaber battle choreographed by Patrick. Then the metaphysical stuff. 

What made me say yes to the project was a combination of Patch being at the helm, and the fact that the script manages to deal with some deep issues with sincerity and comic dark undertone that flows throughout the whole play. It is often hard to keep the balance of those two things, either becoming morbid and deep, or going for the laughs and forgetting the sincerity, fortunately the script perfectly balances the two on this knife-edge. (Or should I say lightsaber edge... Do lightsabers even have edges?) Our job now is to carry this balance into the performance!"


Nessy Warry
I (Patrick) am very pleased to say that our show has Nessy involved, she will be playing the part of one of the Mystical Beings - she missed out on the sword play last year but in this production she will not be missing any of the fun as she is one of the protagonists in the Light Sabre duel. Nessy is an incredibly talented performer, her physical prowess far exceeds mine and I expect to see great things in the duel consequently. 

Nessy Warry, is a internationally trained dancer and burlesque performer, currently studying at the Institute of the Arts Barcelona. She is home over summer to continue performing and pursue her passion in acting. Nessy's hobbies include aerial silks and being an illusionist assistant. She has also acted amongst various island groups in local productions.


What We Need & What You Get

So why do we need your help?

Advertising is a biggy, the better our advertising campaign the greater our potential for attracting sell-out audiences. And that after-all, is what it is all about - our audience!! Our ideal budget for an advertising campaign, inclusive of posters, flyers, programs and distribution will be about £390.

The next big expense will be props and effects. We actually have a lot of the required props already but we are lacking three light sabres – yes, that is the right, the shiny, bright sticks the Jedi and Sith hit each other with!!! The final scene of The Hanged Man has a three way light sabre duel which will be complimented best by the use of three Battle Ready light sabres with a full sound and LED lighting rig. We feel these sabres are the ones to be used as they are powerful enough to be heard throughout the auditorium and bright enough to light the entire stage with their glow – we want the audience to be wowed and leave the theatre wanting more awesomeness!!! We reckon the three lightsabres we really want will cost approximately £800. Unfortunately the mass produced lightsabres, are not battle ready and will not offer the durability we require for the duels. We do have a second choice of lightsabers which will allow us to do almost everything we want, and it is these that are covered with the advertising in the £1100. If we reach our goal we can get those, and will look to the stretch goal or other funding to see if we can get the best quality ones we are aiming for.

The rest of the money will be used to cover shipping and fees.

£1100 is our prime goal, with that budget we can produce an excellent show but will need to compromise and reduce our advertising budget to its minimum and reduce our favoured light sabres for those that are still battle ready but without the full sound or lighting options. 
  
£1500, is our stretch goal, with that we need not compromise on anything, we can purchase the best light sabres and ensure maximum publicity for the show!!

That said if we exceed our budget requirements you can be assured every penny will go into producing the show and making this Crowd Funder a success.  

You may wonder what we intend to do with these lightsaber said following the run at the Fringe. For starters we are hoping to put the play on again at further venues in 2016.

Also, as Greg already runs a series of videos with his Condensed Histories, he and Patch are planning to create a series of videos available free on YouTube under the 'Cutting Edge' banner, aimed at explaining some basics of stage combat, and taking some techniques of old sword and fencing masters and applying these to the lightsaber!

The Impact

The Hanged Man, will be the first time Cutting Edge, has produced a play. Although Cutting Edge has been involved with numerous local productions, it has done so to support another established company with its fight choreography and sourcing of equipment and props...

Cutting Edge, to date has helped out with:
The Thieves of Malmby Hall (Adlib)
Treasure Island (Adlib)
Blackgang Pirates (Vectis Ventures)
Robin Hood (Adlib & Vectis Ventures)
NIght Watch (Adlib)
Sleeping Beauty (Wight Strollers)
Pirates of Penzance (Island Savoyards)
The Merry Wives of Windsor (Arreton Players)
Merchant of Venice (Apollo Theatre)
Robinson Crusoe (Wight Strollers)
The Comedy of Errors (Arreton Players)
The Tempest (Apollo Theatre)
The Herbal Bed (Apollo Theatre)
The Return of the Musketeers (Adlib)
Henry IV (IOW Shakespeare Company)
Various Workshops for Vectis Ventures and Island Schools.


Helping Cutting Edge deliver on this production will aid our long term plan to improve the equipment and services we offer to local performance groups. It will also extend the range of workshops we can offer schools and other groups, All people need to enjoy exercising the mind and the body and in my opinion helping people to understand a script and choreograph the fight that best complements the characters and needs of the scene is the perfect symbiotic relationship.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are minimal. All the Perks have been carefully calculated to be self sustaining and provide the production budget. The show has been booked into the Ventnor Fringe Roster, the cast has been chosen. The show will happen no matter what. The true challenge is the fight choreography, sourcing Light Sabres that are capable of taking the punishment during each show and rehearsal they are used.  

I do not want to compromise on the impact the final scene could offer to it's audience, Getting the best LightSabres available might make the difference between watching something that is fun, or something that is fun and powerful in its authenticity!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools and let people know on Facebook and Twitter! My cast are awesome and the play isn't too bad either!

    We would like to our first impact on the audience to be just as good as our last!! And that's all there is to it.

story:
Lovesick ~ the cat allergy musical, written by Pamela Holm, with songs by Jim Fourniadis, is a comedic musical romp through the world of online dating. While Serenity mines the internet looking for her soulmate, Lucky, her cat, does everything in his power, including dander, gaydar and physical restraint, to secure his position as the alpha male of the household. When the struggle between woman and beast escalates, Serenity is forced to take drastic measures…

Your kind contributions will go toward stipends for the actors and musicians, because we strongly believe that artists deserve to be compensated for their time and talent. 

You can also support us by buying tickets to the show :)

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2774508

 

Starring:

Steffanos X  - Tom Jonesing

Robin Coomer - Loopstation and Birdsaw

Flash Hopkins - Flash

Mikl M

Kate Gibson

Lily Marcheschi

Michael Cai

 

Band:

Dean Mermell - Tom Jonesing 

Phil Clevenger - Squirellex, DIN

Matt Bertken

Jim Fourniadis - Rats of Unusual Size, Darkroom Theater

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Tess Holbrook. I have been working in theatre, specifically with Shakespeare plays, for ten years. Macbeth has certainly become one of my favorite plays for its thrilling observation of the human mind and soul. Most of my work has been through the delightful acting camp: Get Thee To The Funnery! (I'm the one in the hat)
  • I've decided to take this excellent script and switch the genders of each character. In this day in age we have been switching the lead characters, but I wanted to take it a step further and switch ALL the characters. I think this will be the first in a long line of changes we will be seeing in the future when it comes to gender identification.
  • The play will be performed at the amazing Off Center theatre in Burlington Vermont. Which I have worked with many times in the past couple years. We will have minimal set decorations and props so we can focus primarily on the performance. That being said we will need a lot of help paying for the theatre and rehearsal space. Without your donations we wont be able to pay for these spaces.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are trying to raise $2100. That is the minimum we need to pull off this play. Each dollar will go to an important facet of the production. Here is a screen shot of our budget.
  • For you help we'll be giving out: Shout outs on social media, signed poster by the cast, viewing of dress rehearsal, and a thank you in the program!!!
  • If we don't reach our goal we will put what we do raise toward the play and will find other ways to fund the production.

The Impact

I think because this play deals with a gender-less concept, it is the perfect platform to switch genders of all the characters. All the males will be female and played by women and all the females will be male and be played by men. Except the children will be gender-less. I wont be changing anything in the play except the gender roles. So whatever stereotypes the audience sees in the play will be their own perception of gender. I believe we are entering a new era where many of today's youth no longer identify as she or him, but instead they, them.

            I hope this production is a thrill and thought provoking. I think there is so much within the text to play with, and with this twist in casting I think we will be able to delve into new depths of the human mind. I’m excited to see what we create, I’m positive it will be a joy for everyone involved and a treat to the audiences.

Risks & Challenges

  • The only risk is that we don't perform! Which will only happen if we have to cut rehearsals and the venue. 
  • I don't believe it will come to that though. There are plenty of free spaces we can rehearse at. And many arms we can twist to help pay those final venue fees.
Other Ways You Can Help
  • POST THIS EVERYWHERE!!! 
  • COME TO THE PLAY!! MARCH 9th-12th
  • TELL YOUR FRIENDS!
  • Indiegogo share tools!

Love! Tess Holbrook
story_txt:
Short Summary


My name is Tess Holbrook. I have been working in theatre, specifically with Shakespeare plays, for ten years. Macbeth has certainly become one of my favorite plays for its thrilling observation of the human mind and soul. Most of my work has been through the delightful acting camp: Get Thee To The Funnery! (I'm the one in the hat)
I've decided to take this excellent script and switch the genders of each character. In this day in age we have been switching the lead characters, but I wanted to take it a step further and switch ALL the characters. I think this will be the first in a long line of changes we will be seeing in the future when it comes to gender identification.
The play will be performed at the amazing Off Center theatre in Burlington Vermont. Which I have worked with many times in the past couple years. We will have minimal set decorations and props so we can focus primarily on the performance. That being said we will need a lot of help paying for the theatre and rehearsal space. Without your donations we wont be able to pay for these spaces.


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $2100. That is the minimum we need to pull off this play. Each dollar will go to an important facet of the production. Here is a screen shot of our budget.

For you help we'll be giving out: Shout outs on social media, signed poster by the cast, viewing of dress rehearsal, and a thank you in the program!!!
If we don't reach our goal we will put what we do raise toward the play and will find other ways to fund the production.


The Impact
I think because this play deals with a gender-less concept, it is the perfect platform to switch genders of all the characters. All the males will be female and played by women and all the females will be male and be played by men. Except the children will be gender-less. I wont be changing anything in the play except the gender roles. So whatever stereotypes the audience sees in the play will be their own perception of gender. I believe we are entering a new era where many of today's youth no longer identify as she or him, but instead they, them.
            I hope this production is a thrill and thought provoking. I think there is so much within the text to play with, and with this twist in casting I think we will be able to delve into new depths of the human mind. I’m excited to see what we create, I’m positive it will be a joy for everyone involved and a treat to the audiences.

Risks & Challenges

The only risk is that we don't perform! Which will only happen if we have to cut rehearsals and the venue. 
I don't believe it will come to that though. There are plenty of free spaces we can rehearse at. And many arms we can twist to help pay those final venue fees.


Other Ways You Can Help
POST THIS EVERYWHERE!!! 
COME TO THE PLAY!! MARCH 9th-12th
TELL YOUR FRIENDS!
Indiegogo share tools!

Love! Tess Holbrook

story:
The Call For Creativity

Despite our current political climate, theatre artists are determined to continue creating art and sharing important stories. Now, more than ever, is the time to step forward and support women in the theatre industry and projects about women’s issues. THML Theatre Company and IN OUR WORDS have chosen to team up to bring a production of Cagebirds by David Campton to New York City as a response to these shifts in our political and social environment.

About the Show

Our creative team has chosen to take this play in a very realistic and sobering direction- our setting will be in a Center for Troubled Women, hearkening back to the days when women were sent to psychiatric wards for “female ailments” like hysteria. The year is 2020, three years into the new presidential administration. Cagebirds will explore the narratives of the women in the center as they encounter a new addition to the group. This will be an intentional and intersectional all-female cast. We are creating characters that are immigrants, Muslims, Jews, transgender women, southern belles, curvy women, women of color, and women battling mental illness. Our production will tell stories- women’s stories. Current issues. Corrupt, manipulative leadership. Fear. Hate. Gossip. Vanity. Freedom. It is all packed into this one hour show. We are confident that Cagebirds will impact the community we serve here in New York City.

About THML

THML is a new theatre company in New York City dedicated to engaging audiences with stories of women who survive and thrive. Tahamul is a word in Arabic and Farsi which translates, “to endure,” or “to bear the burden.” The Arabic letters which form this word are ta, ha, miim, and laam (THML). Kayla Friend, the founder of THML and director of Cagebirds, created the company out of her desire to see disenfranchised women of all backgrounds empowered through the arts. Her aim is to engage, to invade comfortable spaces, and to change lives by changing the conversation through performance. 

Our Partnership

THML is delighted to partner with IN OUR WORDS for this particular project. IN OUR WORDS is a project under the non-profit, Fractured Atlas. Alan Bounville, the founder of IN OUR WORDS, has been working with playwrights and actors on new, edgy, and engaging pieces of theatre in New York City since 2013. The mission of IN OUR WORDS is to “positively transform lives and communities…by sharing the words of real people and by helping to advance progressive social change agendas.” IN OUR WORDS decided to partner with THML for the production of Cagebirds because of its content and intention- to positively transform lives and help advance progressive social change agendas. Fifteen percent of every ticket sale for our production will be donated to a local organization that has boots on the ground, in the thick of creating social change and responding to community needs. Our current partnering organizations for educational talkback nights are Let My People Go, The National Organization for Victim Assistance, The Arab American Association of New York, and The New York Anti-Violence Project.

Our Goals

Our fundraising goal for this project is $13,000.00. These funds will enable us to secure our venue, pay a stipend to our actors and production team, build our set pieces, purchase and assemble our costumes, pay for the rights to the material, and rent our rehearsal spaces. We aim to reduce the costs wherever possible; we will be rehearsing in a donated space at least once a week throughout the production process. Because of our partnership with IN OUR WORDS, all of our funds will be raised through crowdsourcing and private donations. All donations made through IN OUR WORDS will be processed through Fractured Atlas and will be tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We began fundraising January 15th, 2017 and we were able to raise $2,000 in just under three weeks simply by reaching out to friends and family. This first benchmark helped us secure our venue for the production and pay for the rights to the material. THML and IN OUR WORDS is seeking partnership through individuals like you and the companies that you represent to make this production happen. Independent productions such as these require a great amount of sacrifice and effort for everyone involved; they are truly a labor of love. We do not anticipate making any profit off of this production- we to see this piece as an investment in our community and an opportunity to publicly empower women of all shapes, sizes, colors, and creeds within the arts. Cagebirds is a chance to give back and invest in the people of New York City.

 

Theatre has the power to transform lives. Theatre can challenge the status quo. Theatre can amplify voices that are brushed aside in our mainstream social discourse. THML and IN OUR WORDS aspire to present work that elevates narratives often forgotten or ignored by broader culture. We realize that funding for this type of work is sparse today; this is why we need your partnership. Our team seeks to use theatre as a transformative tool in our community. If you feel as we do, that is our job to elevate the narratives of the oppressed and underrepresented, then we invite you to partner with us on this project by donating. Help us be a part of the change that we seek.

 

If you have any questions regarding partnership, please do not hesitate to contact us using the information below. We look forward to partnering with you on this project. Thank you.

story:
The Company...

The New Natives is an emerging New York City-based theatre company which focuses on producing new work by emerging artists.  Formed by Charly Clive and Jillian Geurts in 2015, The New Natives believes in making theatre for the people… contemporary, thought-provoking work that's funny, sad and everything in between - work that challenges audiences and is accessible to all! 

In September 2016, The New Natives premiered their inaugural work 'The First Man' in a sell-out downtown run in New York's Under St Mark's Theatre. The New Natives are excited to return with their second New York production, 'Camel'.


The Play...

In a small town in suburban America, a town in Virginia, a town with no quarry, Gus Steinem is experiencing loss for the first time. It's been a week since his long estranged high school love, Louie was found dead and even though he hasn't seen her for years, suddenly she's everywhere.  Camel is a dark comedy about lost love, definite loss and marijuana. 
 

Who We Are...

We are a small group of in-demand American and International artists.

Charly Clive - writer

Charly is an English/American playwright who has lived in New York for the last four years. During her time there she has been fortunate enough to have her US writing debut with the play 'On Prosperity' as well as work as Associate Playwright on Douglas Carter-Beane's 'Shows For Days' at The Lincoln Center. Winner of the Breaking Ground award for new writing at the Origin Theatre Company for her comedy 'Safety Dance', Charly also co-wrote the sketch show 'What's Your Fracking Problem?' which premiered in Brooklyn, New York and was a benefit in aid of The Pituitary Foundation. Most recently, Charly was the co-writer of the award winning, sell out show 'Britney' at The Edinburgh Fringe Festival and London VAULT festival. 

Michael Bradshaw Flynn - director

Michael Bradshaw Flynn is the founder and producing artistic director for The Scranton Shakespeare Festival. Michael can also be found associate directing for Broadway legend Jack O’ Brien on projects like the starry, Broadway satire, 'It’s Only A Play' and 'The Front Page' revival, produced by Scott Rudin. Michael assisted Broadway and Television Director, Scott Ellis on his new play 'DADA WOOF PAPA HOT' and has worked alongside Broadway and Hollywood writer Douglas Carter Beane. 

Our four actors are Jillian Geurts, Anthony Severance, Joel Brady and Karen Johal. They are all graduates of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts and are working across the board in theatre, film and TV.  
 

The Budget...

We have managed to secure roughly half of our budget through private investment and are trying to raise the other half through this campaign.  We appreciate any donation that will help get us over the line. Thank you!

Creative's Fees: $2000.00
Artists Fees: $2000.00
Props, sets & costumes: $700.00
Insurance: $200.00
Marketing and Media: $700.00
Indiegogo Fees: $300.00
Rehearsal Space: In Kind (donated by The American Academy of Dramatic Arts)
Miscellaneous Equipment, Production and Ticketing: $500.00
Venue: $250.00 (this is a co-production with HorseTrade and this is a small fee for incidentals)

 

Your Help...

No donation or act of support is too small! 

Supporting 'Camel' and helping us meet our goal will mean we can create a show of the highest quality.  A show that we believe audiences should see. Your donations will mean we can pay our team of actors and creatives for all their hard work.  As detailed in the budget above, no one is receiving a huge amount of money for their time, but everyone involved is passionate about this project and truly committed to creating something great. 

All donations are greatly appreciated and we have some great perks that we hope you'll enjoy!

In the event that your wish to contribute via cheque or cash please email info@thenewnatives.net for more information.

If you’re not able to donate but still want to show your support...we would really appreciate your help with spreading the word about this campaign and about 'Camel'! You can follow and share our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pages and stay updated as the production develops.

story:
Short Summary

We're a not-for-profit theatre company whose main focus is to engage and educate through the arts. We focus on both the positive and negative impacts of historical figures and events in order to promote critical thought on history within our audiences, with a fun musical twist!

What We Need & What You Get

Your funding would go towards artist fees and production costs for any of our three major projects we're looking at doing for 2016: the eastern Ontario School Tour, our summer outdoor theatre show, or historical residencies in which we inhabit and re-animate a historic building! All of these projects promote and encourage community engagement through the arts. Our work has been given much acclaim, including positive reviews, testimonials, and feedback from past audiences. We hope to continue to bring our historical, musical-comedy style of performance to audiences once again in 2016, but can only do so with your support!

The Impact

This will be the 5th summer of our outdoor show, which was rated as the #1 tour/attraction for Kingston on TripAdvisor this past summer. Bringing the show back will continue to animate Kingston's downtown core, benefiting the summer tourist season and students in camps. We have also completed 3 highly successful cross-Canadian tours, and cannot wait to bring our performances to a local audience so local schools can experience professional productions that have been developed and presented across the country. The residencies will help highlight and restore importance to historic buildings in both Ontario and across Canada, helping communities engage with their past and bring it to life again. These projects will span across a great number of communities and will help bring learning through the arts to the forefront of 2016!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share on your social media platforms, check out our website or Youtube channel, and use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out so we can bring a great year of programming to Kingston, Ontario and Canada!

story:
Charity Zombies?!

The Otley Zombie Apocalypse (OZA) will rise again on the Saturday 13th August 2016.

Each year this unique event, organised and performed entirely by a dedicated team of volunteers, take over the small market town of Otley, in West Yorkshire, to raise funds for a local charity.

In 2015 the event almost sold out and raised over £3000 for our chosen charity, Martins House Children's Hospice:

Unfortunately, even with our dedicated team of volunteers, running an event like this still costs money, with insurance costs, costumes, props, make-up supplies and health and safety equipment all eating into the final total that we can give to our chosen charity.

How Can You Help.

Last year, our running costs came to more than £600, and that had to be paid from ticket sales and a couple of small local sponsors. This year we're going to try to organise a bigger and better event and we need your help to fund us so that ALL our profits from ticket sales can go to charity:

You can donate from as little as £1 up to £500 and in return you'll get some exclusive OZA2016 perks, including, Wristbands, T-shirts, personal zombie experiences and VIP event tickets.

Available Perks

£1 - Karma Zombieleon
You give us a pound, we give you a virtual hug.
£2 - In Memorium
Have your name listed as one of the kind sponsors that donated to  unfortunate souls that perished during the 2016 apocalypse

£3 - I'm a Survivor 
Show you have the will to survive with our exclusive glow in the dark "SURVIVOR" wristband.


£3 - Argh!! They Got Me.
Don't think you'll make it? show them you are proud to be one of the hoard with our exclusive "INFECTED" wristband.

Or..  get both wristbands as twin pack for only £5.
£7 - Satchel of the Dead

New for 2016, our exclusive OZA rucksacks are perfect for carrying all your essential supplies when the apocalypse comes. Embroidered with the Otley Zombie Apocalypse 2016 logo, each rucksack has a 10 litre zipped main storage compartment and a smaller zipped pocket. and fully adjustable strap.


£15 - Bite Me T-shirts

New for this year, our 2016 t-shirts, featuring our "BITE ME!" slogan on the front and the official sponsor and OZA2016 logo on the back.

£25 - Bite Me Hoodie

This years Hoodie has the "BITE ME!!!" slogan on the front and the OZA 2016 logo and the official sponsor on the back

£30 - Otley Zombie Apocalypse Hoodie

Back by popular demand, our official OZA hoodie features a discreet Otley Zombie Apocalypse 2016 logo on the front and is plain on the back

£60 - V.I.P. - Very Important Player

Get the full VIP experience this year,  you'll play the game in the penultimate slot, (just as it starts to get dark), we'll also include a wristband and t-shirt, a Zombie cocktail waiting for you when you arrive at the end zone and an exclusive photo with our most ferocious zombies. 

£200 - Zom-Air

Take to the skies to avoid the Zombie hoard. Choose this perk and you'll get one of only 2 Zombie Airways T-shirts, a meet and greet with some of our zombies and an hour long pleasure flight over the Vale of York and beyond.

£400 - V.I.T. - Very Important Team

Get the full VIP experience for your whole team this year,  you'll play the game in the FINAL slot on game night, (just as it starts to get dark), we'll also include a wristband and t-shirt for all 8 members of your team, a Zombie cocktail waiting for each of you when you arrive at the end zone, an exclusive photo with our most ferocious zombies.  AND... an exclusive extra game zone just for your team.

Questions?

Have any questions about the perks above,  do you want to know more details about a perk, or even if you just want to know what our pilot had for lunch. Simply drop us a line at OtleyZombies@gmail.com or send a message to our Facebook page and we'll get back to you as soon as possible.

Your Impact

The Otley Zombie Apocalypse is a non-profit event run by volunteers,  by donating you will be:

  • Helping us to pay the increasing insurance costs, medical support and health and safety equipment hire.
  • Helping our team invest in better props and make-up to make our event more immersive and an overall better experience for the game players.
  • And MOST IMPORTANTLY...
  • Helping to ensure that EVERY SINGLE penny we raise during the event will be direct to our local charity

Who/What is your preferred charity this year

This year, we are raising money for TWO local charitable causes.

1) The Otley Defibrillators - These public access defibrillators are a necessity in emergency first aid in suspected cardiac arrest and increase survival chances by over 70%. The goal is to have emergency defibrillators covering every area of Otley.

2) Otley Flood Support - 100s of families were affected by the 2015 Boxing Day floods, dozens of homes and the local park were badly damaged. Families have lost carpets, furniture, and personal items and are still struggling to rebuild their lives. Hopefully OZA16 can help too.

Other Ways You Can Help

So, you might not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Give us a share on Facebook or Twitter or by using one of the many share tools on this page.
  • Wanna get hands on? Drop us a line at otleyzombies@gmail.com we always welcome people who want be a zombie, do a bit of acting, or just help us to run a safe and fun event

Thank you for your time.

This years Hoodie has the "BITE ME!!!" slogan on the front and the OZA 2016 logo and the official sponsor on the back

£30 - Otley Zombie Apocalypse Hoodie
Back by popular demand, our official OZA hoodie features a discreet Otley Zombie Apocalypse 2016 logo on the front and is plain on the back
£60 - V.I.P. - Very Important Player
Get the full VIP experience this year,  you'll play the game in the penultimate slot, (just as it starts to get dark), we'll also include a wristband and t-shirt, a Zombie cocktail waiting for you when you arrive at the end zone and an exclusive photo with our most ferocious zombies. 

£200 - Zom-Air

Take to the skies to avoid the Zombie hoard. Choose this perk and you'll get one of only 2 Zombie Airways T-shirts, a meet and greet with some of our zombies and an hour long pleasure flight over the Vale of York and beyond.


£400 - V.I.T. - Very Important Team
Get the full VIP experience for your whole team this year,  you'll play the game in the FINAL slot on game night, (just as it starts to get dark), we'll also include a wristband and t-shirt for all 8 members of your team, a Zombie cocktail waiting for each of you when you arrive at the end zone, an exclusive photo with our most ferocious zombies.  AND... an exclusive extra game zone just for your team.
Questions?
Have any questions about the perks above,  do you want to know more details about a perk, or even if you just want to know what our pilot had for lunch. Simply drop us a line at OtleyZombies@gmail.com or send a message to our Facebook page and we'll get back to you as soon as possible.
Your Impact
 The Otley Zombie Apocalypse is a non-profit event run by volunteers,  by donating you will be:  Helping us to pay the increasing insurance costs, medical support and health and safety equipment hire.
Helping our team invest in better props and make-up to make our event more immersive and an overall better experience for the game players. And MOST IMPORTANTLY...
Helping to ensure that EVERY SINGLE penny we raise during the event will be direct to our local charity    Who/What is your preferred charity this year This year, we are raising money for TWO local charitable causes.
1) The Otley Defibrillators - These public access defibrillators are a necessity in emergency first aid in suspected cardiac arrest and increase survival chances by over 70%. The goal is to have emergency defibrillators covering every area of Otley.
2) Otley Flood Support - 100s of families were affected by the 2015 Boxing Day floods, dozens of homes and the local park were badly damaged. Families have lost carpets, furniture, and personal items and are still struggling to rebuild their lives. Hopefully OZA16 can help too.
    Other Ways You Can Help So, you might not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  Give us a share on Facebook or Twitter or by using one of the many share tools on this page. Wanna get hands on? Drop us a line at otleyzombies@gmail.com we always welcome people who want be a zombie, do a bit of acting, or just help us to run a safe and fun event   Thank you for your time.

story:
Short Summary


Note: small amounts are more than welcome. No need to pick a 'perk'!!

'La Compania Paradeo''s founders Pieter Nooten and Miryam La Lucha bring together various artists from different disciplines fusing traditional flamenco with contemporary dance and electronic, neo-classical and ambient music, poetry and cutting edge video art.

'The Parpadeo Project' seeks to communicate an uncompromisingly unique fusion of all performing art forms. We aim to cross over between the old and new – and utilizing themes or concepts to bring them together into an authentic, elegantly minimalist, technically accomplished but above all emotionally overwhelming performance.

"...Based on the poetry of acclaimed young Spanish poet Lilián Pallares 'Parpadeo' will convey us on a profound and electrifying journey through the landscape of human emotions, the telluric, disquieting and profound..."

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to rent rehearsal rooms, buy costumes and re-mix and master our music.
  • Contributors can order a cd of our music or a DVD of the whole show, which will be performed during the Flamenco Bienalle, february 2017. 
  • Small contributions are more then welcome!

story:
Hello,

WE are stronger believers that the arts are not only a way of expressing your feelings, I believe that if you are passionate about dance in all of the different disciplines, music, acting and you have the talent and the passion you SHOULD be able to have the chance to receive the training and education so you can follow your dream and be able to work on this field.

This is the exact reason why we started this project. In my country we have great talent, but we do not have a full education in performance arts, which is why the dancers can not make a career out of what they love.

Here in Nicaragua, we do not have much teachers with global tendencies, and the academies where we can find up to date dance techniques are very expensive for the majority of the aspiring artists here in Nicaragua.

Last year we were able to see perform a group of professional dancers from TROPICANA CABARET FROM CUBA and we started a friendship with them, and we decided that one day we were going to give the chance to let young artists from my country to be trained by one of those dancers.

That day came and we decided to sell our business,  and we started to negotiate with one of the best dancers from Tropicana who is also a professor  to come and train a few dancers, so we donated all our money on this project, we made auditions,  and announced that we were going to train them and be part of the first Cabaret Dance Company in Nicaragua, at the beginning no one understood us, but with time we started giving more information of the tendencies of the cabaret dances and the background of the Tropicana and the audition was a success, which we taped and a few professional nicaraguan dance teachers volunteer to help us picking the young artists, one of them his name is Christopher he is 17 years old he made a beautiful performance and in the interview he said, I quote " No parent want his kid to be a dancer", I asked why you think is that and he said I would never to be able to sustain myself as a dancer.

This confirmed our passion for the project, and we picked 12 kids, between the ages of 15 and 24 we even have one dancer who is almost 30 his name is Leonid, he said, I've always dreamed with being a student of an international professor. Allison, 15 years old, she started at 3 and went to the public school that had a little fee of the equivalent of US$5, she got a full scholarship because she couldn't afford that fee and she is an amazing dancer.

We were able with the funds we donated to pay for the flight ticket, housing food and classes for 45 days and put together a show we called "Noches de Cabaret" we made a deal with a medium size theater and presented the show, it was a success, the costumes weren't as good as I would like to but it was what we could afford, the kids said "It doesn't matter how our costumes are we will leave our hearts on the show", and they did, we taped it and we are working on a demo ourselves so we can get a few contracts so this artist can get financial income out of their dance.

In the process after getting to know the dancers and their lives we decided to not just make a CABARET DANCE COMPANY, we want to make this an educational project, of course we want them to be able to get financial income by dancing but this goes beyond that.

There is a long way to go, this can not stop here, we still need to train the dancers, there's a lot more to learn, and we literally ran out of money, we can't even afford a space to practice, a nicaraguan teacher said she could help us giving her knowledge and "cleaning"the choreography if we can only give her transportation and of curse a space to practice.

This young artists deserve the opportunity to get the best education they can get, I know dancers from other countries who could come and train them but we don't even have the funds to practice what we already paid for.

To be able to pay a full year of training, renting a space for practice, giving the kids a little financial help for transportation (since their houses are in the outside of the city at very poor neighborhoods), adding details for the costumes to make them better, financial help for the nicaraguan professor, shoes for the dancers we need US $10800 exactly. I know is a lot of money but I know they worth it, and we are working hard to become self sustainable, in t he future we want this artists to give classes and train future generations of dancers in Nicaragua.

I can not imagine a world without the arts, especially DANCE, I understand is a lot of money, if one of you can not help us with money, there are OTHER WAYS to support us, by spreading the word, INDIEGOGO have share options, or making little donations. Please help us, this is a beautiful project, we can send all the information you require and we can backup every dollar you send us and give you prove that the money you give us goes 100% to the project.

story:
WHO WE ARE

This little experiment is the brainchild of the four of us, Erin, Molly, Maya and Sofia, working together to create dance! Our collaborative project is hopefully the first of many to come where we, as choreographers, come together with members of the communities we exist in to make ~dance~ happen.

For those who don’t know us (and those that do), we’re a group of recently-graduated twenty-somethings looking to make our dreams to dance a reality in our lives and the lives of others. The style is more ‘contemporary’ than ‘modern,’ where each of us work in distinctly unique and exciting ways to explore how our bodies can move.

Much love from each of us,
Erin, Maya, Molly & Sofia <3

OUR DANCERS

We are currently working with dancers around the greater Boston area that are enthusiastic about moving their bodies in cool and exciting ways and being apart of work that brings people from many walks of life together. We called at auditions for “some bold and brilliant art-making, dance-type folks” who would be “passionate and committed” to this project, and our call was answered. Dancers of all experience levels came to put themselves out there with us, and we are working with many of them to produce fantastic work that they should be very proud of. We need your help to bring these amazing pieces that deserve to be shared to the public!

WHY WE NEED YOU

As we prepare to present our work at the end of this summer, we ask for your help in making our dream of a first-time-ever-collaboration between the four of us and our dancers a reality. The time, energy, resources, and love that have gone into this project will surely prove to be worth it when it comes to fruition, and we appreciate any monetary support you can offer to make our ~dreams~ come true!

Monetary support will allow us to pay for:

Our performance venue, Green Street Studios in Cambridge

Costs of printing fliers, posters and programs

Rehearsal space rentals at the Dance Complex, Studio 550 & Green Street Studios

Providing costumes and needed support to our dancers

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Send an email to mayaszeigler@gmail.com if you would like to discuss contributing or supporting us in our future projects or would like to hear more!  If you would like to stay connected as we aspire to do future choreographic work, we encourage you to reach out personally in order to continue hearing about the dance and art we create. 

ADDITIONAL FUNDS ARE WELCOME!

Additional funds past our needed $1500 will allow us to continue doing work that we can be proud of. We are considering working on a dance film, or doing a fall dance show, or expanding our collaborations to include (and compensate!) other deserving and talented artists. We can dream bigger with your help!

 

Thank you!

story:
What's going on here?

Why BAE Theatre needs your help to produce Recent Tragic Events:

  • BAE Theatre is an LA-based independent theatre company run by Emily Keaney and Isabella Petrini. After a successful independent and Hollywood Fringe Festival run of Matt & Ben by Mindy Kaling and Brenda Withers, BAE Theatre is ready to produce their second production of 2016. 
  • As we approach the 15th anniversary of 9/11, BAE Theatre brings Recent Tragic Events by Craig Wright (Six Feet Under, Lost, and Greenleaf) to the stage, telling the story of four vastly different characters processing the recent attacks of September 11, 2001.
  • This dark comedy will not only have audiences  laughing when they least expect it but will question the idea of fate versus free will in their own lives, and just how much or how little they can do to change the course of history. Donate to this production and help BAE utilize the medium of theatre to tell a poignant, relevant story while simultaneously aiding victims of tragedy in dire need of support. See a spectacular show and help someone in need; what more could you ask for? 
  • Accessibility is key to the mission of BAE Theatre. The more money we raise, the more tickets we can provide for patrons that may not normally have the opportunity to attend theatrical productions. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Theatre is expensive; even established companies must rely on significant contributions from subscribers, donors, and consistent patrons. Our budget for Recent Tragic Events includes funds to finance venue rental, insurance, design team support, set- building, lighting, props, advertising, printing, and food for our cast and creative team. We are lucky to have access to rehearsal space provided by a generous supporter but there are many components of the production process that ticket sales alone cannot cover. We know we can do it with your help! The more we raise, the greater this production will be!
  • As is standard BAE Theatre fashion, we want to thank our donors with goodies ranging from tickets for exciting theatre around LA to posh stationery finds. Every donation above $10 will receive a handwritten thank-you in the mail.  Check out our other gifting levels to see even more sensational prizes. Every little bit counts; if everyone aware of this campaign donated, this production could go above and beyond its projected dynamic potential.

The Impact

  • What actions can be taken in the face of tragedy? How much control do we have over our own lives? BAE Theatre, as a company dedicated to creating meaningful discourse and critical thought, explores these questions by studying the themes of fate and free will.
  • The impact doesn't just stop at moving theatre. 10% of ticket sales from this production go towards The Red Cross, an organization dedicated to the continued support of disaster relief.
  • With two successful productions under our belts, BAE Theatre has already reached hundreds within the LA community. Help us maintain our progress and provide continually meaningful productions to a greater audience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't help financially but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Sharing is caring. Please share this campaign with anyone and everyone. This is not only an artistic mission, but a philanthropic cause devoted to helping those effected by catastrophe. Share it with theatre fans. Share it with anyone that has ever volunteered for The Red Cross. Share it with someone from New York. Share it with someone from the Twin Cities. You never know who's out there that might want to see this show. Repost the link to our campaign on Facebook. Email it to someone. Call your grandmother and tell her that you want to bring her to the show. 
  • We're always on the lookout for other goods and services necessary to enhance the quality of the show. We need resources for set building-- materials and master builders. It's always good to have a backup rehearsal space. We would love to partner with a restaurant to feed the production team or sponsor a fundraising event. We may be looking for specific props and borrowing costs less than renting or buying. Plus, your couch could be famous.
  • Come support us at the show! We can't wait to see you there. Of course you'll be getting all kinds of social media reminders but mark your calendar now and be sure to buy tickets as soon as they go live! 

Support Recent Tragic Events'  journey to the stage while giving back to a worthy cause.
