story:
The Restless Observers Theatre Project is a student led company in Logan, Utah. The five members vary in fields of theatrical study with members being involved in the Bachelor of Fine Arts in Acting, A Bachelor of Arts in Theatre, and Theatre Education. 

The process began six months ago when a member of our company, Brendon Henderson, read the play Slipping by Daniel Talbott. The play follows a teenager named Eli who moves from San Francisco to the middle of nowhere Iowa. Upon moving to Iowa, he meets a boy named Jake who once again opens him up to the idea of love again, an idea that had been shattered after an abusive relationship and the death of his father. We follow Eli on a tumultuous coming of age journey where he battles with discovering himself and with trusting other people. 

Brendon was drawn to the fact that the play touched on various themes that audiences could relate to. Themes such as not feeling good enough for people, feeling comfortable in your own skin, loving so much but not having them love back, and of course the danger of closeness and being swallowed by it.  He knew that it was a story that needed to be told, because it was powerful enough to expose people to a new way of thinking. However, he also realized that the play dealt with themes that were extremely controversial, especially for a Utah audience. He knew that the only way he would be able to get it produced would mean having to do propose something a little bit crazy... 

The only way to get the story told would be to pose the show as a "no conflict" to the University and to have it be completely student produced.

This means that nothing is provided to the students from the University except a location to put on the show, bare minimum furniture for a "set" and a few props. This has resulted in the creation of an extremely barebones theatre experience.   The cast will be on stage throughout the entire course of the play and will be extremely open with the audience. Costume changes will be made on the set, sets will be built using a few benches and black boxes, and the lighting will just be a simple dimmer switch. It is a huge undertaking as the five students have assumed the role of producer, marketer, actor, costume designer, lighting designer, set designer and director. 

With that being said we still need help! The money that you help us raise will go towards buying costumes, helping us secure the licensing rights and a house manager for our four day run (which is a necessity if we are to use the Black Box Theatre). The show is completely not for profit and the actors in the show are only being paid in experience. 

In a way of showing our extreme gratitude for your help in funding this experience we have a large variety of different packages available for sale ranging from $1-$300! The various packages include: 

$1 The Slight Stumble Package

$5 The Talbott Package 

$30 The Jan Package

$50 The Chris Package

$100 The Jake Package 

$200 The Eli Package

$300 The Slipping Package 

(More information can be found in the PERKS section) 

 

The reason for this project is simple and honest. Your donation will help with opening the door for creativity and growth of knowledge for not only us, but for the community that we are going to be sharing this story with. That's because Slipping is being independently produced by young aspiring actors who want to expose audiences to a different way of thinking and to push our limits and comfort zones as artists. 

 

With this being a student led project, there are many road blocks and obstacles that we have had to and that we are going to overcome. The main one right now being working without a budget. This is restricting us from securing the rights to the play, a house manager, and getting simple costumes for our characters. We also run the high risk of protest for this show, specifically because the lead characters are homosexual. If we let fear influence our decisions, however, we would have backed out long ago. All of us firmly believe that this is a beautiful look into the human mind and that it is a story that deserves to be told. Plus let's be honest...controversy adds a little bit of fun! 

 

Of course if you can't contribute to our play we could still use your support by having you join us on this journey!! 

  • Follow us on Facebook @ www.facebook.com/utahstateslipping 
  • Follow us on Instagram @therestlessobservers
  • Share this fundraising effort.
  • Tell your friends! Share the event! 
  • Email us at therestlessobservers.gmail.com if you have any suggestions for how you could help us and our process! We would love to hear from you.
story_txt:
The Restless Observers Theatre Project is a student led company in Logan, Utah. The five members vary in fields of theatrical study with members being involved in the Bachelor of Fine Arts in Acting, A Bachelor of Arts in Theatre, and Theatre Education. 
The process began six months ago when a member of our company, Brendon Henderson, read the play Slipping by Daniel Talbott. The play follows a teenager named Eli who moves from San Francisco to the middle of nowhere Iowa. Upon moving to Iowa, he meets a boy named Jake who once again opens him up to the idea of love again, an idea that had been shattered after an abusive relationship and the death of his father. We follow Eli on a tumultuous coming of age journey where he battles with discovering himself and with trusting other people. 
Brendon was drawn to the fact that the play touched on various themes that audiences could relate to. Themes such as not feeling good enough for people, feeling comfortable in your own skin, loving so much but not having them love back, and of course the danger of closeness and being swallowed by it.  He knew that it was a story that needed to be told, because it was powerful enough to expose people to a new way of thinking. However, he also realized that the play dealt with themes that were extremely controversial, especially for a Utah audience. He knew that the only way he would be able to get it produced would mean having to do propose something a little bit crazy... 
The only way to get the story told would be to pose the show as a "no conflict" to the University and to have it be completely student produced.
This means that nothing is provided to the students from the University except a location to put on the show, bare minimum furniture for a "set" and a few props. This has resulted in the creation of an extremely barebones theatre experience.   The cast will be on stage throughout the entire course of the play and will be extremely open with the audience. Costume changes will be made on the set, sets will be built using a few benches and black boxes, and the lighting will just be a simple dimmer switch. It is a huge undertaking as the five students have assumed the role of producer, marketer, actor, costume designer, lighting designer, set designer and director. 
With that being said we still need help! The money that you help us raise will go towards buying costumes, helping us secure the licensing rights and a house manager for our four day run (which is a necessity if we are to use the Black Box Theatre). The show is completely not for profit and the actors in the show are only being paid in experience. 
In a way of showing our extreme gratitude for your help in funding this experience we have a large variety of different packages available for sale ranging from $1-$300! The various packages include: 
$1 The Slight Stumble Package
$5 The Talbott Package 
$30 The Jan Package
$50 The Chris Package
$100 The Jake Package 
$200 The Eli Package
$300 The Slipping Package 
(More information can be found in the PERKS section) 
 
The reason for this project is simple and honest. Your donation will help with opening the door for creativity and growth of knowledge for not only us, but for the community that we are going to be sharing this story with. That's because Slipping is being independently produced by young aspiring actors who want to expose audiences to a different way of thinking and to push our limits and comfort zones as artists. 
 
With this being a student led project, there are many road blocks and obstacles that we have had to and that we are going to overcome. The main one right now being working without a budget. This is restricting us from securing the rights to the play, a house manager, and getting simple costumes for our characters. We also run the high risk of protest for this show, specifically because the lead characters are homosexual. If we let fear influence our decisions, however, we would have backed out long ago. All of us firmly believe that this is a beautiful look into the human mind and that it is a story that deserves to be told. Plus let's be honest...controversy adds a little bit of fun! 
 
Of course if you can't contribute to our play we could still use your support by having you join us on this journey!! 

Follow us on Facebook @ www.facebook.com/utahstateslipping 
Follow us on Instagram @therestlessobservers
Share this fundraising effort.
Tell your friends! Share the event! 
Email us at therestlessobservers.gmail.com if you have any suggestions for how you could help us and our process! We would love to hear from you.

story:
What We're Doing

Brittany Belland and Weslie Lechner are the writers and creators of the original live satire musical, Willy Wonka and the Weed Factory.  WWWF is the story of five "Golden Spliffin" winners invited by a hemp enthusiast to come tour his factory and experience all that cannabis has to offer. Inspired by the beloved Roald Dahl classic, WWWF explores the history of weed's criminalization and its ties to social and racial injustice, as well as all the medicinal and environmental benefits that cannabis has to offer. It’s more than just a story about smoking weed, it’s a story of love, trust, and above all, acceptance of others.

We've created this show because as climate change becomes increasingly imminent, the U.S. needs to finally recognize Hemp as the sustainable solution. With the ability to make over 25,000 environmentally friendly products (such as plastic, cotton, and even biofuels), it's baffling that the hemp plant is still illegal to produce in over half the country. 

The goal of WWWF  is to reduce the stigma associated with cannabis use, both medicinally and recreationally, and to reintroduce hemp into society for what it really is - a plant that can save the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help in our endeavor to reduce the stigma surrounding cannabis because producing a thirteen cast member musical is expensive!

We're requesting $6,000 in funding to be distributed as follows,

  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Advertisements
  • Hiring of crew (lighting technician, stage manager, musicians and ushers)
  • Hiring of cast (all thirteen characters)

If we're unable to raise our goal funding amount, the professionalism of our show and our efforts to educate about the uses of hemp will suffer... and we really don't want that. So, we've offered a series of custom perks for your donations! View them to the right!

The Impact

We'll be opening our show at The Fremont Centre Theater in South Pasadena, California from July 20th till July 24th. After our initial run of five performances, we hope to take our show on tour across the country to spread the message of the benefits of cannabis.  We believe that the more who see our show and learn about marijuana's universal use, the greater the possibility of cannabis legalization and sustainable hemp production. Knowledge is power.

Risks & Challenges

While Welland Productions has experience producing short films and sketches, this is our very first full length, live musical production. We've received consultation and mentoring from many top industry professionals about our budget and our goals, but the risk of unforeseen issues popping up and not budgeting enough money is always a possibility. 

However, we greatly believe in the message of this show and are determined to produce it, no matter the difficulties. Thankfully, we've got an incredible network of support from our friends and family to help us along the way.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to provide a monetary contribution but believe in our show's message as much as we do and would like to be apart of it, please reach out to us.

We're still looking for assistance in set design, stage managing, publicity and sponsorship, and would love any and all help you're willing to offer.  You can also help us out by -

  • Follow us on Instagram (@willywonkaweedfactory) and Twitter (@weed_factory)
  • Posting this image on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, and sharing the link to our Indiegogo Campaign and website, WellandProductions.com.​

Thank you so much for your consideration! Be sure to view our list of perks for each donation made to the campaign. 

-Brittany Belland and Weslie Lechner
Writers, Producer and Director of Willy Wonka and the Weed Factory.

story:
Help Make It Happen!

We need your help to make this dream come true! 

We're a group of nerds who got together to share in our a passion for nerdlesque! the drive to bring a fantastical festival to the area.

The Mission (We have chosen to accept it)

Nerdlesque is something near and dear to our hearts. From Doctor Who to Spideman, MST3k to D&D, all of our members and collaborators are dedicated to the #nerdlife. 

About the Event

The Midwest Nerdlesque Festival will take place in November 9-10th, 2018. Our venue is the fantabulous World Famous Cabaret at the Tangier in Akron, Ohio.  

 

Headliners!

Our first headliner has been announced! Model, singer, activist, and international burlesque star Ivory joins the Midwest Nerdlesque Fest as a Friday Night Headliner! 

Check back for more updates on headliners!

What you're funding

Here's a little info on what these funds will go toward:

  • Getting the pins and shirts made! We want to be able to have them for sale at the event as well as through here. 
  • Paying for our venue! The venue is beautiful and we can't want to bring you into this amazing space. 
  • Booking top notch talent! We have some headliners in mind who will need to travel to us and a room in our host hotel. 
  • Promoting! We will be printing flyers and doing to digital ads as well to get the burly and nerdy fan in the midwest pumped for this event. 

What We Want To Do

We know between application fees and traveling costs, being involved in a festival can be a financial undertaking for performers, so we're dedicated to keeping costs for our artists down as much as we can.  We're aiming to have free admission to the events for all performers and to be able to give them some fantastic goodiebags to boot. 

Shiny Rewards

Our individual rewards are pretty fab. You'll be the coolest nerd on the block with our sparkly pins and awesome apparel.  Our pins are almost ready to go!

The shirts and sweatshirts will be shipping a bit later; we need to meet our minimum to get them printed. Soooo the more you order, the faster they will come!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to give financially, please share and get the word out! 

Interested in volunteering? Message or email us to join the team!

Local Sponsors - Message or email us for more details on additional sponsorship levels. 

Don't forget to add us on facebook, instagram, and twitter! And check out our website!

story:
Our Project

Over Here Theatre Company is producing Dolphins and Sharks, an incisive new comedy by African-American writer James Anthony Tyler at the award-winning Finborough Theatre in London. It's a play about race, class and dead end jobs set in a Harlem photocopy shop. Dolphins and Sharks will run the 12th to 30th September, 2017 with a cast of British and American actors.

Who is Over Here?

Over Here Theatre Company produces the best new American writing and rediscovered classics for British audiences. In recent years we've presented ObamAmerica, a festival of new short plays about our iconic former president and Our American Cousin, the play Lincoln was watching when he was shot. Have a look at our website http://www.overheretheatre.co.uk/

Why is this play important?

“My first supervisor was a African girl named Ann, and she had the nerve to tell me that I don’t have a right to call myself African American. I had to tell that heffa just because your people sold my people doesn’t mean I don’t got  African roots.”

Dolphins and Sharks shines a light on the lives of ordinary African-American people from different backgrounds:

Yusuf needs a break – his philosophy degree from NYU isn't opening any doors, but his new job would help him pay his overdue rent; Xiomara doesn’t want to settle for the marriage scenario her Dominican mother keeps pushing on her; and Isabel needs her job to put three kids through school, but still manages to keep her sense of humour.

All three are employees of Harlem Office, New York, a neighbourhood copy shop where promotions are rare, raises are even rarer, and racism is often on display.  

But when one staff member is given the chance to move up to manager, friendships are tested and loyalty turns out to be less valuable than cold hard cash. Soon cutbacks and office politics have everyone fighting to keep their jobs and their sanity…

This searing new comedy explores a subject that is often taboo in theatre, the prejudice that exists within a "community" as hard working individuals turn on each other rather than their corporate oppressors.

Why do we need your help?

The Finborough Theatre, although one of the Fringe's finest, is unfunded and tiny. Even if we sold all our tickets, we wouldn't meet our costs. We need to pay all the actors and the creative team a fair wage.  

What We Need

We need to raise at least £2000 to help cover costs. We had a lovely fundraiser in June with lots of entertainment but that didn't meet all of our financial needs, Of course we'd love to raise even more than £2000 but we are trying to be realistic!

To produce a play at the Finborough Theatre in London, we have a budget of over £21,000. That includes theatre rental, rehearsal space, wages for the cast and creatives. Not to mention the set, costumes, props, performance rights etc. 

Arts Council grants are rare (We're applying for the second time) and ticket prices are low in London fringe theatres. We rely on funding from our supporters to help us keep producing great American theatre in London.

What You Get

£10 will get you our gratitude and a big thank you on Facebook.

£25 gets a big thank you on Facebook and if you send us a photo we'll make it personal about how wonderful you are.

£50 gets you all of the above plus our newsletter

£100 gets you all of the above plus two tickets to the play

£200 gets you all of the above plus you get to sit in on a rehearsal and see how we work.

With Indiegogo, we get to keep what ever we raise, which is great. The project is up and running, we just need your support.

Why are we crowdfunding?

Crowdfunding is a great way to build a community of supporters. We successfully raised £3000 with Kickstarter to produce ObamAmerica.  Indiegogo is even better because even if we don't reach our goal, we get to keep what we've raised from your generous contributions.

It's also a great way to spread the word about the production. If you like what you see here, please share this page.

You can also follow us on Facebook @dolphinsandsharks, Twitter @DolphinSharksUK and Instagram dolphinssharksuk

story:
Short Summary

About Our Project

The RC Players is an entirely student-run theatre troupe at the University of Michigan, passionate about theatre in all of its facets. The RC Players is sending a cast of actors, producers, directors, and a playwright to Edinburgh, Scotland to perform the student-written piece "Anarchy at the Hearty Toadstool" at the 2016 Edinburgh Fringe Festival. 

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the largest arts festival in the world and takes place for three weeks annually during the month of August. In 2015, the festival was host to 50,459 performances of 3,314 shows at 313 unique venues--and 2016 will likely be even larger. The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is a truly unique and enriching experience.

We'll be performing our original, one-act comedy during the third week of the festival, in the Mint Studio space at the acclaimed Greenside @ Infirmary Street venue. The RC Players are so excited for the opportunity to be involved in such an amazing event.

Students Involved

Production Staff

  • Playwright: Skyler Tarnas
  • Co-Director/Stage Manager: Paul Mayer
  • Co-Director: Emma McGlashen
  • Producer: Julia Byers
  • Assistant Producer: Hannah Levine

Cast (in order of appearance)

  • Emma McGlashen as Lavinia Gerania
  • Julia Byers as Janice DeRay
  • Cameron Flynn as Bradley Crumble
  • Cassidy Strome as Avery Porige
  • Laurie Perrin as Bitsy
  • Katrina Anderson and Hannah Levine as Melody Bradashery*
  • Lydia Wandmacher as Dina Bradashery
  • Hannah Levine and Katrina Anderson as Sheriff Deakins*

*Hannah Levine and Katrina Anderson will alternate who performs which of these two roles

What We Need & What You Get

We're extremely grateful to have already received funding support from a number of sources at the University of Michigan, including the Institute for the Humanities, the Silverman Award (through the Residential College), and the Arts at Michigan program. This has allowed us to book a venue in Edinburgh, register with the festival, put down the deposit on housing in Edinburgh, and allocate money for putting together our set in Edinburgh. However, we still need a little more money to make performing at the Fringe Festival a reality.

What We Need:

  • Funding for props
  • Funding for housing
  • Funding for insurance for our venue

What you get:

  • Fun and useful perks
  • The knowledge that you helped a group of motivated and passionate students achieve their dream of performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival

The Impact

This is an amazing, once-in-a-lifetime experience for all of the members of the cast and production team. Not only will we get to experience the eclectic culture of Scotland, but we will also be witness to the cultures of dozens of other countries from around the world as we attend other shows and interact with fellow performers throughout the city. As young aspiring thespians, getting to exhibit our work on a world stage will also be incredible exposure, which could lead to future theatrical opportunities for all involved.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us financially, you can support us by following our Instagram account (@RCPFringe16), following our Twitter account (@RCPFringe16), liking our Facebook page ("RC Players Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2016"), or taking a trip to our website: www.rcpfringe2016.wordpress.com. 

We would love if you could spread the word about our trip by sharing this on Facebook or Twitter, or whatever social media platform you prefer!

story:
Short Summary  

  • I've been in the theatre since I was seven and have always been apart of it in one fashion or another. For 27 years the theatre has been my home and my passion. I've toured locally and internationally and I've been in two feature films and the TV show Crash. I was also the Unit Production Manager for a Telly Award Winning film. Moreover, I was the director of a nationally recognized acting and modeling school. My experience with on-screen acting, musical theatre, voice, dance and make-up application makes me extremely well suited to teach this craft to others.
  • All my life I've wanted to inspire others through the theater and this campaign gives me the perfect platform to do so. My goal is to have a very successful and inspirational place for students to learn and grow. I'm excited to share my gift with others and to help them find theirs.
  •  I need your support to make this dream a reality. To be a positive influence to the young children of today so we may all have a better tomorrow will mean a brighter future for us all! With your help, I can be the catalyst for this type of change.

What We Need & What You Get

  • In order to make my venture successful I need your help to achieve my goal  to raise $12,000 for start-up costs so I can open the doors to this new and exciting endeavor.
  • I will be offering some amazing perks for those going above and beyond to help me; however, all donations are appreciated.  One of the exciting perks is your name on a wall as a beneficiary. Another exciting perk is a professional photoshoot with a well known New York City photographer.
  • No matter what amount I receive, I know this pursuit will be successful and flourish because of your generous donation.

The Impact

  • Promoting a positive environment in which our children can thrive in is vital to the health and well being of not only the participant and those they touch but of the entire planet. This is my mission.
  • The success I've had with my students has been overwhelming.  I've helped students get into their college of choice; some have gone on to become singers/songwriters and actors. Students have won awards and been offered exciting opportunities in the arts; such as special invitations to perform with award winning performing artists in New York City and Las Vegas.
  • I have an outstanding reputation in the community for being professional, caring, energetic and inspiring to my students and the community as a whole.  Without the arts the community would be a less exciting and vivacious place to be.

Risks & Challenges

  • The only challenge I face in this journey is a monetary one.  I know I have the skills and drive to succeed.  I just need the capital.
  • I'm reaching out to the small business community for help and guidance in securing funding, support and business expertise so that my venture will be very successful.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you cannot contribute financially there are other ways you can help.  I can supply postcards and flyers for you to distribute and a simple word-of-mouth goes a long way.  
  • Also, remember you can also share my indiegogo sight with all your friends and family.
story_txt:
Short Summary   
I've been in the theatre since I was seven and have always been apart of it in one fashion or another. For 27 years the theatre has been my home and my passion. I've toured locally and internationally and I've been in two feature films and the TV show Crash. I was also the Unit Production Manager for a Telly Award Winning film. Moreover, I was the director of a nationally recognized acting and modeling school. My experience with on-screen acting, musical theatre, voice, dance and make-up application makes me extremely well suited to teach this craft to others. All my life I've wanted to inspire others through the theater and this campaign gives me the perfect platform to do so. My goal is to have a very successful and inspirational place for students to learn and grow. I'm excited to share my gift with others and to help them find theirs.
 I need your support to make this dream a reality. To be a positive influence to the young children of today so we may all have a better tomorrow will mean a brighter future for us all! With your help, I can be the catalyst for this type of change.  What We Need & What You Get
 
In order to make my venture successful I need your help to achieve my goal  to raise $12,000 for start-up costs so I can open the doors to this new and exciting endeavor. I will be offering some amazing perks for those going above and beyond to help me; however, all donations are appreciated.  One of the exciting perks is your name on a wall as a beneficiary. Another exciting perk is a professional photoshoot with a well known New York City photographer. No matter what amount I receive, I know this pursuit will be successful and flourish because of your generous donation.    The Impact

Promoting a positive environment in which our children can thrive in is vital to the health and well being of not only the participant and those they touch but of the entire planet. This is my mission.
 The success I've had with my students has been overwhelming.  I've helped students get into their college of choice; some have gone on to become singers/songwriters and actors. Students have won awards and been offered exciting opportunities in the arts; such as special invitations to perform with award winning performing artists in New York City and Las Vegas. I have an outstanding reputation in the community for being professional, caring, energetic and inspiring to my students and the community as a whole.  Without the arts the community would be a less exciting and vivacious place to be.    Risks & Challenges 
The only challenge I face in this journey is a monetary one.  I know I have the skills and drive to succeed.  I just need the capital. I'm reaching out to the small business community for help and guidance in securing funding, support and business expertise so that my venture will be very successful.    Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially there are other ways you can help.  I can supply postcards and flyers for you to distribute and a simple word-of-mouth goes a long way.  
Also, remember you can also share my indiegogo sight with all your friends and family.

story:
We need your help!

THE FANTASTICKS, by Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt,  is a beloved classic musical that remains as timely today as was when it first opened off-Broadway in 1960. We've assembled a fabulous group of some of the Twin Cities most popular performers to help tell this poignant tale of romance and realism: come see Gary Briggle and Wendy Lehr as the young lovers, Christina Baldwin and Jennifer Baldwin Peden as the fathers, William Gilness as El Gallo, and  Brian Sostek as The Actor!

Musical direction is provided by Jerry Rubino, the set and costumes are designed by Victoria Petrovich, the lighting is created by Michael Wangen, and the whole production is staged by Nautilus' Artistic Director Ben Krywosz.

12 performances only:
April 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 15, 16, 17,
18, 19 @ 7:30 April 9, 16 @ 2:00
Presented at the Nautilus Music-Theater studio
in Lowertown St Paul, 308 Prince St #190

We're the company that won Ivey Awards for our productions of ORDINARY DAYS, SISTER STORIES, and I AM ANNE FRANK. Although we don't always produce classic musicals, when we do we change the way that people think about telling stories through music. Perhaps you attended our productions of MAN OF LA MANCHA, CAROUSEL, or INTO THE WOODS? Or maybe you remember our premieres of JOAN OF ARC, TWISTED APPPLES, or UNTOLD LIES, or recent works such as THE LAST FIVE YEARS, THE VIEW FROM HERE,  or ORPHEUS AND EURYDICE?

Ticket prices will cover less than one-third of production expenses, so we are asking for your support. And here's the best part:

New and returning donors get access to ticket       sales immediately, and any remaining tickets will   go on sale to the general public on March 28!

It's true! Given the advance buzz around this project, we are expecting that access to THE FANTASTICKS will be the hottest ticket in town! Who doesn't want to see these fabulous performers (many of whom have appeared in Nautilus productions before)? Let their musical storytelling feed your soul, as they offer such classic Jones and Schmidt songs as "Try to Remember", "Much More", "Soon it's Gonna Rain", and "They Were You"! Join them in the intimate surroundings of Nautilus' little studio in Lowertown, St Paul's most active cultural neighborhood. And when you buy your tickets, you'll also have an option of ordering a special package deal that includes pre-show dining -- casual food at the Black Dog, or Japanese cuisine at Tanpopo restaurant, both restaurants right next door to Nautilus.

Don't miss out on the chance to pre-order your tickets to THE FANTASTICKS and actually help make the production happen. Your contribution will go toward paying performers' salaries, building the sets, hanging the lights, designing the costumes, and creating all of the other pieces of theater that make the magic happen on stage. Not only will you get to see a fabulous production with an extraordinary cast, but you'll sleep a little easier knowing that you helped make the world a little safer for new music-theater!  

Make a donation now, and we'll get in touch with you with instructions on how to order your tickets.

Thank you for your support, and we'll see you at the show!

story:
This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Provincetown Community Compact Inc, a verified nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

SUPER-LUBRICATED GOES TO DUBLIN – HELP US GET THERE

CTEK Arts has been invited to bring SUPER-LUBRICATED to the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival 2016 (www.gaytheatre.ie).  We are honored that this will be our third time at this great festival! The play will run for six performances from May 9-15. 

SUPER-LUBRICATED BY LYNDA STURNER AND JIM DALGLISH

SUPER-LUBRICATED is a comedic and compelling evening of theater featuring the playwrights as the actors. Directed by Margaret Van Sant, it is set in the wee hours of the morning as two strangers, a widow and a clerk working the grave-yard shift, discover the secret of life might be as obvious as a box hanging on a rack at the local Walgreen’s. Helen (Lynda Sturner) and Perry (Jim Dalglish) talk love, loss and condoms.

LYNDA AND JIM ARE BOTH AWARD-WINNING PLAYWRIGHTS

They also co-authored A TALENTED WOMAN, the winner of the 2013 Jeremiah Kaplan New Play Prize, and the script was a semi-finalist at The Eugene O’Neill Theater Conference. It also had readings at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, New Jersey and The Actors Studio in NYC. NY

THE PLAY HAS DEEP ROOTS IN PROVINCETOWN

Provincetown, known as the birthplace of Modern American Drama, has been instrumental in developing SUPER-LUBRICATED. The play began as one in a series of six short plays about sex called SEXTET. It was first produced by the Provincetown Theater Company in 2004.  In 2015, Margaret Van Sant chose the play for CTEK Arts Woman’s International Theater Festival. Jim and Lynda updated the play to the current time frame.

THE COMPANY

The CTEK Arts company traveling to Dublin this year are: Lynda Sturner, JIm Dalglish, Margaret Van Sant and Ellen Rubenstein, our Company/Stage Manager at our venue in Dublin, the Cobalt Cafe.

HELP “SUPER-LUBRICATED” GET TO IRELAND

Your contribution (of any amount) will help fund the following:

  • Roundtrip airfare from Boston to Dublin for the company
  • The cost of a furnished flat (with kitchen and laundry!) in Dublin for our stay.
  • Postcards, posters and playbills
  • A per diem so the actors don't have to go out busking in the street! (Though they can if they want to).
  • Basic groceries to save money on dinner out.

Other Ways

Many of you are artists trying to get your own work up and running... sometimes you're just not able to contribute in cash. But we still need (and love!) you!

Please share, re-post, tweet, busk and otherwise spread the word about our SUPER-LUBRICATED campaign. And:

  • Send your Irish friends to the International Gay Dublin Theatre Festival and SUPER-LUBRICATED!
  • Come and see us in Dublin…we’ll play great pub games after the show.
  • Send us a kind word, and come to our DUBLIN BENEFIT here at the Provincetown Theater on March 19th and enjoy Billy and Beth playing their magnificent Celtic music.

story:
The Plantation will be 100% free to the general public, and that is why we need your help!

Brave New World Repertory Theatre, a Brooklyn-based company, reaches under-served audiences to promote a love of theatre, with re-imagined classics and brave new works that reflect our diverse community. BNW’s free-to-low-cost programs range from intimate readings to large outdoor productions, and cast unique and historic Brooklyn venues in a leading role. We seek to tell stories that celebrate life and explore social justice; stories that make us laugh, feel deeply, and find common ground.

 

 $25 guarantees you a reservation, and there are many other levels of giving with fantastic perks!

 

THE PLANTATION, set in Virginia 1870, five years after the end of the Civil War and seven years before the Jim Crow backlash, is an American retelling of Anton Chekhov's play seen through the lens of Reconstruction, when the South was still occupied by the Union, African American men were given the right to vote, and 1500 were elected to public office including two U.S. Senators. Claire Beckman's adaptation aims to promote conversations about this fascinating period in American history curiously missing from most public school curricula.

In 1861, Anton Chekhov, grandson of a former serf, was 1-year-old, when The Russian Tsar, Alexander II abolished serfdom, two years before Abraham Lincoln's emancipation proclamation. Like Lincoln, "Alexander the Liberator" was also assassinated. In a January 1861 letter to Fredrick Engels, Karl Marx wrote: "In my opinion, the biggest things that are happening in the world today, are on the one hand, the movements of the slaves in America started by the death of John Brown, and on the other the movements of the serfs in Russia."  

Of course "the movements of the serfs" led to revolution, where the "movements of the slaves" were extinguished by Jim Crow.

This project began with a staged reading last summer to coincide with the 150th anniversary of the end of The Civil War, and the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Movement. Tragic and senseless events in Ferguson, Staten Island, Baltimore, Cleveland, Charleston, Baton Rouge, St. Paul and elsewhere are brutal reminders that we do not live in a post-racial America, and that the deep-seated, economic consequences, and social legacy of slavery will continue to haunt our collective consciousness if we continue to sweep our history under the rug. The Plantation is true to Chekhov's play, a human portrait of a rudderless gentry and an ambitious working class navigating life post-emancipation.

Thanks to an invitation by the Governors Island Trust, Four FREE site-specific fully mounted performances will occur in front, behind and inside the stunning pre-Civil War Commanding Officers's House in the historic Nolan Park section of the island. This season reservations will be taken for the FREE SEATING on two Sunday afternoons: September 18 and 25 at 1:00 and 3:30.

Three years ago, over coffee, fellow Carnegie-Mellon Drama alums Bob McGrath, Ridge Theater artistic director and three-time obie-winner, and Claire Beckman, BNW co-founder and producing artistic director were discussing theatre and Reconstruction, when Bob suggested setting Anton Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard" in The Old South. That spark led to Claire's adaptation and this project. Thank you Bob!

 

The Plantation's total budget of $12,000 will pay for:

Insurance: $750

Sound Equipment: $3,000

Costumes: $750

Professional Equity Actors & Designers : $5,000

Marketing & PR: $500

Transportation, fees and other expenses: $2000

 

Many thanks to the original members of The Plantation Project, who helped to develop the  inaugural staged reading of The Plantation on August 16, 2015

Craig A. Grant, Tim Craig, Lauren Young, Nick Plakias, Hale Thompson, Leonie Ettinger, Roy Eaton, AnnieRose Kafer, Tyler Egan, Alice Kors, Alice Barrett-Mitchell John Morgan, Caroline Ryburn, Brittany Giles-Jones Neville Aurelius, Al-nisa Petty, Daniel Blanda, Shawn-Herb Felton, Jonathan Kirkland, Martina Nevermann, Harrison Adams, Lucy Gwathmey, Carol Klenfner, Benjamin Furiga and Sarah Elizabeth Dickerson

story:
My name is Kristen, and I'm a Toronto-based actor, composer, and pianist. Earnshaw is a project that I am extremely passionate about, and I am thrilled to bring it to life this fall! However, I'll need your help.

Virginia Woolf once wrote that Emily Brontë "could free life from its dependence on facts; with a few touches indicate the spirit of a face so that it needs no body; by speaking of the moor make the wind blow and the thunder roar".

Let's bring that thunder to Toronto.

What We Need & What You Get

Every little bit of help is very much appreciated! I've set a fundraising goal of $2000, which includes the costs of renting a small venue with a piano for performance and rehearsal, production costs such as costumes, set and props, advertising and promotion, to mention only a few.

However, there's no way you're giving and not getting anything in return! Every donation level has a different set of perks, including some unique musical ones - check out the different perks to the right on this page!

In the event that I don't reach my fundraising goal, your donation will still be helping this project - it may simply run for a shorter period of time, or take longer than anticipated to mount.

(But, isn't October the best month for a ghost story?)

Risks & Challenges

While I have been helping produce theatre through independent companies for my entire career, this will be my first adventure producing my own work, and doing so independently. Naturally, this will pose some challenges that are new for me. However, I have a strong network among the independent theatre community, as well as a Master of Arts from University of Toronto for Study of Theatre, Drama and Performance. Your funding will be going to help an experienced theatre practitioner, who is doing a very difficult but very possible thing! And the more help I receive through Indiegogo, the more possible Earnshaw's debut will be.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to help out financially, you can still help me and Earnshaw by promoting the show through social media and recommending it to anyone who may be interested in contributing. It's a small world - any help making it a little smaller for artists is always welcome.

story:
The Dream

Dear Friends and Supporters,

It is with raucous girlish giggles that we announce that our play, Lamariya, has been chosen for the Midtown International Theatre Festival in New York. We couldn't be more humbled or grateful for the opportunity. We know we've got something here- a story worth telling. Consider joining us as we work to bring Lamariya to the stage.

What's Needed

We need to raise a minimum of 2, 000 dollars to help cover the travel expenses of the cast, crew, and artistic team- 15 people total.

Anything beyond that would be allotted towards:

  • Venue Rental
  • Hotel Costs
  • Marketing

Diversity in Theatre

In an industry where opportunites for women and people od color are few, you might be excited to know:

  • Lamariya is directed by an amazing woman, Troy Scheid, who has a number of writing and directing credits of her own.
  • Lamariya was penned by Crystal Rae, an African - American woman.
  • Lamariya's cast is entirely African- American.

Lamariya in a Nutshell

Zach and Eliza are the only teachers in Lamariya, a small Mississippi town. As they age, their hopes for a child of their own fade. But the storks, supernatural beings who crossed the Middle Passage with the townspeople's enslaved African ancestors, know Lamariya will be the birthplace of a child who will change the world. A war breaks our on earth and in heaves as two families, one ancient and one new fight the ignorance, fear and violence that are the last acts of a belief system in decline.

Other Ways You Can Help

Consider liking our Facebook page, Lamariya Play, reposting links, handing out flyers and spreading the word. All of the above are worth their weight in gold and are certainly appreciated.
story_txt:
The Dream
Dear Friends and Supporters,
It is with raucous girlish giggles that we announce that our play, Lamariya, has been chosen for the Midtown International Theatre Festival in New York. We couldn't be more humbled or grateful for the opportunity. We know we've got something here- a story worth telling. Consider joining us as we work to bring Lamariya to the stage.What's NeededWe need to raise a minimum of 2, 000 dollars to help cover the travel expenses of the cast, crew, and artistic team- 15 people total.Anything beyond that would be allotted towards:
Venue Rental
Hotel Costs
Marketing
Diversity in TheatreIn an industry where opportunites for women and people od color are few, you might be excited to know:
Lamariya is directed by an amazing woman, Troy Scheid, who has a number of writing and directing credits of her own.
Lamariya was penned by Crystal Rae, an African - American woman.
Lamariya's cast is entirely African- American.
Lamariya in a NutshellZach and Eliza are the only teachers in Lamariya, a small Mississippi town. As they age, their hopes for a child of their own fade. But the storks, supernatural beings who crossed the Middle Passage with the townspeople's enslaved African ancestors, know Lamariya will be the birthplace of a child who will change the world. A war breaks our on earth and in heaves as two families, one ancient and one new fight the ignorance, fear and violence that are the last acts of a belief system in decline.Other Ways You Can HelpConsider liking our Facebook page, Lamariya Play, reposting links, handing out flyers and spreading the word. All of the above are worth their weight in gold and are certainly appreciated.

story:
Join our Greece-based multicultural performance arts troupe, Tribal Caravan, on a wild, adventure-filled and magical journey to a desert in the middle of Nowhere Festival, Spain – Burning Man's official European event!!!

In only 2 short weeks, your help will:

1) CREATE A JAW-DROPPING OPENING CEREMONY PARADE AT NOWHERE filled with surreal & interactive performances, and all the sparkle and magic that your help makes possible!

2) SUPPORT A GREEN, COMMUNITY-BASED FESTIVAL by creating the best performance ever for a environmentally-friendly and low-impact, no-cash festival, based on the beautiful principles of self-expression, inclusion, co-operation, gifting and self-reliance.

3) SUPPORT DANCE & CIRCUS PERFORMANCE ARTS as we share weird and wonderful performance arts in multiple fun-filled workshop series at the festival and in spectacular performances during the parade.

With our campaign's perks, everyone, INCLUDING YOU, can learn these skills too, experience Nowhere Festival and become a Tribal Caravaner too!

Come Hop on Board! :) LETS SPREAD JOY AND MAGIC THE WORLD OVER!

Tribal Caravan is a multinational performance arts troupe based in Greece, with a passion for blending culturally diverse, magical and unique performance arts into surreal interactive fun-filled experiences.

Inclusion and freedom of performance expression is our bag, and its proving to really let both performance newbs and seasoned pros shine in sharing their art with the world!

Our skills: We guarantee to overstimulate the crowd's senses with frivolity and festivity with our:

  • slacliners, acrobats, aerial and trapeze artists
  • pole, tribal, African and salsa dancers (and more)
  • fire spinners, hula hoopers and flow artists
  • balcan, swing, world music and reggae musicians
  • magicians, artists, actors, comedians and clowns
Recent Performances: As a newly formed troupe, our first large-scale performance, involving almost 50 performers was Gypsies in Madness Land, a non-profit performance arts party for an anti-fascist festival in Athens Greece 2016, Αντιφασιστικο Φεστιβαλ Παραστατικων Τεχνων, raising awareness and funds for refugee causes.


It was such a phenomenal success, we are proud to say that we held the top fundraising night of the festival!

Now we need your help to keep that success train rolling!

Nowhere is Burning Man's official European event, held this year at Monegros Desert, Spain (July 5th-10th 2016). Unlike regular festivals, this environmentally-friendly arts festival is located in the desert, and is based on 10 beautiful principles:

  • Self Expression ::The freedom to be yourself
  • Self Reliance :: You are responsible for you, mentally and physically
  • No commerce :: Forget about money – there’s nothing to buy
  • Leave no trace ::From dust to dust – we only leave footprints
  • Participation :: Get involved – Nowhere is what we make it
  • Inclusion :: Everyone is welcome to be a Nobody
  • Gifting :: We give our time, effort, and gifts freely
  • Co-operation :: Together we are stronger
  • Community :: A family of individuals, we look after each other
  • Immediacy :: Make now count

    Expect to see unseen sights, magnificent large-scale creative art projects,  spectacular performances, innovative eco-projects and many acts of human awesomeness!

    We want to teach you our arts, document the whole journey and share with you the experience of Nowhere's celebration of all things beautiful about humanity!


We need to raise $3,500!

All of the money goes to aiding 6-10 Tribal Caravaners in creating the best experience for the 2000+ festival attendees, and sharing the surreal and unique experience with YOU!

Having previously being focused on a non-profit antifascist festival event, we now have just 2 short weeks to raise the funds needed to create a spectacular performance arts experience for Nowhere festival in Spain.

We have a short time to prepare, and performing in the desert living self-reliant comes with challenges, but with your donations we can undoubtedly make a magical and surreal experience a living reality for 1000s of people, and you can join the ride!

1) WITNESS TRIBAL CARAVAN: The Opening Ceremony Parade

Beginning at the gates to Nowhere, Tribal Caravan will spin a story that inspires festival attendees to join Tribal Caravan and a whole host of whacky art cars in experiencing a fairy tale journey through Nowhere, stopping at phenemonal art installations and locations that set the scene for spectacular performances culminating in a fiery battle scene finale!

  • Magnificent Costumes
    To immerse attendees minds in fantastical scenarios and performances, we have to look the part…and often be fire retardant too!
  • Innovative Stage/Interactive Props
    How about fairy glitter ‘bombs’ for the crowd, or getting them to super-soak tribal dancers to make their outfit burst into a rainbow of colors as they dance...our imagination is the only limit.
  • Mobile Lighting & Sound Equipment
    Its a parade, meaning that being loud, bright and proud also requires this equipment to be mobile.
  • Transport of Equipment & Supplies
    Getting all of the equipment and supplies from Greece to Monegros Desert, Spain is challenging.

2) SUMMON TRIBAL CARAVAN: Weddings, Parties & Ad Hoc Events

We want to give the most we can possibly give, including performing  at our utmost best for festival attendees, both at the wedding and any other wonderful events at the festival!


3) BECOME TRIBAL CARAVAN: Workshops

Throughout the whole festival we will host workshop series including:

  • aerial acrobatics
  • hula hoop
  • strength & flexibility
  • tribal dance
With a possibility of workshop for kids too!

You want a specific perk?  Tell us!
We welcome perk suggestions & can make a special perk just for YOU!!!

Not only do you support an amazing event that is based on admirable values, and support artists in Greece sharing unique performance arts with an international audience, we also have fantastic perks to thank you for  contributing to our campaign.

We have perks that let you join the Tribal Caravan and Going Nowhere experience! : 

  • One of a kind Greek Getaway Experience packages
  • Funky Tribal Caravan merchandise perks
  • Fun-filled, one-on-one, private Skype lessons in a variety of performance art skills, including Tribal Dance, Hula Hoop Dance, Burlesque & Strength/flexibility training.
  • Digital & physical perks documenting the behind the scenes journey to Nowhere.  

You can also gift your perk to a friend of your choosing, or get a friend to gift it to you ;)

"I wish I could donate, but my budget is very tight right now."

You can still help!  All levels of support are appreciated including spreading the word and suggesting to others to aid our campaign...by mouth, phone, email, Twitter, Facebook, fax, Morse code, smoke signals, or even a message in a bottle, your help is wholeheartedly appreciated.



When will I receive my perks?

We will deliver most of our digital perks during the campaign, our Nowhere related perks by August 2016 and our experience perks can be redeemed by booking your dates anytime until October 2017.

How do I reach you?

You can email Carla Clark at cclark@gnif.org, or message us on the Tribal Caravan Facebook page.

Can my perk be redeemed by a friend of my choosing?

Yes we love the gift og giving, of course you can! Just give us a shout at tribalcaravan@gmail.com, or message us on the Tribal Caravan Facebook page.

Do you receive any payment from the festival?

For our performances or workshops, no. However, we are very thankful to have been awarded a grant of up to 620 euro that we can redeem after the festival using receipts of our payments: for the transport of some equipment and the opening ceremony costs (see above). We will use this money to guarantee funding all perks, and if we exceed our funraising goal, it will fund our other stretch goals too (see below).   

We have really been budgeting the minimum necessary to do Going Nowhere Festival attendees proud and give them a performance experience they will never forget!

What can we do if we raise more than our goal? More Magic!

  • Take the opening ceremony to the next level!!! 
  • Enhance contributors prizes and Nowhere video documentary with some extra sparkle.
  • Charitable donations to non-profit Nowhere festival.
  • Help fund Tribal Caravan’s next fantastical event.

Every second of your time and every dollar of your donation is a special gift that we lovingly appreciate. We are eternally thankful for you helping support performance arts in Greece as well as low-impact , green and positivity-focused festivals, in keeping, magic, wonder and unity alive.

story:
We're creating a bold new multimedia play, exploring the most basic of human needs... the search for love, sex, life-work balance, and the perfect single-malt scotch! And through this Indiegogo campaign, you can secure your tickets and contribute to the development of this play!

Co-written by David Steele, Victoria Chong Der and Davern Wright and based on the original writings of David Steele, the play will premiere at the soon-to-be-renovated Thick House Theater in San Francisco's Potrero Hill Neighborhood next summer, July 6-30, 2017, in a co-production with leading playwright incubator PlayGround and music festival producer Noise Pop.

The play was originally conceived by San Francisco "renaissance man" David Steele who, in addition to writing, also is a financial planner, restauranteur, yoga studio-owner, and managing partner of Noise Pop (Treasure Island Music Festival, 20th Street Block Party, Swedish American Hall). Noise Pop will help curate the sound track to the production, featuring the best of contemporary up-and-coming bands and 80s rock. To read more about David, visit http://www.sfchronicle.com/business/networth/ar....

Co-writing the play are two PlayGround veteran playwrights, Victoria Chong Der and Davern Wright. PlayGround Artistic Director Jim Kleinmann is slated to direct. The play tells the story of six intertwined characters (La Ronde-style), each struggling with self-destructive tendencies, set in the bar, hotel rooms, doctor’s office, and apartments where their stories play out.

To reach opening night, we need to raise $25,000. That money helps cover the costs of the actors, designers, costumes, lighting equipment, props, videos, rehearsal space, theatre rental, and much, much more! In addition, for all donors of $1,000 or more to the campaign, a portion of your gift directly supports the $300,000 Thick House Renovations Campaign, helping bring much-needed improvements to the Thick House Theater, including new air conditioning, seating, theatrical lighting, signage, as well as lobby and bathroom upgrades, and establishing this venue as a leading center for the development and production of new plays. [NOTE: It’s no coincidence that VIGNETTES ON LOVE will premiere in the soon-to-be-renovated Thick House Theater; In his capacity as a PlayGround Board Member, David Steele has been instrumental in PlayGround’s decision to sign a multi-year master lease for Thick House and the successful fundraising efforts for the Thick House renovations… $246,000 to date. By 2017, there will be no finer 99-seat venue in San Francisco!] Well, suffice it to say, we can't do it alone. Here's where you come in...

When you make your tax-deductible contribution to the VIGNETTES ON LOVE Premiere campaign, you not only get the deep satisfaction of knowing you're helping to create something fun and entertaining (and maybe just a little bit risqué), you'll also receive some wonderful perks: a pair of free tickets, a signed show poster, an invitation to the VIP opening night performance and post-show reception (July 8), recognition in the playbill, Producer's credit, or your very own theatre seat permanently engraved with your name. Check out the complete list and find the donor level and perks that're just right for you!

WE THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

Vignettes on Love is a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround, a California 501c3 nonprofit corporation (Federal ID 94-3336399). All contributions are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
The Winter’s Tale, one of Shakespeare’s most mature and beautiful works, brings audiences on a fable-like journey, exploring the themes of jealousy, tyranny, repentance, reconciliation, and ultimately forgiveness.  We at Seoul Shakespeare Company are currently in rehearsal to bring this work to Korea’s theatre district, and we need the support of people like you to help us achieve this goal.

Impact

By contributing to this production, you will help to bring the brilliance of Shakespeare to diverse audiences in Korea. In addition, you will be supporting a diverse artistic community in Seoul and allowing us to continue to create theatrical art in Korea’s international community.  

An Introduction to Seoul Shakespeare Company

Seoul Shakespeare Company is an all-volunteer theatre company that brings Shakespeare’s works to Seoul audiences in English, with Korean subtitles. We have existed since 2010, and have put on fully-staged productions since 2011. We typically produce one major show per year in Korea's theatre district of Daehangno, with smaller fundraising events throughout the year, as well as acting workshops that are open to the community.

We serve three main populations in Korea: 

1) Korean audience members (including students) who would like to see Shakespeare performed in the original language, 

2) English-speaking audience members (including students from international schools) who would like to see theatre performed in a language they understand 

3) English-speakers (both foreign and Korean) who want to participate in making theatre and hone their craft in the theatrical arts. 

By being an all-volunteer company, we are able to allow people of all nationalities to participate freely in the creation of theatre. At the same time, we aim to put on productions that are professional in quality, so that we are worth the time and effort of people who are serious about a future career in the theatre. Some of our past company members are now pursuing a professional career in theatre in other countries, and one of our core purposes is to provide an opportunity for English-speaking theatre people living in Korea to continue to develop their craft, while also contributing positively to Korean society.

Last year's production of Much Ado About Nothing brought a new vibrancy to our productions and was very popular with audiences, defying expectations of what could be done in Seoul's theatre community. It also marked the expansion of interest in our company among international schools in particular, and for the first time we had many groups of English-speaking students from these schools attend our performances. For many in our audience (not just students), our shows are their first exposure to live theatre or to live Shakespeare performance in particular.

What we need

This fundraising campaign is to raise the $5,000 that we need in order to make the second payment on our theatre space, which is due when we move into the theatre. It is absolutely crucial that we be able to make this payment.

We have already paid for our rehearsal space and made our first payment to the theatre using last year's ticket sales, and the ticket sales from this year's show should cover our third theatre payment as well as reimbursing our producer for our other expenses, like printing, advertising, costumes, set, and props. As long as ticket sales do well, this $5,000 is the last bit we need to make this production happen.

More about The Winter’s Tale

This year's production of The Winter's Tale builds upon the success of last year's Much Ado About Nothing, shifting from last year’s Elizabethan setting to a roughly Victorian/Edwardian period. Much Ado About Nothing’s warm and joyful mood, in which we placed an emphasis on music and dance, is carried over into the middle section of The Winter’s Tale, which takes place in a rustic, pastoral Bohemia, but is contrasted with a stark, melancholic, tragic world of Sicilia in the beginning of the play. 

The themes in The Winter’s Tale run a bit deeper and are broader in scope than those in Much Ado, and reflect Shakespeare’s most mature (and experimental, rule-bending) period of writing. Many of Shakespeare’s plays explore the psychology of heads of state, and the effects that power can have on those who wield it. In the first half of The Winter’s Tale, we explore the themes of jealousy and tyranny. Whereas in Othello, the emphasis is on the slow development of Othello’s misplaced jealousy, ending with violence, and in Much Ado About Nothing, Claudio’s jealousy is a plot device that is comedically cleared up in the end, in The Winter’s Tale, Leontes’ jealousy is acted upon near the beginning of the play. The emphasis in this play is on what unfolds afterwards as a result. We see King Leontes’ jealousy turn into tyranny, as he orders the poisoning of his friend (the Bohemian King, Polixenes), imprisons his own innocent wife (Queen Hermione), accusing her of adultery and a plot to murder him, and refuses to listen to truth or dissent, accusing even his closest advisors of being traitors when they try to persuade him that he is wrong. The strongest resistance to him comes from one of Shakespeare’s most outspoken female characters, Paulina, but even she ultimately fails to change Leontes’ mind, and Leontes orders that his newborn daughter (whose paternity he questions) be abandoned in a foreign land. In the play’s famous trial scene, Leontes’ imperviousness to truth reaches is zenith when even the oracle to the god Apollo, normally trusted religiously by Leontes, declares Hermione’s innocence and calls Leontes a jealous tyrant. Leontes calls the oracle's decree "falsehood" and insists on continuing with the trial. It is only when, in an apparent retaliation by the gods, Leontes’ beloved son Mamillius suddenly dies, followed immediately after by Hermione, that Leontes realizes he was wrong and accepts the furious wrath of a distraught Paulina. He devotes his life to repentance, and takes on Paulina as a trusted advisor and reminder of the wrongs he committed. For the next 16 years, he mourns and punishes himself for the deaths of his son and his wife, and the abandonment of his baby daughter.

So we begin with the themes of jealousy, tyranny, and tragedy. However, this mini-tragedy is only the first half of the play. In the second half, with a 16-year jump forward in time and a movement of the action to Polixenes’s rustic kingdom of Bohemia, we see Perdita, the abandoned baby daughter of Leontes and Hermione, as a 16-year old, who has grown up as the adopted daughter of a shepherd, and who captures the admiration of those around her with her elegance and wit. Not knowing of the events that led to this point in the play, she and Prince Florizel (the son of Bohemian King Polixenes) have fallen in love, and Florizel is determined that they will marry, despite her low social status, even if it means facing the wrath of his father and forfeiting his right to the crown. We see them on the day of a local sheep-shearing celebration, where events unfold that bring about a sudden escape to Leontes’ Sicilia, the reunion of Perdita and her long-repentant father Leontes, a reconciliation between the two kings, and one of Shakespeare’s most moving final scenes—which we won’t spoil for you here—a scene of reunion and forgiveness, and a testament to the healing effects of Time.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't give directly to our production, you can help us by sharing our campaign through social media, and, if you're in Korea, coming to our show!  Ticket reservations for the show are already available: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/up-next-...

Korean Bank Transfer Option

If you have a Korean bank account, you can also contribute via bank transfer.  Your contribution won't show up in our Indiegogo total, but we can still send you the perks listed above.  Send us an email to let us know that you've contributed, and whether you would like to receive the associated perks, and we'll add you to our list of donors.  Here is a link to our bank information: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/make-a-c...

 

Thank you for anything you are able to give to support this production!

  

****Please note that, on Indiegogo, making a contribution does not automatically sign you up to receive a perk.  If you would like to receive a perk, you must specifically click on the perk you would like to receive! If you accidentally donate without selecting a perk, and you would like to receive the associated perk, just email us to let us know to add you to our perks list.*****

 

Seoul Shakespeare Company Email: 

info@seoulshakespeare.com

 

Email for questions about ticketing:

sscticketing@gmail.com 

 

The Winter's Tale webpage: 

http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/up-next-...

 

Ticket Reservation page: 

http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/ticket-r... 

 

Seoul Shakespeare Company Home Page: 

http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/ 

 

Seoul Shakespeare Company Facebook Page: 

https://www.facebook.com/seoulshakespeare/

Music composed and recorded by: Lauren Ash-Morgan

 

Cast:

story_txt: The Winter’s Tale, one of Shakespeare’s most mature and beautiful works, brings audiences on a fable-like journey, exploring the themes of jealousy, tyranny, repentance, reconciliation, and ultimately forgiveness.  We at Seoul Shakespeare Company are currently in rehearsal to bring this work to Korea’s theatre district, and we need the support of people like you to help us achieve this goal.ImpactBy contributing to this production, you will help to bring the brilliance of Shakespeare to diverse audiences in Korea. In addition, you will be supporting a diverse artistic community in Seoul and allowing us to continue to create theatrical art in Korea’s international community.  An Introduction to Seoul Shakespeare CompanySeoul Shakespeare Company is an all-volunteer theatre company that brings Shakespeare’s works to Seoul audiences in English, with Korean subtitles. We have existed since 2010, and have put on fully-staged productions since 2011. We typically produce one major show per year in Korea's theatre district of Daehangno, with smaller fundraising events throughout the year, as well as acting workshops that are open to the community.We serve three main populations in Korea: 1) Korean audience members (including students) who would like to see Shakespeare performed in the original language, 2) English-speaking audience members (including students from international schools) who would like to see theatre performed in a language they understand 3) English-speakers (both foreign and Korean) who want to participate in making theatre and hone their craft in the theatrical arts. By being an all-volunteer company, we are able to allow people of all nationalities to participate freely in the creation of theatre. At the same time, we aim to put on productions that are professional in quality, so that we are worth the time and effort of people who are serious about a future career in the theatre. Some of our past company members are now pursuing a professional career in theatre in other countries, and one of our core purposes is to provide an opportunity for English-speaking theatre people living in Korea to continue to develop their craft, while also contributing positively to Korean society.Last year's production of Much Ado About Nothing brought a new vibrancy to our productions and was very popular with audiences, defying expectations of what could be done in Seoul's theatre community. It also marked the expansion of interest in our company among international schools in particular, and for the first time we had many groups of English-speaking students from these schools attend our performances. For many in our audience (not just students), our shows are their first exposure to live theatre or to live Shakespeare performance in particular.What we needThis fundraising campaign is to raise the $5,000 that we need in order to make the second payment on our theatre space, which is due when we move into the theatre. It is absolutely crucial that we be able to make this payment.We have already paid for our rehearsal space and made our first payment to the theatre using last year's ticket sales, and the ticket sales from this year's show should cover our third theatre payment as well as reimbursing our producer for our other expenses, like printing, advertising, costumes, set, and props. As long as ticket sales do well, this $5,000 is the last bit we need to make this production happen.More about The Winter’s TaleThis year's production of The Winter's Tale builds upon the success of last year's Much Ado About Nothing, shifting from last year’s Elizabethan setting to a roughly Victorian/Edwardian period. Much Ado About Nothing’s warm and joyful mood, in which we placed an emphasis on music and dance, is carried over into the middle section of The Winter’s Tale, which takes place in a rustic, pastoral Bohemia, but is contrasted with a stark, melancholic, tragic world of Sicilia in the beginning of the play. The themes in The Winter’s Tale run a bit deeper and are broader in scope than those in Much Ado, and reflect Shakespeare’s most mature (and experimental, rule-bending) period of writing. Many of Shakespeare’s plays explore the psychology of heads of state, and the effects that power can have on those who wield it. In the first half of The Winter’s Tale, we explore the themes of jealousy and tyranny. Whereas in Othello, the emphasis is on the slow development of Othello’s misplaced jealousy, ending with violence, and in Much Ado About Nothing, Claudio’s jealousy is a plot device that is comedically cleared up in the end, in The Winter’s Tale, Leontes’ jealousy is acted upon near the beginning of the play. The emphasis in this play is on what unfolds afterwards as a result. We see King Leontes’ jealousy turn into tyranny, as he orders the poisoning of his friend (the Bohemian King, Polixenes), imprisons his own innocent wife (Queen Hermione), accusing her of adultery and a plot to murder him, and refuses to listen to truth or dissent, accusing even his closest advisors of being traitors when they try to persuade him that he is wrong. The strongest resistance to him comes from one of Shakespeare’s most outspoken female characters, Paulina, but even she ultimately fails to change Leontes’ mind, and Leontes orders that his newborn daughter (whose paternity he questions) be abandoned in a foreign land. In the play’s famous trial scene, Leontes’ imperviousness to truth reaches is zenith when even the oracle to the god Apollo, normally trusted religiously by Leontes, declares Hermione’s innocence and calls Leontes a jealous tyrant. Leontes calls the oracle's decree "falsehood" and insists on continuing with the trial. It is only when, in an apparent retaliation by the gods, Leontes’ beloved son Mamillius suddenly dies, followed immediately after by Hermione, that Leontes realizes he was wrong and accepts the furious wrath of a distraught Paulina. He devotes his life to repentance, and takes on Paulina as a trusted advisor and reminder of the wrongs he committed. For the next 16 years, he mourns and punishes himself for the deaths of his son and his wife, and the abandonment of his baby daughter.So we begin with the themes of jealousy, tyranny, and tragedy. However, this mini-tragedy is only the first half of the play. In the second half, with a 16-year jump forward in time and a movement of the action to Polixenes’s rustic kingdom of Bohemia, we see Perdita, the abandoned baby daughter of Leontes and Hermione, as a 16-year old, who has grown up as the adopted daughter of a shepherd, and who captures the admiration of those around her with her elegance and wit. Not knowing of the events that led to this point in the play, she and Prince Florizel (the son of Bohemian King Polixenes) have fallen in love, and Florizel is determined that they will marry, despite her low social status, even if it means facing the wrath of his father and forfeiting his right to the crown. We see them on the day of a local sheep-shearing celebration, where events unfold that bring about a sudden escape to Leontes’ Sicilia, the reunion of Perdita and her long-repentant father Leontes, a reconciliation between the two kings, and one of Shakespeare’s most moving final scenes—which we won’t spoil for you here—a scene of reunion and forgiveness, and a testament to the healing effects of Time.Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you can't give directly to our production, you can help us by sharing our campaign through social media, and, if you're in Korea, coming to our show!  Ticket reservations for the show are already available: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/up-next-...Korean Bank Transfer OptionIf you have a Korean bank account, you can also contribute via bank transfer.  Your contribution won't show up in our Indiegogo total, but we can still send you the perks listed above.  Send us an email to let us know that you've contributed, and whether you would like to receive the associated perks, and we'll add you to our list of donors.  Here is a link to our bank information: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/make-a-c... Thank you for anything you are able to give to support this production!  ****Please note that, on Indiegogo, making a contribution does not automatically sign you up to receive a perk.  If you would like to receive a perk, you must specifically click on the perk you would like to receive! If you accidentally donate without selecting a perk, and you would like to receive the associated perk, just email us to let us know to add you to our perks list.***** Seoul Shakespeare Company Email: info@seoulshakespeare.com Email for questions about ticketing:sscticketing@gmail.com  The Winter's Tale webpage: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/up-next-... Ticket Reservation page: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/ticket-r...  Seoul Shakespeare Company Home Page: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/  Seoul Shakespeare Company Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/seoulshakespeare/   Crew:Director: Michael DowneyArtistic Director/Producer/Costumer/Sound Designer: Lauren Ash-MorganStage Manager: Megan HammondLighting Designer: Iain CulpVenue Coordinator: Charles JeongIndiegogo video editor: Lauren Ash-MorganMusic composed and recorded by: Lauren Ash-Morgan Cast: Archidamus/Autolycus: Charles JeongCamillo: Josh KrootLeontes: Jamie HoranPolixenes: Jeffrey WagnerHermione/Bohemian: Hana KellyAntigonus: John MichaelsFirst Lord/Jailer/Shepherd: Jason CutlerSecond Lord/Florizel: David ChoiMamillius/Perdita: Kim HymanEmilia: Sarah McRobertsSecond Lady/Mopsa: Min YoungThird Lady: Hye Bin LeePaulina/Time/Bohemian: Lauren Ash-MorganDion/Clown: A.J. story:
Jump! has received an in-kind grant from American Conservatory Theater  in San Francisco,  under their Community Space Sharing Initiative to present Springboard Series IX, new short plays, excerpts, and monologues created by local playwrights.   These artists responded to Jump’s mission of telling authentic stories of mental illness from a variety of perspectives by creating monologues (Diana Slampyak, Suzanne Gamble and Jeanne Lupton;) short works (Ashley Smiley and Gaetana Caldwell-Smith) and a full length play (Roberta D'Alois). We  feature local playwrights, actors, and other artists with an eye toward involving the community at large as audience responders to the issues presented in our work.


Jump! Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Jump! Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
